Pytheus can handle multiple ancilla detectors and removed_connections to forbid unwanted links.  \n   3) Percolation cell is conceptually interesting but essentially a repetition of entanglement\u2010swapping chains in different configurations; less striking as a single target.\n\n Step 3: Pick the router (Option 2) \u2013 it\u2019s novel in the quantum\u2010network literature, it\u2019s independent of state\u2010generation implementation, and Pytheus can optimize a linear\u2010optical multiport with single\u2010photon sources and ancilla detectors to realize a family of heralded swaps.\n\n Step 4: This idea is novel because \u2026  \n   \u2013 In existing linear-optical examples one picks one pair to swap at a time; here a single fixed multiport allows heralded entangling of any two out of N memory nodes simply by postselecting on different detector patterns.  \n   \u2013 It generalizes entanglement swapping to a fully passive, reconfigurable (\u201crouter\u201d) architecture, opening a pathway to scalable quantum\u2010network switches.\n\n Step 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all additional constraints because \u2026  \n   \u2013 It uses only abstract photonic modes and linear optics (single\u2010photon sources and beam splitters) plus ancilla detectors\u2014exactly what Pytheus can optimize.  \n   \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward or cavities/resonances are needed; a single static interferometer plus heralding detectors suffices.  \n   \u2013 The target is a family of Bell\u2010swap outcomes (i.e. entanglement swapping transformations), not raw state generation, and it directly addresses a new quantum\u2010network primitive.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the target I suggest for Pytheus:\n\nDescription:\n Design a fixed linear\u2010optical \u201centanglement router\u201d that passively connects any two chosen nodes of a small Rydberg\u2010atom array network, purely by heralding on which ancilla detectors click.  Physically, each of the N array nodes (e.g. N=3 or 4 for demonstration) holds a Rydberg atomic qubit whose excitation can be converted into a single photon.  We assume that each node emits one photon entangled with its atomic memory (an abstract photonic mode).  All N photons enter a single N-port interferometer network, mix via beam splitters and phase shifters, and exit at output ports monitored by ancilla photon-number-resolving detectors.  Different click patterns at these ancilla detectors herald a Bell\u2010pair between exactly two of the memory qubits\u2014thereby routing entanglement on demand, without reconfiguring optics.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Generalizes entanglement swapping to a fully passive, reconfigurable router.  \n \u2022 Enables multiplexed, on-demand Bell\u2010links across any pair of atomic memory nodes.  \n \u2022 Lays groundwork for scalable quantum\u2010network switches and network\u2010coding primitives in Rydberg-based quantum repeaters or quantum internet nodes.\n\nKey Pytheus configuration elements (expert to flesh out):\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0,\u2026,N\u20131]  (one photon per memory node)  \n \u2022 a single multiport network (to be optimized) with N inputs \u2192 M outputs (M\u2265N)  \n \u2022 ancilla detectors on M\u20132 ports, leaving 2 \u201cmemory\u2010link\u201d output ports free  \n \u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct two-photon collisions between non-chosen node pairs if desired  \n \u2022 target_quantum: a set of Bell states on every 2-node subset; optimize so that each ancilla\u2010click pattern projects the remaining two output modes onto |00>+|11>  \n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the minimal multiport interferometer and detector arrangement that, upon heralding, routes entanglement between arbitrary node pairs\u2014an architecture-level quantum\u2010network primitive novel to the linear\u2010optical toolbox.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router\u201d proposal. The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Whenever exactly one detector Di clicks, the remaining two (unclicked) output modes are projected into a two-qubit Bell state |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of Rydberg memories.     "output": "Here is a completely new quantum\u2010network primitive combining Rydberg\u2010atom memories with an entangled\u2010state transformation\u2014no raw \u201cstate generation,\u201d just purification (distillation) of existing links via linear optics and heralding:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cRydberg-Enhanced Entanglement Distillation\u201d\n\nexplanation:  \n\u2022 Setup: Four Rydberg-atom memory nodes A, B, C, D each emit one photon (abstract modes 0,1,2,3).  A\u2013B and C\u2013D each share a *partially* entangled link of the form |00\u27e9+\u03b5|11\u27e9 (e.g. from imperfect fiber channels).  \n\u2022 Goal: Using *one* static linear-optical device + heralding, convert these two weak links into *one* high-fidelity Bell pair between A and B.  This is the Procrustean entanglement\u2010purification protocol realized as a single \u201cdistillation router.\u201d  \n\u2022 Network: All four photons enter a fixed multiport interferometer (to be found by Pytheus) with 6 output ports.  Three of these outputs go to ancilla photon\u00adnumber\u2010resolving detectors D4,D5,D6; the remaining two outputs map back onto the memories A,B.  We enforce no direct \u201ccross-talk\u201d between the bad link C\u2013D and the target memories by removed_connections=[[0,3],[1,2]].  \n\u2022 Heralding: Upon coincidence clicks on exactly two specified ancilla detectors (e.g. D4+D5), the unmeasured outputs project the A\u2013B memories onto the *maximally* entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9\u2014i.e. distilled from the two noisy inputs.  \n\nconfig (example for one heralding pattern):  \n{'description':'Rydberg entanglement distillation','foldername':'ryd_distill',  \n 'single_emitters':[0,1,2,3],  \n 'num_anc':3,  \n 'heralding_out':[4,5],          # detectors whose coincidence heralds success  \n 'target_quantum':['00','11'],   # A\u2013B Bell pair  \n 'removed_connections':[[0,3],[1,2]],  \n 'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr',  \n 'edges_tried':50,'tries_per_edge':10,'samples':20,  \n 'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True  \n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:  \n1) Entanglement purification is a *foundational* network primitive for any quantum repeater or distributed\u2010memory architecture\u2014but no linear-optical, static device for Rydberg\u2010memory\u2010based links has been designed yet.  \n2) By changing which ancilla\u2010detector pair is heralded, one can distil either A\u2013B or C\u2013D, or even route purified entanglement to other node\u2010pairs in a larger array.  \n3) This naturally extends to multi\u00adcopy distillation (use 2N memories \u2192 one N-round protocol) and to higher\u2010dimensional \u201cqutrit\u201d or \u201cququart\u201d purification by simply increasing the interferometer size and detector bank.  \n\nAll of this lies fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (single-photon emitters, static linear optics, number-resolving heralds, abstract state encoding) and focuses on an essential *transformation*\u2014distillation\u2014rather than raw entangled\u2010state creation."

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"rydberg atom array\" and \"entangled quantum state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. We assume that each node emits one photon entangled with its atomic memory (an abstract photonic mode).  All N photons enter a single N-port interferometer network, mix via beam splitters and phase shifters, and exit at output ports monitored by ancilla photon-number-resolving detectors. Each node coherently converts its atomic excitation into one photon (abstract mode 0,1,2). These three photons enter a single 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus). The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Whenever exactly one detector Di clicks, the remaining two (unclicked) output modes are projected into a two-qubit Bell state |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of Rydberg memories. Thus:\n \u2022 D0 click \u2192 entangles B&C  \n \u2022 D1 click \u2192 entangles A&C  \n \u2022 D2 click \u2192 entangles A&B  \n\nThis is a passive, heralded entanglement router: by post-selecting on which detector fires, we choose which pair of memories becomes entangled, without reconfiguring the optics.\n\nconfig (example for heralding D2 \u2192 entangle A&B):\n{'description':'Passive 3-node entanglement router for Rydberg memories','foldername':'RydbergRouter3','single_emitters':[0,1,2],'num_anc':1,'heralding_out':[2],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'in_nodes':[],'out_nodes':[],'anc_detectors':[],'removed_connections':[],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':30,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':10,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo cover all three routing patterns, one simply repeats the optimization with heralding_out=[0] and heralding_out=[1]: each run yields the same static interferometer but different herald-detector assignment projects onto the desired Bell link. It uses only single\u2010photon emitters, a static interferometer, and heralding detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit.  \n   c) Discard (requires dynamic feedback/control).\n\n Step 3: Choose (b) \u201c4\u2010node quantum percolation switch.\u201d  \n\n Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing linear\u2010optical design offers a single static interferometer that, upon different heralded two\u2010click patterns, projects four quantum memories into entangled Bell\u2013links across any chosen pair (edges or diagonals), thereby enabling in one device the study of entanglement percolation and dynamic network connectivity.  \n\n Step 5: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus because it only demands:  \n   \u2022 Four single\u2010photon sources (one per Rydberg node \u2192 abstract photonic modes 0\u20133)  \n   \u2022 A single 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters & phase shifters)  \n   \u2022 Four number\u2010resolving detectors  \n   \u2022 Heralding on exactly two clicks projects the remaining two modes into a Bell pair.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201c4-Node Quantum Percolation Switch for Rydberg Arrays\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have four Rydberg\u2010atom memory nodes A, B, C, D. Each node emits one photon (modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter a single 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized). The outputs go to four photon-number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the remaining two unclicked output modes are projected into the Bell state |00>+|11> of the corresponding two memories. Different click-pairs activate different network links:\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangles C&D (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangles B&D (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangles A&C (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangles A&B (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangles B&C (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangles A&D (diagonal AD)  \n\nconfig (example for heralding clicks {0,1} \u2192 entangle C&D):\n{'description':'4-node percolation switch','foldername':'RydbergPercolation4','single_emitters':[0,1,2,3],'num_anc':0,'heralding_out':[0,1],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':40,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':20,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo generate the full percolation cell, one runs six optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair. The result is one static 4\u00d74 network whose various two-click patterns switch on any desired Bell\u2010link among the four Rydberg memories. This device is the building block for testing entanglement percolation, network coding, and dynamic rerouting in quantum repeater networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal duplicates the core idea of a fixed interferometer with heralded detector clicks selecting which two memories share a Bell pair. four at Z for the two Bell measurements, two at C,D to receive the teleported states.  \n    \u2022 Heralding on specific four\u2010click patterns at Z projects A\u2192D and B\u2192C (or A\u2192C and B\u2192D if desired) without any dynamic re\u2010routing.  \n    \u2022 Exactly within Pytheus\u2019s capability: abstract modes, linear optics, single\u2010photon emitters, heralding convert into single photons (modes 0,1).  \n\u2022 A central station Z generates two photonic Bell pairs: modes 2\u20133 entangle Z\u21c4C, modes 4\u20135 entangle Z\u21c4D.  \n\u2022 All six photons     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nHeralded Linear\u2010Optical 1\u21922 QuTrIt Telecloning via Resonance-Dip Multiport Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose and analyze a fully linear-optical implementation of the first 1\u21922 qutrit telecloner, in which three probabilistic qutrit-entangled photon-pair sources feed a balanced three-mode multiport Bell measurement module synchronized by identical delay-loop \u201cresonators.\u201d Success of the telecloning is unambiguously heralded by a generalized Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel resonance dip in triple-coincidence ancilla detections, conditionally projecting the two receivers into the optimal symmetric clones of the unknown input qutrit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a target PyTheus-compatible linear-optical network in which two classical users, Alice and Bob, each send Z-basis single photons to a fully quantum node, Charlie, who entangles them with his ancilla Bell pair and performs post-selected entanglement-swapping to nonlocally compute their parity x\u2295y as a shared key bit. This minimal experiment\u2014requiring only probabilistic photon-pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors without dynamic feed-forward\u2014demonstrates a novel nonlocal XOR primitive and provides a direct semi-quantum key agreement primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nEntanglement-Fano Interferometry via Three-Channel Heralded Swaps in a Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a discrete-vs-continuum Fano-resonance experiment between distant nodes A and C in which the two-photon Bell-state amplitude from a direct Bell-pair source coherently interferes with amplitudes generated by successive two-hop (via B) and three-hop (via D\u2192E) heralded entanglement swaps, with static polarization phase shifts \u03c6\u2082 and \u03c6\u2083 controlling the interference.  The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the target I suggest for Pytheus:\n\nDescription:\n Design a fixed linear\u2010optical \u201centanglement router\u201d that passively connects any two chosen nodes of a small Rydberg\u2010atom array network, purely by heralding on which ancilla detectors click.  Physically, each of the N array nodes (e.g. N=3 or 4 for demonstration) holds a Rydberg atomic qubit whose excitation can be converted into a single photon.  We assume that each node emits one photon entangled with its atomic memory (an abstract photonic mode).  All N photons enter a single N-port interferometer network, mix via beam splitters and phase shifters, and exit at output ports monitored by ancilla photon-number-resolving detectors.  Different click patterns at these ancilla detectors herald a Bell\u2010pair between exactly two of the memory qubits\u2014thereby routing entanglement on demand, without reconfiguring optics.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Generalizes entanglement swapping to a fully passive, reconfigurable router.  \n \u2022 Enables multiplexed, on-demand Bell\u2010links across any pair of atomic memory nodes.  \n \u2022 Lays groundwork for scalable quantum\u2010network switches and network\u2010coding primitives in Rydberg-based quantum repeaters or quantum internet nodes.\n\nKey Pytheus configuration elements (expert to flesh out):\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0,\u2026,N\u20131]  (one photon per memory node)  \n \u2022 a single multiport network (to be optimized) with N inputs \u2192 M outputs (M\u2265N)  \n \u2022 ancilla detectors on M\u20132 ports, leaving 2 \u201cmemory\u2010link\u201d output ports free  \n \u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct two-photon collisions between non-chosen node pairs if desired  \n \u2022 target_quantum: a set of Bell states on every 2-node subset; optimize so that each ancilla\u2010click pattern projects the remaining two output modes onto |00>+|11>  \n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the minimal multiport interferometer and detector arrangement that, upon heralding, routes entanglement between arbitrary node pairs\u2014an architecture-level quantum\u2010network primitive novel to the linear\u2010optical toolbox.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed static multiport interferometer that passively heralds entanglement between any two of N quantum\u2010memory nodes is essentially the same \u201cmultiplexed entanglement router\u201d primitive already in the ensemble (\u201cA Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\u201d). Both rely on N emitters feeding a fixed interferometer and ancilla\u2010click heralds to select which two nodes share a Bell pair, differing only in physical platform (Rydberg vs. plasmonic waveguides). To be novel, you would need a fundamentally new routing mechanism (e.g. non-heralded, multi-stage network coding, coherent superposition of multiple routes, or indefinite causal order) rather than just changing the emitter technology.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cRydberg Entanglement Router (3-node)\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have a small Rydberg\u2010atom array of three memory nodes A, B, C. Each node coherently converts its atomic excitation into one photon (abstract mode 0,1,2). These three photons enter a single 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus). The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Whenever exactly one detector Di clicks, the remaining two (unclicked) output modes are projected into a two-qubit Bell state |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of Rydberg memories. Thus:\n \u2022 D0 click \u2192 entangles B&C  \n \u2022 D1 click \u2192 entangles A&C  \n \u2022 D2 click \u2192 entangles A&B  \n\nThis is a passive, heralded entanglement router: by post-selecting on which detector fires, we choose which pair of memories becomes entangled, without reconfiguring the optics.\n\nconfig (example for heralding D2 \u2192 entangle A&B):\n{'description':'Passive 3-node entanglement router for Rydberg memories','foldername':'RydbergRouter3','single_emitters':[0,1,2],'num_anc':1,'heralding_out':[2],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'in_nodes':[],'out_nodes':[],'anc_detectors':[],'removed_connections':[],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':30,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':10,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo cover all three routing patterns, one simply repeats the optimization with heralding_out=[0] and heralding_out=[1]: each run yields the same static interferometer but different herald-detector assignment projects onto the desired Bell link. This architecture scales to N nodes via an N\u00d7N multiport and N single-photon sources.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed 3-node \u201cRydberg Entanglement Router\u201d implements exactly the same passive, heralded routing primitive as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides,\u201d merely swapping in Rydberg emitters.     "output": "Thought: This proposal implements exactly the same two\u2010qubit \u201cbutterfly\u201d network\u2010coding primitive already put forward in the ensemble (Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross\u2010Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits), only swapping the physical emitter platform to Rydberg atoms. To be novel, you would need a fundamentally new element\u2014e.g. higher-dimensional network coding, coherent superposition of multiple code paths, indefinite causal order in the butterfly code, or a multi-stage adaptive coding architecture\u2014rather than a straightforward platform swap."

{
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"rydberg atom array\" and \"entangled quantum state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Pytheus can handle multiple ancilla detectors and removed_connections to forbid unwanted links.  \n   3) Percolation cell is conceptually interesting but essentially a repetition of entanglement\u2010swapping chains in different configurations; less striking as a single target.\n\n Step 3: Pick the router (Option 2) \u2013 it\u2019s novel in the quantum\u2010network literature, it\u2019s independent of state\u2010generation implementation, and Pytheus can optimize a linear\u2010optical multiport with single\u2010photon sources and ancilla detectors to realize a family of heralded swaps.\n\n Step 4: This idea is novel because \u2026  \n   \u2013 In existing linear-optical examples one picks one pair to swap at a time; here a single fixed multiport allows heralded entangling of any two out of N memory nodes simply by postselecting on different detector patterns.  \n   \u2013 It generalizes entanglement swapping to a fully passive, reconfigurable (\u201crouter\u201d) architecture, opening a pathway to scalable quantum\u2010network switches.\n\n Step 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all additional constraints because \u2026  \n   \u2013 It uses only abstract photonic modes and linear optics (single\u2010photon sources and beam splitters) plus ancilla detectors\u2014exactly what Pytheus can optimize.  \n   \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward or cavities/resonances are needed; a single static interferometer plus heralding detectors suffices.  \n   \u2013 The target is a family of Bell\u2010swap outcomes (i.e. entanglement swapping transformations), not raw state generation, and it directly addresses a new quantum\u2010network primitive.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the target I suggest for Pytheus:\n\nDescription:\n Design a fixed linear\u2010optical \u201centanglement router\u201d that passively connects any two chosen nodes of a small Rydberg\u2010atom array network, purely by heralding on which ancilla detectors click.  Physically, each of the N array nodes (e.g. N=3 or 4 for demonstration) holds a Rydberg atomic qubit whose excitation can be converted into a single photon.  We assume that each node emits one photon entangled with its atomic memory (an abstract photonic mode).  All N photons enter a single N-port interferometer network, mix via beam splitters and phase shifters, and exit at output ports monitored by ancilla photon-number-resolving detectors.  Different click patterns at these ancilla detectors herald a Bell\u2010pair between exactly two of the memory qubits\u2014thereby routing entanglement on demand, without reconfiguring optics.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Generalizes entanglement swapping to a fully passive, reconfigurable router.  \n \u2022 Enables multiplexed, on-demand Bell\u2010links across any pair of atomic memory nodes.  \n \u2022 Lays groundwork for scalable quantum\u2010network switches and network\u2010coding primitives in Rydberg-based quantum repeaters or quantum internet nodes.\n\nKey Pytheus configuration elements (expert to flesh out):\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0,\u2026,N\u20131]  (one photon per memory node)  \n \u2022 a single multiport network (to be optimized) with N inputs \u2192 M outputs (M\u2265N)  \n \u2022 ancilla detectors on M\u20132 ports, leaving 2 \u201cmemory\u2010link\u201d output ports free  \n \u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct two-photon collisions between non-chosen node pairs if desired  \n \u2022 target_quantum: a set of Bell states on every 2-node subset; optimize so that each ancilla\u2010click pattern projects the remaining two output modes onto |00>+|11>  \n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the minimal multiport interferometer and detector arrangement that, upon heralding, routes entanglement between arbitrary node pairs\u2014an architecture-level quantum\u2010network primitive novel to the linear\u2010optical toolbox.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router\u201d proposal. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to combine \u201cRydberg atom array\u201d and \u201centangled quantum state\u201d in a network context, steering clear of raw state generation:\n   a) A three\u2010node \u201centanglement router\u201d for a Rydberg\u2010atom array: each atom emits one photon into a static 3\u00d73 interferometer. A click on one output port heralds a Bell\u2010pair on the other two ports, thereby routing entanglement between any two memory qubits on demand.  \n   b) A four\u2010node \u201centanglement\u2010percolation cell\u201d on a square of Rydberg sites: probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources on each edge, with chosen Bell measurements (i.e. certain beam-splitter + detector modules) enabling entanglement swapping along different paths (edge vs diagonal), exploring connectivity thresholds.  \n   c) A superposed\u2010order entanglement swap between two pairs of Rydberg nodes: two entanglement-swapping modules placed in a Mach\u2013Zehnder\u2013like arrangement so that the order of swaps (swap AB\u2192C vs C\u2192D) is in coherent superposition\u2014studying indefinite\u2010causal\u2010order effects in network links.  \n Step 2: Compare to past Pytheus experiments and feasibility:\n   a) The 3-node router is not in the list (past work only did fixed entanglement swapping, not a single device that can herald any of three links). It uses only single-photon sources, linear optics, and heralding detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope.  \n   b) The percolation cell is largely repeated swapping modules\u2014less novel.  \n   c) Indefinite swap order would require coherent feed-forward or nested interferometry beyond Pytheus\u2019s feedback-free remit.  \n Step 3: Select (a) the 3-node entanglement router as the prime idea: it\u2019s a new network primitive, highly generalizable to N nodes, and purely static/honest linear optics.  \n Step 4: This idea is novel because no prior linear\u2010optical setup passively routes entanglement on demand between any pair of N quantum memories with one interferometer and heralding alone.  \n Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses only abstract photonic modes (one per Rydberg node), a static multiport network, single-photon sources, and heralding detectors\u2014exactly what Pytheus can optimize, without dynamic control or cavities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cRydberg Entanglement Router (3-node)\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have a small Rydberg\u2010atom array of three memory nodes A, B, C. Each node coherently converts its atomic excitation into one photon (abstract mode 0,1,2). These three photons enter a single 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus). The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Whenever exactly one detector Di clicks, the remaining two (unclicked) output modes are projected into a two-qubit Bell state |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of Rydberg memories. Thus:\n \u2022 D0 click \u2192 entangles B&C  \n \u2022 D1 click \u2192 entangles A&C  \n \u2022 D2 click \u2192 entangles A&B  \n\nThis is a passive, heralded entanglement router: by post-selecting on which detector fires, we choose which pair of memories becomes entangled, without reconfiguring the optics.\n\nconfig (example for heralding D2 \u2192 entangle A&B):\n{'description':'Passive 3-node entanglement router for Rydberg memories','foldername':'RydbergRouter3','single_emitters':[0,1,2],'num_anc':1,'heralding_out':[2],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'in_nodes':[],'out_nodes':[],'anc_detectors':[],'removed_connections':[],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':30,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':10,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo cover all three routing patterns, one simply repeats the optimization with heralding_out=[0] and heralding_out=[1]: each run yields the same static interferometer but different herald-detector assignment projects onto the desired Bell link. This architecture scales to N nodes via an N\u00d7N multiport and N single-photon sources.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This target is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router\u201d proposal. To achieve genuine novelty, you\u2019d need a fundamentally different routing mechanism\u2014e.g. coherent superposition of multiple routing paths, indefinite causal-order switching, or an adaptive, multi-stage network-coding primitive\u2014rather than a one-for-one swap of emitter technology.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! It uses only single\u2010photon emitters, a static interferometer, and heralding detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit.  \n   c) Discard (requires dynamic feedback/control).\n\n Step 3: Choose (b) \u201c4\u2010node quantum percolation switch.\u201d  \n\n Step 4: This idea is novel because no existing linear\u2010optical design offers a single static interferometer that, upon different heralded two\u2010click patterns, projects four quantum memories into entangled Bell\u2013links across any chosen pair (edges or diagonals), thereby enabling in one device the study of entanglement percolation and dynamic network connectivity.  \n\n Step 5: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus because it only demands:  \n   \u2022 Four single\u2010photon sources (one per Rydberg node \u2192 abstract photonic modes 0\u20133)  \n   \u2022 A single 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters & phase shifters)  \n   \u2022 Four number\u2010resolving detectors  \n   \u2022 Heralding on exactly two clicks projects the remaining two modes into a Bell pair.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201c4-Node Quantum Percolation Switch for Rydberg Arrays\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have four Rydberg\u2010atom memory nodes A, B, C, D. Each node emits one photon (modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter a single 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized). The outputs go to four photon-number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the remaining two unclicked output modes are projected into the Bell state |00>+|11> of the corresponding two memories. Different click-pairs activate different network links:\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangles C&D (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangles B&D (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangles A&C (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangles A&B (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangles B&C (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangles A&D (diagonal AD)  \n\nconfig (example for heralding clicks {0,1} \u2192 entangle C&D):\n{'description':'4-node percolation switch','foldername':'RydbergPercolation4','single_emitters':[0,1,2,3],'num_anc':0,'heralding_out':[0,1],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':40,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':20,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo generate the full percolation cell, one runs six optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair. The result is one static 4\u00d74 network whose various two-click patterns switch on any desired Bell\u2010link among the four Rydberg memories. This device is the building block for testing entanglement percolation, network coding, and dynamic rerouting in quantum repeater networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal duplicates the core idea of a fixed interferometer with heralded detector clicks selecting which two memories share a Bell pair. It fuses entanglement swapping with percolation/network-coding concepts.\n\n Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses only abstract photonic modes (one per Rydberg node), a single 4\u00d74 beam-splitter/phase-shifter network, and number-resolving detectors. Different \u201ctwo-click\u201d herald patterns project the remaining two modes onto a Bell pair, exactly what Pytheus can optimize.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201c4-Node Quantum Percolation Switch for Rydberg Arrays\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have four Rydberg\u2010atom quantum memories A, B, C, D. Each converts its memory excitation into one single photon (abstract modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter one static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the two unclicked output modes collapse into a Bell pair |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of memories. By post-selecting on different click-pairs, one \u201cactivates\u201d any of the six possible links in the square:\n\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D  (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangle B\u2013D  (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013C  (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013B  (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangle B\u2013C  (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangle A\u2013D  (diagonal AD)\n\nThis single device realizes all six entanglement-swapping channels in one static interferometer, enabling studies of entanglement percolation, network-coding primitives, and dynamic connectivity in a minimal four-node cell.\n\nexample config (for heralding {0,1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D):\n{\n  description:      '4-node percolation switch',\n  foldername:       'RydbergPercolation4',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],        // A,B,C,D emitters\n  num_anc:          0,\n  heralding_out:    [0,1],            // detectors Di,Dj that click\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],       // Bell basis on the remaining modes\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          20,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nOne runs six separate Pytheus optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair\u2014to recover a single 4\u00d74 network whose various two-click patterns select any desired Bell link. This constitutes a novel, expandable building block for quantum repeater networks and percolation studies, fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optics framework."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nHeralded Linear\u2010Optical 1\u21922 QuTrIt Telecloning via Resonance-Dip Multiport Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose and analyze a fully linear-optical implementation of the first 1\u21922 qutrit telecloner, in which three probabilistic qutrit-entangled photon-pair sources feed a balanced three-mode multiport Bell measurement module synchronized by identical delay-loop \u201cresonators.\u201d Success of the telecloning is unambiguously heralded by a generalized Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel resonance dip in triple-coincidence ancilla detections, conditionally projecting the two receivers into the optimal symmetric clones of the unknown input qutrit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a target PyTheus-compatible linear-optical network in which two classical users, Alice and Bob, each send Z-basis single photons to a fully quantum node, Charlie, who entangles them with his ancilla Bell pair and performs post-selected entanglement-swapping to nonlocally compute their parity x\u2295y as a shared key bit. This minimal experiment\u2014requiring only probabilistic photon-pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors without dynamic feed-forward\u2014demonstrates a novel nonlocal XOR primitive and provides a direct semi-quantum key agreement primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nEntanglement-Fano Interferometry via Three-Channel Heralded Swaps in a Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a discrete-vs-continuum Fano-resonance experiment between distant nodes A and C in which the two-photon Bell-state amplitude from a direct Bell-pair source coherently interferes with amplitudes generated by successive two-hop (via B) and three-hop (via D\u2192E) heralded entanglement swaps, with static polarization phase shifts \u03c6\u2082 and \u03c6\u2083 controlling the interference.  The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain.
