Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the target I suggest for Pytheus:\n\nDescription:\n Design a fixed linear\u2010optical \u201centanglement router\u201d that passively connects any two chosen nodes of a small Rydberg\u2010atom array network, purely by heralding on which ancilla detectors click.  Physically, each of the N array nodes (e.g. N=3 or 4 for demonstration) holds a Rydberg atomic qubit whose excitation can be converted into a single photon.  We assume that each node emits one photon entangled with its atomic memory (an abstract photonic mode).  All N photons enter a single N-port interferometer network, mix via beam splitters and phase shifters, and exit at output ports monitored by ancilla photon-number-resolving detectors.  Different click patterns at these ancilla detectors herald a Bell\u2010pair between exactly two of the memory qubits\u2014thereby routing entanglement on demand, without reconfiguring optics.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Generalizes entanglement swapping to a fully passive, reconfigurable router.  \n \u2022 Enables multiplexed, on-demand Bell\u2010links across any pair of atomic memory nodes.  \n \u2022 Lays groundwork for scalable quantum\u2010network switches and network\u2010coding primitives in Rydberg-based quantum repeaters or quantum internet nodes.\n\nKey Pytheus configuration elements (expert to flesh out):\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0,\u2026,N\u20131]  (one photon per memory node)  \n \u2022 a single multiport network (to be optimized) with N inputs \u2192 M outputs (M\u2265N)  \n \u2022 ancilla detectors on M\u20132 ports, leaving 2 \u201cmemory\u2010link\u201d output ports free  \n \u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct two-photon collisions between non-chosen node pairs if desired  \n \u2022 target_quantum: a set of Bell states on every 2-node subset; optimize so that each ancilla\u2010click pattern projects the remaining two output modes onto |00>+|11>  \n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the minimal multiport interferometer and detector arrangement that, upon heralding, routes entanglement between arbitrary node pairs\u2014an architecture-level quantum\u2010network primitive novel to the linear\u2010optical toolbox.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed static multiport interferometer that passively heralds entanglement between any two of N quantum\u2010memory nodes is essentially the same \u201cmultiplexed entanglement router\u201d primitive already in the ensemble (\u201cA Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\u201d). Both rely on N emitters feeding a fixed interferometer and ancilla\u2010click heralds to select which two nodes share a Bell pair, differing only in physical platform (Rydberg vs. plasmonic waveguides). Because the core routing mechanism and target transformation are identical, this idea lacks sufficient novelty over existing suggestions.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router\u201d proposal. To be novel, you would need a fundamentally new routing mechanism (e.g. non-heralded, multi-stage network coding, coherent superposition of multiple routes, or indefinite causal order) rather than just changing the emitter technology.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cRydberg Entanglement Router (3-node)\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have a small Rydberg\u2010atom array of three memory nodes A, B, C. Each node coherently converts its atomic excitation into one photon (abstract mode 0,1,2). These three photons enter a single 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus). The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Whenever exactly one detector Di clicks, the remaining two (unclicked) output modes are projected into a two-qubit Bell state |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of Rydberg memories. Thus:\n \u2022 D0 click \u2192 entangles B&C  \n \u2022 D1 click \u2192 entangles A&C  \n \u2022 D2 click \u2192 entangles A&B  \n\nThis is a passive, heralded entanglement router: by post-selecting on which detector fires, we choose which pair of memories becomes entangled, without reconfiguring the optics.\n\nconfig (example for heralding D2 \u2192 entangle A&B):\n{'description':'Passive 3-node entanglement router for Rydberg memories','foldername':'RydbergRouter3','single_emitters':[0,1,2],'num_anc':1,'heralding_out':[2],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'in_nodes':[],'out_nodes':[],'anc_detectors':[],'removed_connections':[],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':30,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':10,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo cover all three routing patterns, one simply repeats the optimization with heralding_out=[0] and heralding_out=[1]: each run yields the same static interferometer but different herald-detector assignment projects onto the desired Bell link. This architecture scales to N nodes via an N\u00d7N multiport and N single-photon sources.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed 3-node \u201cRydberg Entanglement Router\u201d implements exactly the same passive, heralded routing primitive as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides,\u201d merely swapping in Rydberg emitters. Because the core transformation (N emitters \u2192 static N\u00d7N interferometer \u2192 heralded two-node Bell pair) and network-switch functionality are identical, this offers no new conceptual twist beyond what\u2019s already in the literature.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This target is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router\u201d proposal. To achieve genuine novelty, you\u2019d need a fundamentally different routing mechanism\u2014e.g. coherent superposition of multiple routing paths, indefinite causal-order switching, or an adaptive, multi-stage network-coding primitive\u2014rather than a one-for-one swap of emitter technology.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201c4-Node Quantum Percolation Switch for Rydberg Arrays\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have four Rydberg\u2010atom memory nodes A, B, C, D. Each node emits one photon (modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter a single 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized). The outputs go to four photon-number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the remaining two unclicked output modes are projected into the Bell state |00>+|11> of the corresponding two memories. Different click-pairs activate different network links:\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangles C&D (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangles B&D (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangles A&C (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangles A&B (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangles B&C (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangles A&D (diagonal AD)  \n\nconfig (example for heralding clicks {0,1} \u2192 entangle C&D):\n{'description':'4-node percolation switch','foldername':'RydbergPercolation4','single_emitters':[0,1,2,3],'num_anc':0,'heralding_out':[0,1],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':40,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':20,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo generate the full percolation cell, one runs six optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair. The result is one static 4\u00d74 network whose various two-click patterns switch on any desired Bell\u2010link among the four Rydberg memories. This device is the building block for testing entanglement percolation, network coding, and dynamic rerouting in quantum repeater networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The 4\u2010node \u201cpercolation switch\u201d is essentially the same passive, heralded entanglement\u2010routing primitive already proposed in the ensemble (\u201cQuantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\u201d and related entanglement\u2010percolation schemes). Merely extending from N=3 to N=4 and using two\u2010click patterns to select one of six edges does not introduce a fundamentally new routing mechanism or network capability. coding primitive\u2014rather than a straightforward N\u21924 scaling of the same router concept.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the new target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cButterfly unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9_A, |\u03d5\u27e9_B to be teleported.  \n\u2022 Two entangled photonic Bell\u2010pair sources originate at a central station Z: one pair entangles Z\u21c4C, the other entangles Z\u21c4D.  \n\u2022 Each of the six photonic modes (A_emit, B_emit, Z_C_emit (two modes), Z_D_emit (two modes)) enters a single static 6\u00d76 linear\u2010optical interferometer (beam splitters & phase shifters).  \n\u2022 The interferometer\u2019s six outputs go to six number\u2010resolving detectors: four \u201cBell\u2010measurement\u201d detectors at Z and two \u201creceiver\u201d detectors at C and D.  \n\u2022 Upon one of several distinct four\u2010click patterns on the Z detectors, the unknown qubit from A emerges at D and from B emerges at C\u2014i.e. A\u2192D and B\u2192C simultaneously\u2014thereby realizing the quantum butterfly network code in one device.\n\nKey configuration elements:\n{'description':'Butterfly network\u2010coded teleportation','foldername':'RYD_butterfly_tele','single_emitters':[0,1],'amplitudes':[],'heralding_pairs':[ [Z_det_indices click pattern set 1], [set 2], \u2026 ],'target_mapping':{\n   // For each computational basis |i\u27e9_A \u2297 |j\u27e9_B, the click pattern k maps the input to outputs at C,D in swapped order:\n   '00\u219200','01\u219210','10\u219201','11\u219211'\n},'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','edges_tried':50,'tries_per_edge':10,'samples':30,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Introduces the first linear\u2010optical quantum network coding primitive\u2014simultaneous cross\u2010teleportation (butterfly) in one static module.  \n \u2022 Directly leverages Rydberg\u2010based memory nodes as tele\u2010ports\u2019 endpoints, demonstrating how atomic arrays can feed into complex network transforms.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to larger codes: can scale to multi\u2010source, multi\u2010receiver networks by extending the interferometer size and defining more heralding patterns.  \n\nThis target asks Pytheus to optimize a single static interferometer that, via heralded Bell measurements, implements two crossed teleportation channels in strict analogy to the classical butterfly code\u2014opening a new avenue for quantum\u2010network coding experiments.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross\u2010Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\u201d)\u2014it merely swaps out SiV emitters for Rydberg atoms and ups the port count. A different heralding pattern implements the alternate routing (A\u2192C, B\u2192D).\n\nconfig example (for heralding pattern routing A\u2192D, B\u2192C):\n{\n  description:      'Butterfly map for computational basis\n    '00'-> output at (D,C) = '00',\n    '01'->                  '10',\n    '10'->                  '01',\n    '11'->                  '11'\n  },\n  optimizer: Each converts its memory excitation into one single photon (abstract modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter one static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the two unclicked output modes collapse into a Bell pair |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of memories. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"rydberg atom array\" and \"entangled quantum state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. We assume that each node emits one photon entangled with its atomic memory (an abstract photonic mode).  All N photons enter a single N-port interferometer network, mix via beam splitters and phase shifters, and exit at output ports monitored by ancilla photon-number-resolving detectors. Each node coherently converts its atomic excitation into one photon (abstract mode 0,1,2). These three photons enter a single 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus). The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Whenever exactly one detector Di clicks, the remaining two (unclicked) output modes are projected into a two-qubit Bell state |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of Rydberg memories. interferometer that, via heralded Bell measurements, implements two crossed teleportation channels in strict analogy to the classical butterfly code\u2014opening a new avenue for quantum\u2010network coding experiments.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the ensemble\u2019s butterfly network coding primitive. To be novel, you\u2019d need a qualitatively new element\u2014e.g. higher-dimensional network coding, coherent superposition of multiple code paths, indefinite causal order in the butterfly code, or an adaptive multi-stage coding architecture\u2014rather than a straightforward platform swap.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm 3 Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to link \u201cRydberg atom array\u201d + \u201centangled quantum state\u201d in a quantum\u2010network primitive (no raw state generation):\n    1) A 3\u2010node entanglement router that passively heralds any pair\u2010link among A, B, C via one static interferometer.  \n    2) A 4\u2010node \u201cquantum percolation switch\u201d where two\u2010click heralds in a static 4\u00d74 network activate any edge or diagonal link on a square of Rydberg memories.  \n    3) A \u201cbutterfly network\u2010coded teleportation\u201d device: two senders A,B teleport simultaneously to two receivers C,D via one static linear\u2010optical module, implementing the quantum analogue of the classical butterfly code in one shot.\n\n  Step 2: Assess novelty & Pytheus fit:\n    1) Similar to prior \u201centanglement router\u201d proposals.  \n    2) Essentially scales that same idea\u2014flagged as too close.  \n    3) Butterfly network coding is not in the list of explored experiments. convert into single photons (modes 0,1).  \n\u2022 A central station Z generates two photonic Bell pairs: modes 2\u20133 entangle Z\u21c4C, modes 4\u20135 entangle Z\u21c4D.  \n\u2022 All six photons \u201cBell-measurement\u201d detectors at Z (indices d0\u2013d3) and two \u201creceiver\u201d detectors at C (d4) and D (d5).  \n\u2022 Upon one of two distinct four-click patterns at {d0,d1,d2,d3}, the unknown qubit from A emerges at D and from B emerges at C, implementing simultaneous crossed teleportation (A\u2192D, B\u2192C). A different heralding pattern implements the alternate routing (A\u2192C, B\u2192D).\n\nconfig example (for heralding pattern routing A\u2192D, B\u2192C):\n{\n  description:      'Butterfly network-coded teleportation',\n  foldername:       'ryd_butterfly_tele',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1],          // A,B unknown-state emitters\n  amplitudes:       [],             // two Bell pairs at Z are implicit pair sources\n  in_nodes:         [],\n  out_nodes:        [],\n  heralding_out:    [d0,d1,d2,d3],  // specific four-click set at Z\n  target_mapping: {                   // teleportation map for computational basis\n    '00'-> output at (D,C) = '00',\n    '01'->                  '10',\n    '10'->                  '01',\n    '11'->                  '11'\n  },\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      50,\n  tries_per_edge:   10,\n  samples:          30,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 First linear-optical implementation of the quantum butterfly network code, a true network-coding primitive.  \n \u2022 Ties Rydberg atomic memories to advanced teleportation routing without dynamic control.  \n \u2022 Scales to larger network codes by extending the interferometer and heralding patterns.\n\nThis task asks Pytheus to discover the minimal static interferometer & detection scheme that, via heralded post-selection, performs two crossed teleportations in one device\u2014opening a new frontier in quantum network coding.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s butterfly cross\u2010teleportation target. It fuses entanglement swapping with percolation/network-coding concepts.\n\n Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses only abstract photonic modes (one per Rydberg node), a single 4\u00d74 beam-splitter/phase-shifter network, and number-resolving detectors. Different \u201ctwo-click\u201d herald patterns project the remaining two modes onto a Bell pair, exactly what Pytheus can optimize.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201c4-Node Quantum Percolation Switch for Rydberg Arrays\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have four Rydberg\u2010atom quantum memories A, B, C, D. Each converts its memory excitation into one single photon (abstract modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter one static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the two unclicked output modes collapse into a Bell pair |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of memories. By post-selecting on different click-pairs, one \u201cactivates\u201d any of the six possible links in the square:\n\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D  (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangle B\u2013D  (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013C  (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013B  (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangle B\u2013C  (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangle A\u2013D  (diagonal AD)\n\nThis single device realizes all six entanglement-swapping channels in one static interferometer, enabling studies of entanglement percolation, network-coding primitives, and dynamic connectivity in a minimal four-node cell.\n\nexample config (for heralding {0,1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D):\n{\n  description:      '4-node percolation switch',\n  foldername:       'RydbergPercolation4',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],        // A,B,C,D emitters\n  num_anc:          0,\n  heralding_out:    [0,1],            // detectors Di,Dj that click\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],       // Bell basis on the remaining modes\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          20,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nOne runs six separate Pytheus optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair\u2014to recover a single 4\u00d74 network whose various two-click patterns select any desired Bell link. This constitutes a novel, expandable building block for quantum repeater networks and percolation studies, fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optics framework.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the core idea of a fixed interferometer with heralded detector clicks selecting one of several Bell links (as in the ensemble\u2019s entanglement router and percolation schemes).     "output": "Thought:\n  I need a novel quantum-network primitive combining a Rydberg atom array and entangled quantum states, implementable by Pytheus (static linear optics, single-photon sources, heralding) and not just iterative scaling of prior router/swapping modules. Entanglement purification has not been explored in the provided list, and it\u2019s a fundamental two-node network transformation (distillation) that can be generalized to repeater chains. It uses only abstract photonic modes, linear optics, and heralding detectors\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities and avoids forbidden state\u2010generation proposals.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cEntanglement Purification Module for Rydberg-Atom Memories\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe consider two distant Rydberg-atom memory nodes A and B that share two imperfect photonic Bell pairs of fidelity <1. Each node converts its two local memories into photons: A produces modes 0,1 (imperfect pair a\u2081\u2013b\u2081), and B produces modes 2,3 (imperfect pair a\u2082\u2013b\u2082). All four photons enter a single static 4\u00d74 linear-optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus). The four outputs go to four number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Upon obtaining clicks on detectors {D2,D3} (the \u201cancilla\u201d measurement), the unmeasured output modes (D0,D1) collapse into a purified high-fidelity Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between the two Rydberg memories at A and B. This implements one round of the BBPSSW entanglement-distillation protocol in a single passive module\u2014no dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, only static linear optics and heralding. By cascading or interconnecting multiple such modules, one can build multi-stage purification chains for long-distance quantum repeater networks.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3} \u2192 purified A\u2013B Bell pair):\n{\n  description:      'Entanglement purification for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydPurification2',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],       // modes from A:a1,a2 and B:b1,b2\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],           // detectors D2,D3 clicks herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],      // purified Bell basis on modes 0,1\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      30,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Introduces the first static, heralded entanglement-distillation primitive for Rydberg-atom quantum memories in a single module.  \n \u2022 Moves beyond point-to-point swapping: it cleans noisy links, a vital network primitive toward scalable repeaters.  \n \u2022 Fully generalizable to multi-stage purification chains and to higher dimensions by extending the network size and detection patterns.\n\nThis target leverages Pytheus\u2019s strength\u2014optimizing static linear-optical networks with single-photon sources and heralding detectors\u2014to discover minimal purification circuits, forging a new building block for quantum-network protocols."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nHeralded Linear\u2010Optical 1\u21922 QuTrIt Telecloning via Resonance-Dip Multiport Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose and analyze a fully linear-optical implementation of the first 1\u21922 qutrit telecloner, in which three probabilistic qutrit-entangled photon-pair sources feed a balanced three-mode multiport Bell measurement module synchronized by identical delay-loop \u201cresonators.\u201d Success of the telecloning is unambiguously heralded by a generalized Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel resonance dip in triple-coincidence ancilla detections, conditionally projecting the two receivers into the optimal symmetric clones of the unknown input qutrit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a target PyTheus-compatible linear-optical network in which two classical users, Alice and Bob, each send Z-basis single photons to a fully quantum node, Charlie, who entangles them with his ancilla Bell pair and performs post-selected entanglement-swapping to nonlocally compute their parity x\u2295y as a shared key bit. This minimal experiment\u2014requiring only probabilistic photon-pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors without dynamic feed-forward\u2014demonstrates a novel nonlocal XOR primitive and provides a direct semi-quantum key agreement primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nEntanglement-Fano Interferometry via Three-Channel Heralded Swaps in a Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a discrete-vs-continuum Fano-resonance experiment between distant nodes A and C in which the two-photon Bell-state amplitude from a direct Bell-pair source coherently interferes with amplitudes generated by successive two-hop (via B) and three-hop (via D\u2192E) heralded entanglement swaps, with static polarization phase shifts \u03c6\u2082 and \u03c6\u2083 controlling the interference.  The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. In the current experiment, the explicit target is to herald each of the four Bell-state outcomes using two ancilla photons and ten number-resolving detectors\u2014realizing, for the first time, a high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer to enable ququart teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the target I suggest for Pytheus:\n\nDescription:\n Design a fixed linear\u2010optical \u201centanglement router\u201d that passively connects any two chosen nodes of a small Rydberg\u2010atom array network, purely by heralding on which ancilla detectors click.  Physically, each of the N array nodes (e.g. N=3 or 4 for demonstration) holds a Rydberg atomic qubit whose excitation can be converted into a single photon.  We assume that each node emits one photon entangled with its atomic memory (an abstract photonic mode).  All N photons enter a single N-port interferometer network, mix via beam splitters and phase shifters, and exit at output ports monitored by ancilla photon-number-resolving detectors.  Different click patterns at these ancilla detectors herald a Bell\u2010pair between exactly two of the memory qubits\u2014thereby routing entanglement on demand, without reconfiguring optics.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Generalizes entanglement swapping to a fully passive, reconfigurable router.  \n \u2022 Enables multiplexed, on-demand Bell\u2010links across any pair of atomic memory nodes.  \n \u2022 Lays groundwork for scalable quantum\u2010network switches and network\u2010coding primitives in Rydberg-based quantum repeaters or quantum internet nodes.\n\nKey Pytheus configuration elements (expert to flesh out):\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0,\u2026,N\u20131]  (one photon per memory node)  \n \u2022 a single multiport network (to be optimized) with N inputs \u2192 M outputs (M\u2265N)  \n \u2022 ancilla detectors on M\u20132 ports, leaving 2 \u201cmemory\u2010link\u201d output ports free  \n \u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct two-photon collisions between non-chosen node pairs if desired  \n \u2022 target_quantum: a set of Bell states on every 2-node subset; optimize so that each ancilla\u2010click pattern projects the remaining two output modes onto |00>+|11>  \n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the minimal multiport interferometer and detector arrangement that, upon heralding, routes entanglement between arbitrary node pairs\u2014an architecture-level quantum\u2010network primitive novel to the linear\u2010optical toolbox.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed static multiport interferometer that passively heralds entanglement between any two of N quantum\u2010memory nodes is essentially the same \u201cmultiplexed entanglement router\u201d primitive already in the ensemble (\u201cA Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\u201d). Both rely on N emitters feeding a fixed interferometer and ancilla\u2010click heralds to select which two nodes share a Bell pair, differing only in physical platform (Rydberg vs. plasmonic waveguides). Because the core routing mechanism and target transformation are identical, this idea lacks sufficient novelty over existing suggestions.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router\u201d proposal. To be novel, you would need a fundamentally new routing mechanism (e.g. non-heralded, multi-stage network coding, coherent superposition of multiple routes, or indefinite causal order) rather than just changing the emitter technology.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cRydberg Entanglement Router (3-node)\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have a small Rydberg\u2010atom array of three memory nodes A, B, C. Each node coherently converts its atomic excitation into one photon (abstract mode 0,1,2). These three photons enter a single 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus). The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Whenever exactly one detector Di clicks, the remaining two (unclicked) output modes are projected into a two-qubit Bell state |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of Rydberg memories. Thus:\n \u2022 D0 click \u2192 entangles B&C  \n \u2022 D1 click \u2192 entangles A&C  \n \u2022 D2 click \u2192 entangles A&B  \n\nThis is a passive, heralded entanglement router: by post-selecting on which detector fires, we choose which pair of memories becomes entangled, without reconfiguring the optics.\n\nconfig (example for heralding D2 \u2192 entangle A&B):\n{'description':'Passive 3-node entanglement router for Rydberg memories','foldername':'RydbergRouter3','single_emitters':[0,1,2],'num_anc':1,'heralding_out':[2],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'in_nodes':[],'out_nodes':[],'anc_detectors':[],'removed_connections':[],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':30,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':10,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo cover all three routing patterns, one simply repeats the optimization with heralding_out=[0] and heralding_out=[1]: each run yields the same static interferometer but different herald-detector assignment projects onto the desired Bell link. This architecture scales to N nodes via an N\u00d7N multiport and N single-photon sources.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed 3-node \u201cRydberg Entanglement Router\u201d implements exactly the same passive, heralded routing primitive as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides,\u201d merely swapping in Rydberg emitters. Each converts its memory excitation into one single photon (abstract modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter one static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the two unclicked output modes collapse into a Bell pair |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of memories. By post-selecting on different click-pairs, one \u201cactivates\u201d any of the six possible links in the square:\n\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D  (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangle B\u2013D  (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013C  (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013B  (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangle B\u2013C  (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangle A\u2013D  (diagonal AD)\n\nThis single device realizes all six entanglement-swapping channels in one static interferometer, enabling studies of entanglement percolation, network-coding primitives, and dynamic connectivity in a minimal four-node cell.\n\nexample config (for heralding {0,1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D):\n{\n  description:      '4-node percolation switch',\n  foldername:       'RydbergPercolation4',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],        // A,B,C,D emitters\n  num_anc:          0,\n  heralding_out:    [0,1],            // detectors Di,Dj that click\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],       // Bell basis on the remaining modes\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          20,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nOne runs six separate Pytheus optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair\u2014to recover a single 4\u00d74 network whose various two-click patterns select any desired Bell link. This constitutes a novel, expandable building block for quantum repeater networks and percolation studies, fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optics framework.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The 4-node \u201cpercolation switch\u201d is effectively the same static interferometer plus heralded\u2010click routing primitive for selecting which two memories share a Bell pair that already appears in the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router\u201d and related percolation proposals. Merely extending to N=4 Rydberg nodes and labeling click\u2010pairs does not introduce a genuinely new mechanism or target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This duplicates the core idea of a fixed interferometer with heralded detector clicks selecting one of several Bell links (as in the ensemble\u2019s entanglement router and percolation schemes). To be novel, you need a fundamentally different element\u2014e.g. coherent superposition of multiple link activations, indefinite causal\u2010order percolation, or an adaptive multi\u2010stage network coding primitive\u2014rather than a straightforward platform and node\u2010count swap.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cEntanglement Purification Module for Rydberg-Atom Memories\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe consider two distant Rydberg-atom memory nodes A and B that share two imperfect photonic Bell pairs of fidelity <1. Each node converts its two local memories into photons: A produces modes 0,1 (imperfect pair a\u2081\u2013b\u2081), and B produces modes 2,3 (imperfect pair a\u2082\u2013b\u2082). All four photons enter a single static 4\u00d74 linear-optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus). The four outputs go to four number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Upon obtaining clicks on detectors {D2,D3} (the \u201cancilla\u201d measurement), the unmeasured output modes (D0,D1) collapse into a purified high-fidelity Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between the two Rydberg memories at A and B. This implements one round of the BBPSSW entanglement-distillation protocol in a single passive module\u2014no dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, only static linear optics and heralding. By cascading or interconnecting multiple such modules, one can build multi-stage purification chains for long-distance quantum repeater networks.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3} \u2192 purified A\u2013B Bell pair):\n{\n  description:      'Entanglement purification for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydPurification2',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],       // modes from A:a1,a2 and B:b1,b2\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],           // detectors D2,D3 clicks herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],      // purified Bell basis on modes 0,1\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      30,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Introduces the first static, heralded entanglement-distillation primitive for Rydberg-atom quantum memories in a single module.  \n \u2022 Moves beyond point-to-point swapping: it cleans noisy links, a vital network primitive toward scalable repeaters.  \n \u2022 Fully generalizable to multi-stage purification chains and to higher dimensions by extending the network size and detection patterns.\n\nThis target leverages Pytheus\u2019s strength\u2014optimizing static linear-optical networks with single-photon sources and heralding detectors\u2014to discover minimal purification circuits, forging a new building block for quantum-network protocols.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposed \u201cEntanglement Purification Module\u201d is essentially the same one\u2010shot, static linear\u2010optical distillation primitive already in the ensemble (the \u201cOne-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u3009+|11\u3009 Bell Pairs\u201d), which mixes two imperfect pairs in a 4\u00d74 network and post-selects on detector clicks to output a purified Bell link. Swapping in Rydberg memories does not introduce a new transformation or mechanism.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This duplicates the ensemble\u2019s one\u2010shot swap-and-concentrate repeater. To be novel, you must propose a fundamentally different purification mechanism (e.g. multi\u2010round adaptive purification, higher-dimensional distillation, or coherence-assisted protocols beyond simple post-selection) rather than a direct platform swap of the same static linear-optical module."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. Physically, each of the N array nodes (e.g. N=3 or 4 for demonstration) holds a Rydberg atomic qubit whose excitation can be converted into a single photon.  We assume that each node emits one photon entangled with its atomic memory (an abstract photonic mode).  All N photons enter a single N-port interferometer network, mix via beam splitters and phase shifters, and exit at output ports monitored by ancilla photon-number-resolving detectors.  Different click patterns at these ancilla detectors herald a Bell\u2010pair between exactly two of the memory qubits\u2014thereby routing entanglement on demand, without reconfiguring optics.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Generalizes entanglement swapping to a fully passive, reconfigurable router.  \n \u2022 Enables multiplexed, on-demand Bell\u2010links across any pair of atomic memory nodes.  \n \u2022 Lays groundwork for scalable quantum\u2010network switches and network\u2010coding primitives in Rydberg-based quantum repeaters or quantum internet nodes.\n\nKey Pytheus configuration elements (expert to flesh out):\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0,\u2026,N\u20131]  (one photon per memory node)  \n \u2022 a single multiport network (to be optimized) with N inputs \u2192 M outputs (M\u2265N)  \n \u2022 ancilla detectors on M\u20132 ports, leaving 2 \u201cmemory\u2010link\u201d output ports free  \n \u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct two-photon collisions between non-chosen node pairs if desired  \n \u2022 target_quantum: a set of Bell states on every 2-node subset; optimize so that each ancilla\u2010click pattern projects the remaining two output modes onto |00>+|11>  \n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the minimal multiport interferometer and detector arrangement that, upon heralding, routes entanglement between arbitrary node pairs\u2014an architecture-level quantum\u2010network primitive novel to the linear\u2010optical toolbox.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router\u201d proposal. Each node coherently converts its atomic excitation into one photon (abstract mode 0,1,2). These three photons enter a single 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus). The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Whenever exactly one detector Di clicks, the remaining two (unclicked) output modes are projected into a two-qubit Bell state |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of Rydberg memories. Thus:\n \u2022 D0 click \u2192 entangles B&C  \n \u2022 D1 click \u2192 entangles A&C  \n \u2022 D2 click \u2192 entangles A&B  \n\nThis is a passive, heralded entanglement router: by post-selecting on which detector fires, we choose which pair of memories becomes entangled, without reconfiguring the optics.\n\nconfig (example for heralding D2 \u2192 entangle A&B):\n{'description':'Passive 3-node entanglement router for Rydberg memories','foldername':'RydbergRouter3','single_emitters':[0,1,2],'num_anc':1,'heralding_out':[2],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'in_nodes':[],'out_nodes':[],'anc_detectors':[],'removed_connections':[],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':30,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':10,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo cover all three routing patterns, one simply repeats the optimization with heralding_out=[0] and heralding_out=[1]: each run yields the same static interferometer but different herald-detector assignment projects onto the desired Bell link. the unknown qubit from A emerges at D and from B emerges at C, implementing simultaneous crossed teleportation (A\u2192D, B\u2192C). Each converts its memory excitation into one single photon (abstract modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter one static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the two unclicked output modes collapse into a Bell pair |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of memories. By post-selecting on different click-pairs, one \u201cactivates\u201d any of the six possible links in the square:\n\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D  (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangle B\u2013D  (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013C  (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013B  (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangle B\u2013C  (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangle A\u2013D  (diagonal AD)\n\nThis single device realizes all six entanglement-swapping channels in one static interferometer, enabling studies of entanglement percolation, network-coding primitives, and dynamic connectivity in a minimal four-node cell.\n\nexample config (for heralding {0,1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D):\n{\n  description:      '4-node percolation switch',\n  foldername:       'RydbergPercolation4',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],        // A,B,C,D emitters\n  num_anc:          0,\n  heralding_out:    [0,1],            // detectors Di,Dj that click\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],       // Bell basis on the remaining modes\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          20,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nOne runs six separate Pytheus optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair\u2014to recover a single 4\u00d74 network whose various two-click patterns select any desired Bell link. Each node converts its two local memories into photons: A produces modes 0,1 (imperfect pair a\u2081\u2013b\u2081), and B produces modes 2,3 (imperfect pair a\u2082\u2013b\u2082). All four photons enter a single static 4\u00d74 linear-optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus). The four outputs go to four number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Upon obtaining clicks on detectors {D2,D3} (the \u201cancilla\u201d measurement), the unmeasured output modes (D0,D1) collapse into a purified high-fidelity Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between the two Rydberg memories at A and B. This implements one round of the BBPSSW entanglement-distillation protocol in a single passive module\u2014no dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, only static linear optics and heralding. By cascading or interconnecting multiple such modules, one can build multi-stage purification chains for long-distance quantum repeater networks.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3} \u2192 purified A\u2013B Bell pair):\n{\n  description:      'Entanglement purification for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydPurification2',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],       // modes from A:a1,a2 and B:b1,b2\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],           // detectors D2,D3 clicks herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],      // purified Bell basis on modes 0,1\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      30,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Introduces the first static, heralded entanglement-distillation primitive for Rydberg-atom quantum memories in a single module.  \n \u2022 Moves beyond point-to-point swapping: it cleans noisy links, a vital network primitive toward scalable repeaters.  \n \u2022 Fully generalizable to multi-stage purification chains and to higher dimensions by extending the network size and detection patterns.\n\nThis target leverages Pytheus\u2019s strength\u2014optimizing static linear-optical networks with single-photon sources and heralding detectors\u2014to discover minimal purification circuits, forging a new building block for quantum-network protocols.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the ensemble\u2019s one\u2010shot swap-and-concentrate repeater.     "output": "Thought:\nI need a genuinely new network\u2010operation primitive\u2014no simple swapping or routing\u2014for Rydberg\u2010memory nodes implementable in Pytheus\u2019s static linear\u2010optics framework. A heralded nonlocal parity measurement on two distant quantum memories is a fundamental transformation (a joint Z\u2297Z check) that\u2019s been little explored in photonic networks, yet is crucial for error syndrome extraction in distributed quantum computing and entanglement purification. Pytheus can optimize a static interferometer with three single\u2010photon inputs and number\u2010resolving detectors to realize the two\u2010outcome parity measurement nonlocally. This meets all constraints and offers a new elementary network primitive that generalizes to multi\u2010node stabilizer checks.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cHeralded Nonlocal Parity Measurement for Rydberg Memories\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have two distant Rydberg\u2010atom quantum memories A and B. Each memory\u2019s qubit is converted into one photon (abstract modes 0 and 1) that carries its Z\u2010basis information. We also introduce one ancillary single\u2010photon emitter (mode 2) to mediate the joint measurement. All three photons enter a single static 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The three output modes are monitored by number\u2010resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Depending on which detector clicks (exactly one click), the two Rydberg memories collapse into one of the two Z\u2297Z parity subspaces:\n\n \u2022 If Di clicks with i\u2208{0,1}, the memories are projected onto the even\u2010parity Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 (heralded by detector patterns {0} or {1}).  \n \u2022 If D2 clicks, the memories are projected onto the odd\u2010parity Bell state |01\u27e9+|10\u27e9 (heralded by {2}).\n\nThis realizes a non\u2010destructive, heralded remote Z\u2297Z parity check between two atomic qubits in one static module\u2014an essential building block for distributed error syndrome extraction and measurement\u2010based network protocols.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding Di\u2192even or odd parity):\n{\n  description:      'Heralded parity measurement for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydParityMeas',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],         // modes from A, B, and ancilla\n  heralding_out:    [i],             // i=0 or 1 \u2192 even parity; i=2 \u2192 odd parity\n  target_quantum:   (i<2 ? ['00','11'] : ['01','10']),\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      20,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 A joint nonlocal parity measurement is a key network transform\u2014beyond swapping or teleportation\u2014that underpins entanglement purification, error syndrome extraction, and measurement\u2010based repeater protocols.  \n \u2022 We deploy only static linear optics, three single\u2010photon emitters, and heralding detectors\u2014perfectly within Pytheus\u2019s remit.  \n \u2022 The concept generalizes immediately to N\u2010qubit stabilizer checks (e.g. 4\u2010mode network for X\u2297X\u2297Z\u2297Z) by adding ancilla emitters and detectors.  \n \u2022 This primitive opens new avenues for distributed quantum error correction and measurement\u2010based quantum networking with Rydberg\u2010memory nodes."

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nHeralded Linear\u2010Optical 1\u21922 QuTrIt Telecloning via Resonance-Dip Multiport Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose and analyze a fully linear-optical implementation of the first 1\u21922 qutrit telecloner, in which three probabilistic qutrit-entangled photon-pair sources feed a balanced three-mode multiport Bell measurement module synchronized by identical delay-loop \u201cresonators.\u201d Success of the telecloning is unambiguously heralded by a generalized Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel resonance dip in triple-coincidence ancilla detections, conditionally projecting the two receivers into the optimal symmetric clones of the unknown input qutrit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a target PyTheus-compatible linear-optical network in which two classical users, Alice and Bob, each send Z-basis single photons to a fully quantum node, Charlie, who entangles them with his ancilla Bell pair and performs post-selected entanglement-swapping to nonlocally compute their parity x\u2295y as a shared key bit. This minimal experiment\u2014requiring only probabilistic photon-pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors without dynamic feed-forward\u2014demonstrates a novel nonlocal XOR primitive and provides a direct semi-quantum key agreement primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nEntanglement-Fano Interferometry via Three-Channel Heralded Swaps in a Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a discrete-vs-continuum Fano-resonance experiment between distant nodes A and C in which the two-photon Bell-state amplitude from a direct Bell-pair source coherently interferes with amplitudes generated by successive two-hop (via B) and three-hop (via D\u2192E) heralded entanglement swaps, with static polarization phase shifts \u03c6\u2082 and \u03c6\u2083 controlling the interference.  The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins.
