In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"rydberg atom array\" and \"entangled quantum state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Each node coherently converts its atomic excitation into one photon (abstract mode 0,1,2). These three photons enter a single 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus). The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Each node emits one photon (modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter a single 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized). The outputs go to four photon-number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the remaining two unclicked output modes are projected into the Bell state |00>+|11> of the corresponding two memories. Different click-pairs activate different network links:\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangles C&D (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangles B&D (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangles A&C (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangles A&B (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangles B&C (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangles A&D (diagonal AD)  \n\nconfig (example for heralding clicks {0,1} \u2192 entangle C&D):\n{'description':'4-node percolation switch','foldername':'RydbergPercolation4','single_emitters':[0,1,2,3],'num_anc':0,'heralding_out':[0,1],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':40,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':20,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo generate the full percolation cell, one runs six optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair. The result is one static 4\u00d74 network whose various two-click patterns switch on any desired Bell\u2010link among the four Rydberg memories. This device is the building block for testing entanglement percolation, network coding, and dynamic rerouting in quantum repeater networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal duplicates the core idea of a fixed interferometer with heralded detector clicks selecting which two memories share a Bell pair. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the two unclicked output modes collapse into a Bell pair |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of memories. Each node converts its two local memories into photons: A produces modes 0,1 (imperfect pair a\u2081\u2013b\u2081), and B produces modes 2,3 (imperfect pair a\u2082\u2013b\u2082). All four photons enter a single static 4\u00d74 linear-optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus). The four outputs go to four number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Upon obtaining clicks on detectors {D2,D3} (the \u201cancilla\u201d measurement), the unmeasured output modes (D0,D1) collapse into a purified high-fidelity Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between the two Rydberg memories at A and B. This implements one round of the BBPSSW entanglement-distillation protocol in a single passive module\u2014no dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, only static linear optics and heralding. By cascading or interconnecting multiple such modules, one can build multi-stage purification chains for long-distance quantum repeater networks.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3} \u2192 purified A\u2013B Bell pair):\n{\n  description:      'Entanglement purification for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydPurification2',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],       // modes from A:a1,a2 and B:b1,b2\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],           // detectors D2,D3 clicks herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],      // purified Bell basis on modes 0,1\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      30,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Introduces the first static, heralded entanglement-distillation primitive for Rydberg-atom quantum memories in a single module.  \n \u2022 Moves beyond point-to-point swapping: it cleans noisy links, a vital network primitive toward scalable repeaters.  \n \u2022 Fully generalizable to multi-stage purification chains and to higher dimensions by extending the network size and detection patterns.\n\nThis target leverages Pytheus\u2019s strength\u2014optimizing static linear-optical networks with single-photon sources and heralding detectors\u2014to discover minimal purification circuits, forging a new building block for quantum-network protocols.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the ensemble\u2019s one\u2010shot swap-and-concentrate repeater. All three photons enter a single static 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The three output modes are monitored by number\u2010resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Depending on which detector clicks (exactly one click), the two Rydberg memories collapse into one of the two Z\u2297Z parity subspaces:\n\n \u2022 If Di clicks with i\u2208{0,1}, the memories are projected onto the even\u2010parity Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 (heralded by detector patterns {0} or {1}).  \n \u2022 If D2 clicks, the memories are projected onto the odd\u2010parity Bell state |01\u27e9+|10\u27e9 (heralded by {2}).\n\nThis realizes a non\u2010destructive, heralded remote Z\u2297Z parity check between two atomic qubits in one static module\u2014an essential building block for distributed error syndrome extraction and measurement\u2010based network protocols.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding Di\u2192even or odd parity):\n{\n  description:      'Heralded parity measurement for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydParityMeas',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],         // modes from A, B, and ancilla\n  heralding_out:    [i],             // i=0 or 1 \u2192 even parity; i=2 \u2192 odd parity\n  target_quantum:   (i<2 ? ['00','11'] : ['01','10']),\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      20,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 A joint nonlocal parity measurement is a key network transform\u2014beyond swapping or teleportation\u2014that underpins entanglement purification, error syndrome extraction, and measurement\u2010based repeater protocols.  \n \u2022 We deploy only static linear optics, three single\u2010photon emitters, and heralding detectors\u2014perfectly within Pytheus\u2019s remit.  \n \u2022 The concept generalizes immediately to N\u2010qubit stabilizer checks (e.g. 4\u2010mode network for X\u2297X\u2297Z\u2297Z) by adding ancilla emitters and detectors.  \n \u2022 This primitive opens new avenues for distributed quantum error correction and measurement\u2010based quantum networking with Rydberg\u2010memory nodes.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core parity\u2010measurement primitive duplicates the previously suggested nonlocal parity gate. To be novel, you would need a qualitatively new twist\u2014e.g. multi-qubit stabilizer checks beyond two qubits, coherent superposition of parity\u2010check orders, or a higher-dimensional nonlocal operator\u2014rather than a straightforward platform swap of the same static linear\u2010optical parity projector.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nI need a genuinely new network transformation\u2014no mere swapping or routing\u2014combining a Rydberg\u2010atom array with entangled photonic ancillas in a purely static linear\u2010optical module. Pytheus can optimize static interferometers with single\u2010photon sources and heralding detectors to implement a nontrivial two\u2010qubit gate (Controlled-Z) between remote memories. This \u201ctele\u2010CZ\u201d module is a key building block for distributed quantum processing, generalizable to higher\u2010node graph\u2010state fusion or multi\u2010gate sequences, yet uses no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cHeralded Tele-CZ Gate for Rydberg-Atom Memories\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have two distant Rydberg-atom quantum memories A and B, each holding an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9_A, |\u03d5\u27e9_B. Each memory is converted on demand into a single photon in modes 0 and 1. We also prepare one photonic Bell pair (ancilla) in modes 2 & 3 (abstractly |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9). All four photons enter a single static 4\u00d74 linear-optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Conditioned on a specific two-click heralding pattern (e.g. clicks on D2 & D3), the two photonic inputs from A and B emerge (in the remaining unclicked outputs) having undergone a CZ gate:\n\n  CZ : |x,y\u27e9 \u2192 (\u20131)^{x\u00b7y} |x,y\u27e9 \n\nThus the unknown memory qubits are teleported back to A and B with the CZ applied between them. No dynamic control is needed\u2014just static optics and heralding.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3}):\n{\n  description:      'Heralded tele-CZ gate for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydTeleCZ',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],           // modes: A_photon, B_photon, ancilla pair\n  amplitudes:       [[2,3]],             // one Bell-pair source on modes 2&3\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],               // clicks on detectors D2 & D3 herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00->00','01->01','10->10','11->-11'], // ideal CZ mapping\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          15,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Implements a nonlocal two-qubit CZ gate between remote Rydberg memories in one static linear\u2010optical device.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to multi-gate, graph-state fusion modules by adding ancilla Bell pairs and extending the interferometer.  \n \u2022 A centerpiece for distributed quantum computing and repeater protocols that require remote entangling gates, not just swapping.  \n \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope: abstract photonic modes, static interferometer, single-photon sources, heralding detectors\u2014no feedback or cavities needed.  \n\nThis target invites Pytheus to discover the minimal interferometer and detection scheme that, via post-selection, teleports a CZ between two atomic memories\u2014opening a new primitive for quantum networks and distributed processing.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This overlaps with standard teleportation-based entangling gates (e.g. the PT-symmetric tele-CNOT) and KLM-style non-deterministic CZ teleportation. To be PRL-worthy, you need a genuinely new network primitive\u2014e.g. multi-party gate teleportation, indefinite causal-order gating, higher-dimensional teleported operations, or an adaptive multi-stage gate sequence\u2014rather than a direct CZ variant of an existing teleportation protocol.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:\nI need a genuinely new network\u2010operation primitive\u2014beyond routing or simple swapping\u2014that combines a Rydberg\u2010atom array with entangled photonic ancillas, is implementable by Pytheus using only static linear optics, single\u2010photon (and pair) emitters, and heralding detectors, and which can be generalized to larger networks. The concept of an indefinite\u2010order (quantum switch) applied to entanglement\u2010swapping modules fits: it superposes two distinct swap operations, creating a new \u201cswap\u2010in\u2010superposition\u201d network primitive.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cQuantum\u2010Switch Entanglement Swapping for Rydberg Arrays\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have two distant Rydberg\u2010atom memories A and B (modes 0 and 1) that we wish to entangle. Instead of a single entanglement\u2010swap station, there are two ancilla memories C and D, each initially sharing a Bell pair with A and B respectively:\n \u2022 Bell pair A\u2013C in photonic modes 2&3  \n \u2022 Bell pair B\u2013D in photonic modes 4&5  \nWe also introduce one control photon (mode 6), prepared in an equal superposition of two path\u2010labels |c1\u27e9+|c2\u27e9. All seven photons enter a single static 7\u00d77 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. At the output, seven number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D6 monitor every mode.\n\nThe network is arranged so that:\n \u2022 If the control lives in path c1, the interferometer implements a Bell measurement on modes 2&3 first (swap via C),  \n \u2022 If it lives in path c2, it implements the Bell measurement on modes 4&5 first (swap via D).  \nBecause the control photon remains unmeasured and both paths are coherently recombined, the order of the two swap\u2010modules is placed in superposition. Conditioned on a single \u201cheralding\u2010click\u201d in a designated ancilla detector subset (e.g. D2), the two unmeasured output modes corresponding to A and B collapse into an entangled state. Crucially, A\u2013B becomes entangled by a pathway that is in an indefinite causal order\u2014an equal superposition of \u201cswap via C then D\u201d and \u201cswap via D then C.\u201d\n\nThis realizes a new network primitive: superposed\u2010order entanglement swapping (a photonic quantum SWITCH applied to Bell\u2010measurements), directly coupling Rydberg\u2010memory nodes in a way no prior static device has done.\n\nexample config skeleton:\n{\n  description:      'Q\u2010SWITCH entanglement swap between A,B via C,D',\n  foldername:       'RydQSwitchSwap',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,6],             // modes A, B, control\n  amplitudes:       [[2,3],[4,5]],       // two Bell\u2010pair sources: A\u2013C, B\u2013D\n  heralding_out:    [2],                  // e.g. click on detector D2 heralds success\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],          // AB in Bell basis on unmeasured modes\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      50,\n  tries_per_edge:   10,\n  samples:          30,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 First static\u2010optical realization of a quantum SWITCH on entanglement\u2010swapping modules\u2014placing the order of two Bell measurements in superposition.  \n \u2022 Goes beyond \u201centanglement router\u201d or \u201cpercolation switch\u201d: it introduces indefinite causal structure into a basic quantum\u2010network link operation.  \n \u2022 Directly uses Rydberg\u2010memory nodes as the endpoints and purely photonic ancillas and static optics\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to N\u2010swap superpositions, larger networks, and studies of causal order in entanglement distribution.\n\nThis invites Pytheus to discover the minimal 7\u00d77 interferometer and detection scheme that, via post\u2010selection, implements a superposed\u2010order entanglement swap between two remote atomic memories\u2014a brand\u2010new quantum\u2010network primitive."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nHeralded Linear\u2010Optical 1\u21922 QuTrIt Telecloning via Resonance-Dip Multiport Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose and analyze a fully linear-optical implementation of the first 1\u21922 qutrit telecloner, in which three probabilistic qutrit-entangled photon-pair sources feed a balanced three-mode multiport Bell measurement module synchronized by identical delay-loop \u201cresonators.\u201d Success of the telecloning is unambiguously heralded by a generalized Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel resonance dip in triple-coincidence ancilla detections, conditionally projecting the two receivers into the optimal symmetric clones of the unknown input qutrit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a target PyTheus-compatible linear-optical network in which two classical users, Alice and Bob, each send Z-basis single photons to a fully quantum node, Charlie, who entangles them with his ancilla Bell pair and performs post-selected entanglement-swapping to nonlocally compute their parity x\u2295y as a shared key bit. This minimal experiment\u2014requiring only probabilistic photon-pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors without dynamic feed-forward\u2014demonstrates a novel nonlocal XOR primitive and provides a direct semi-quantum key agreement primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nEntanglement-Fano Interferometry via Three-Channel Heralded Swaps in a Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a discrete-vs-continuum Fano-resonance experiment between distant nodes A and C in which the two-photon Bell-state amplitude from a direct Bell-pair source coherently interferes with amplitudes generated by successive two-hop (via B) and three-hop (via D\u2192E) heralded entanglement swaps, with static polarization phase shifts \u03c6\u2082 and \u03c6\u2083 controlling the interference.  The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. In the current experiment, the explicit target is to herald each of the four Bell-state outcomes using two ancilla photons and ten number-resolving detectors\u2014realizing, for the first time, a high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer to enable ququart teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Non-Abelian Wilson Loop via a Four-Step Teleportation Ring\n\nAbstract: We implement the proposed Pytheus target\u2014a closed \u201cteleporter loop\u201d around a four-site square\u2014by chaining four probabilistic photon-pair sources and sequential two-photon Bell measurements to teleport an input qubit around a plaquette and accumulate a non-trivial Pauli by-product holonomy. By post-selecting on a fixed pattern of Bell outcomes and contrasting clockwise versus counterclockwise traversal, we directly reveal a non-commuting (non-Abelian) Wilson-loop effect in a purely linear-optical quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single-Shot GHZ-Based Entanglement Percolation on an Integrated Photonic Chip\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a single-shot multi-photon GHZ-projection percolation protocol on an integrated photonic chip with ultra-high-Q microring delays, explicitly targeting a joint six-mode GHZ\u2297Bell measurement across three adjacent Bell-pair sources to herald end-to-end entanglement between two distant nodes. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Four-Party GHZ Entanglement-Swapping Star with 3\u21921 Network Steering\n\nAbstract: We implement a single-step four-photon GHZ entanglement-swapping star that fuses four independent probabilistic Bell-pair sources at a central station via a linear-optical 4-photon GHZ projector to realize the target 4-party GHZ resource. Conditioned on the heralding event, three remote parties perform mutually unbiased-basis measurements whose correlated outcomes, together with tomography data at the fourth party, violate a 3\u21921 multipartite EPR-steering inequality\u2014demonstrating genuine network steering without nonlinear elements or feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear\u2010Optical Partial-SWAP Gate for Emulating Coherent Rabi Oscillations and Ultrastrong Coupling in Photonic Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose a heralded linear-optical implementation of the tunable partial-SWAP unitary  \nU(\u03b8)=cos \u03b8 I + i\u2009sin \u03b8 SWAP on two photonic-qubit modes, which continuously maps the \u03b8-dependent population exchange |10\u27e9\u2194|01\u27e9 (analogous to coherent Rabi oscillations) into the ultrastrong-coupling regime at \u03b8\u2192\u03c0/2 (full SWAP with multi-photon excitations). By optimizing the write/read reflectivities {r_w\u2081,r_w\u2082,r_r\u2081,r_r\u2082} to achieve the target average cloning fidelity F_target = 5/6 under a minimum success probability p_min, our scheme fully exploits PytHeus\u2019s optimization framework to quantify the trade-off between coupling strengths and finite photon lifetimes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By statically mixing the inner modes in an optimized linear-optics network and post-selecting on two threshold-detector clicks, the scheme realizes the target Bell pair in one heralded operation without active feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Discrete Quantum\u2010Metric Classification of Photonic Qudits via Parallel SWAP\u2010Test Network\n\nAbstract: We implement a fixed linear\u2010optical network that routes a single unknown D\u2010level photonic qudit into one of K output ports by performing K parallel SWAP\u2010test and entanglement\u2010swapping modules against K reference states, thereby selecting the port whose Fubini\u2013Study distance to the input is minimal. The resulting single\u2010click detector events yield a fully quantized classifier response targeting photonic qudit state discrimination as a new quantum\u2010metric machine\u2010learning primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOn\u2010Chip Three\u2010Photon Repetition\u2010Code Logical\u2010Bell State Analyzer in Silicon Photonics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract:  \nWe propose and design an integrated silicon\u2010photonic circuit that implements an error\u2010detecting logical\u2010Bell state measurement on two qubits encoded in the three\u2010photon repetition code, using six waveguide modes, tunable Mach\u2013Zehnder interferometer parity\u2010check modules, and a final multiport interferometer. This analyzer unambiguously discriminates all four logical Bell states (|\u03a6\u00b1\u27e9\u2097, |\u03a8\u00b1\u27e9\u2097) while simultaneously heralding single\u2010photon loss errors via on\u2010chip photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors, fully compatible with Pyth\u00e9us linear\u2010optics primitives.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Post-Selected Linear-Optics Teleportation of Wigner-Negative Qutrits in d = 3\n\nAbstract: We design a discrete-variable teleportation channel in dimension d = 3 using a pre-shared probabilistic qutrit Bell pair, four single-photon ancillas, and number-resolving detectors within a linear-optics interferometer to probabilistically teleport any unknown qutrit input.  Leveraging the PytHeus framework, we optimize beam-splitter angles and routing to maximize the teleportation fidelity of representative Wigner-negative test states (\u03a8\u2081,\u03a8\u2082), explicitly targeting the preservation of Wigner function negativity as the primary performance metric.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. Physically, each of the N array nodes (e.g. N=3 or 4 for demonstration) holds a Rydberg atomic qubit whose excitation can be converted into a single photon.  We assume that each node emits one photon entangled with its atomic memory (an abstract photonic mode).  All N photons enter a single N-port interferometer network, mix via beam splitters and phase shifters, and exit at output ports monitored by ancilla photon-number-resolving detectors.  Different click patterns at these ancilla detectors herald a Bell\u2010pair between exactly two of the memory qubits\u2014thereby routing entanglement on demand, without reconfiguring optics.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Generalizes entanglement swapping to a fully passive, reconfigurable router.  \n \u2022 Enables multiplexed, on-demand Bell\u2010links across any pair of atomic memory nodes.  \n \u2022 Lays groundwork for scalable quantum\u2010network switches and network\u2010coding primitives in Rydberg-based quantum repeaters or quantum internet nodes.\n\nKey Pytheus configuration elements (expert to flesh out):\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0,\u2026,N\u20131]  (one photon per memory node)  \n \u2022 a single multiport network (to be optimized) with N inputs \u2192 M outputs (M\u2265N)  \n \u2022 ancilla detectors on M\u20132 ports, leaving 2 \u201cmemory\u2010link\u201d output ports free  \n \u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct two-photon collisions between non-chosen node pairs if desired  \n \u2022 target_quantum: a set of Bell states on every 2-node subset; optimize so that each ancilla\u2010click pattern projects the remaining two output modes onto |00>+|11>  \n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the minimal multiport interferometer and detector arrangement that, upon heralding, routes entanglement between arbitrary node pairs\u2014an architecture-level quantum\u2010network primitive novel to the linear\u2010optical toolbox.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed static multiport interferometer that passively heralds entanglement between any two of N quantum\u2010memory nodes is essentially the same \u201cmultiplexed entanglement router\u201d primitive already in the ensemble (\u201cA Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\u201d). Each node coherently converts its atomic excitation into one photon (abstract mode 0,1,2). These three photons enter a single 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus). The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Whenever exactly one detector Di clicks, the remaining two (unclicked) output modes are projected into a two-qubit Bell state |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of Rydberg memories. Thus:\n \u2022 D0 click \u2192 entangles B&C  \n \u2022 D1 click \u2192 entangles A&C  \n \u2022 D2 click \u2192 entangles A&B  \n\nThis is a passive, heralded entanglement router: by post-selecting on which detector fires, we choose which pair of memories becomes entangled, without reconfiguring the optics.\n\nconfig (example for heralding D2 \u2192 entangle A&B):\n{'description':'Passive 3-node entanglement router for Rydberg memories','foldername':'RydbergRouter3','single_emitters':[0,1,2],'num_anc':1,'heralding_out':[2],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'in_nodes':[],'out_nodes':[],'anc_detectors':[],'removed_connections':[],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':30,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':10,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo cover all three routing patterns, one simply repeats the optimization with heralding_out=[0] and heralding_out=[1]: each run yields the same static interferometer but different herald-detector assignment projects onto the desired Bell link. This architecture scales to N nodes via an N\u00d7N multiport and N single-photon sources.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed 3-node \u201cRydberg Entanglement Router\u201d implements exactly the same passive, heralded routing primitive as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides,\u201d merely swapping in Rydberg emitters. Each node converts its two local memories into photons: A produces modes 0,1 (imperfect pair a\u2081\u2013b\u2081), and B produces modes 2,3 (imperfect pair a\u2082\u2013b\u2082). All four photons enter a single static 4\u00d74 linear-optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus). The four outputs go to four number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Upon obtaining clicks on detectors {D2,D3} (the \u201cancilla\u201d measurement), the unmeasured output modes (D0,D1) collapse into a purified high-fidelity Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between the two Rydberg memories at A and B. This implements one round of the BBPSSW entanglement-distillation protocol in a single passive module\u2014no dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, only static linear optics and heralding. By cascading or interconnecting multiple such modules, one can build multi-stage purification chains for long-distance quantum repeater networks.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3} \u2192 purified A\u2013B Bell pair):\n{\n  description:      'Entanglement purification for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydPurification2',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],       // modes from A:a1,a2 and B:b1,b2\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],           // detectors D2,D3 clicks herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],      // purified Bell basis on modes 0,1\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      30,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Introduces the first static, heralded entanglement-distillation primitive for Rydberg-atom quantum memories in a single module.  \n \u2022 Moves beyond point-to-point swapping: it cleans noisy links, a vital network primitive toward scalable repeaters.  \n \u2022 Fully generalizable to multi-stage purification chains and to higher dimensions by extending the network size and detection patterns.\n\nThis target leverages Pytheus\u2019s strength\u2014optimizing static linear-optical networks with single-photon sources and heralding detectors\u2014to discover minimal purification circuits, forging a new building block for quantum-network protocols.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed \u201cEntanglement Purification Module\u201d is essentially the same one\u2010shot, static linear\u2010optical distillation primitive already in the ensemble (the \u201cOne-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u3009+|11\u3009 Bell Pairs\u201d), which mixes two imperfect pairs in a 4\u00d74 network and To be novel, you must propose a fundamentally different purification mechanism (e.g. multi\u2010round adaptive purification, higher-dimensional distillation, or coherence-assisted protocols beyond simple post-selection) rather than a direct platform swap of the same static linear-optical module.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cHeralded Nonlocal Parity Measurement for Rydberg Memories\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have two distant Rydberg\u2010atom quantum memories A and B. Each memory\u2019s qubit is converted into one photon (abstract modes 0 and 1) that carries its Z\u2010basis information. We also introduce one ancillary single\u2010photon emitter (mode 2) to mediate the joint measurement. All three photons enter a single static 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The three output modes are monitored by number\u2010resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Depending on which detector clicks (exactly one click), the two Rydberg memories collapse into one of the two Z\u2297Z parity subspaces:\n\n \u2022 If Di clicks with i\u2208{0,1}, the memories are projected onto the even\u2010parity Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 (heralded by detector patterns {0} or {1}).  \n \u2022 If D2 clicks, the memories are projected onto the odd\u2010parity Bell state |01\u27e9+|10\u27e9 (heralded by {2}).\n\nThis realizes a non\u2010destructive, heralded remote Z\u2297Z parity check between two atomic qubits in one static module\u2014an essential building block for distributed error syndrome extraction and measurement\u2010based network protocols.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding Di\u2192even or odd parity):\n{\n  description:      'Heralded parity measurement for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydParityMeas',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],         // modes from A, B, and ancilla\n  heralding_out:    [i],             // i=0 or 1 \u2192 even parity; i=2 \u2192 odd parity\n  target_quantum:   (i<2 ? ['00','11'] : ['01','10']),\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      20,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 A joint nonlocal parity measurement is a key network transform\u2014beyond swapping or teleportation\u2014that underpins entanglement purification, error syndrome extraction, and measurement\u2010based repeater protocols.  \n \u2022 We deploy only static linear optics, three single\u2010photon emitters, and heralding detectors\u2014perfectly within Pytheus\u2019s remit.  \n \u2022 The concept generalizes immediately to N\u2010qubit stabilizer checks (e.g. 4\u2010mode network for X\u2297X\u2297Z\u2297Z) by adding ancilla emitters and detectors.  \n \u2022 This primitive opens new avenues for distributed quantum error correction and measurement\u2010based quantum networking with Rydberg\u2010memory nodes.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This scheme is essentially a two\u2010qubit Z\u2297Z parity projector implemented by a fixed 3\u00d73 interferometer and a single ancilla photon, which collapses two atomic memories into the even\u2010 or odd\u2010parity Bell subspace based on one-click heralding. However, the ensemble has already proposed a nonlocal parity gate (\u201cExperimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\u201d) that uses static linear optics and post-selected ancilla measurements to compute x\u2295y and project onto even/odd parity. Swapping in Rydberg memories and trading a Bell-pair ancilla for one single photon does not introduce a fundamentally new network transform or mechanism.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The core parity\u2010measurement primitive duplicates the previously suggested nonlocal parity gate. To be novel, you would need a qualitatively new twist\u2014e.g. multi-qubit stabilizer checks beyond two qubits, coherent superposition of parity\u2010check orders, or a higher-dimensional nonlocal operator\u2014rather than a straightforward platform swap of the same static linear\u2010optical parity projector.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cHeralded Tele-CZ Gate for Rydberg-Atom Memories\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have two distant Rydberg-atom quantum memories A and B, each holding an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9_A, |\u03d5\u27e9_B. Each memory is converted on demand into a single photon in modes 0 and 1. We also prepare one photonic Bell pair (ancilla) in modes 2 & 3 (abstractly |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9). All four photons enter a single static 4\u00d74 linear-optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Conditioned on a specific two-click heralding pattern (e.g. clicks on D2 & D3), the two photonic inputs from A and B emerge (in the remaining unclicked outputs) having undergone a CZ gate:\n\n  CZ : |x,y\u27e9 \u2192 (\u20131)^{x\u00b7y} |x,y\u27e9 \n\nThus the unknown memory qubits are teleported back to A and B with the CZ applied between them. No dynamic control is needed\u2014just static optics and heralding.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3}):\n{\n  description:      'Heralded tele-CZ gate for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydTeleCZ',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],           // modes: A_photon, B_photon, ancilla pair\n  amplitudes:       [[2,3]],             // one Bell-pair source on modes 2&3\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],               // clicks on detectors D2 & D3 herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00->00','01->01','10->10','11->-11'], // ideal CZ mapping\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          15,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Implements a nonlocal two-qubit CZ gate between remote Rydberg memories in one static linear\u2010optical device.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to multi-gate, graph-state fusion modules by adding ancilla Bell pairs and extending the interferometer.  \n \u2022 A centerpiece for distributed quantum computing and repeater protocols that require remote entangling gates, not just swapping.  \n \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope: abstract photonic modes, static interferometer, single-photon sources, heralding detectors\u2014no feedback or cavities needed.  \n\nThis target invites Pytheus to discover the minimal interferometer and detection scheme that, via post-selection, teleports a CZ between two atomic memories\u2014opening a new primitive for quantum networks and distributed processing.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed heralded tele-CZ gate is essentially a teleportation-based entangling gate built from one Bell-pair ancilla and post-selected linear optics\u2014a straight LO version of the well-known gate-teleportation primitive (and highly reminiscent of the PT-symmetric tele-CNOT suggestion in the ensemble). Swapping CNOT for CZ by local Hadamards does not introduce a new network capability or mechanism. There\u2019s no novel twist beyond a trivial platform swap of a basic non-deterministic linear-optical gate teleportation.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This overlaps with standard teleportation-based entangling gates (e.g. the PT-symmetric tele-CNOT) and KLM-style non-deterministic CZ teleportation. Instead of a single entanglement\u2010swap station, there are two ancilla memories C and D, each initially sharing a Bell pair with A and B respectively:\n \u2022 Bell pair A\u2013C in photonic modes 2&3  \n \u2022 Bell pair B\u2013D in photonic modes 4&5  \nWe also introduce one control photon (mode 6), prepared in an equal superposition of two path\u2010labels |c1\u27e9+|c2\u27e9. All seven photons enter a single static 7\u00d77 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. At the output, seven number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D6 monitor every mode.\n\nThe network is arranged so that:\n \u2022 If the control lives in path c1, the interferometer implements a Bell measurement on modes 2&3 first (swap via C),  \n \u2022 If it lives in path c2, it implements the Bell measurement on modes 4&5 first (swap via D).  \nBecause the control photon remains unmeasured and both paths are coherently recombined, the order of the two swap\u2010modules is placed in superposition. Conditioned on a single \u201cheralding\u2010click\u201d in a designated ancilla detector subset (e.g. D2), the two unmeasured output modes corresponding to A and B collapse into an entangled state. Crucially, A\u2013B becomes entangled by a pathway that is in an indefinite causal order\u2014an equal superposition of \u201cswap via C then D\u201d and \u201cswap via D then C.\u201d\n\nThis realizes a new network primitive: superposed\u2010order entanglement swapping (a photonic quantum SWITCH applied to Bell\u2010measurements), directly coupling Rydberg\u2010memory nodes in a way no prior static device has done.\n\nexample config skeleton:\n{\n  description:      'Q\u2010SWITCH entanglement swap between A,B via C,D',\n  foldername:       'RydQSwitchSwap',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,6],             // modes A, B, control\n  amplitudes:       [[2,3],[4,5]],       // two Bell\u2010pair sources: A\u2013C, B\u2013D\n  heralding_out:    [2],                  // e.g. click on detector D2 heralds success\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],          // AB in Bell basis on unmeasured modes\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      50,\n  tries_per_edge:   10,\n  samples:          30,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 First static\u2010optical realization of a quantum SWITCH on entanglement\u2010swapping modules\u2014placing the order of two Bell measurements in superposition.  \n \u2022 Goes beyond \u201centanglement router\u201d or \u201cpercolation switch\u201d: it introduces indefinite causal structure into a basic quantum\u2010network link operation.  \n \u2022 Directly uses Rydberg\u2010memory nodes as the endpoints and purely photonic ancillas and static optics\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to N\u2010swap superpositions, larger networks, and studies of causal order in entanglement distribution.\n\nThis invites Pytheus to discover the minimal 7\u00d77 interferometer and detection scheme that, via post\u2010selection, implements a superposed\u2010order entanglement swap between two remote atomic memories\u2014a brand\u2010new quantum\u2010network primitive.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposed \u201cquantum\u2010switch entanglement swap\u201d is functionally identical to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cEntanglement\u2010Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic\u2010Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders,\u201d merely swapping in Rydberg memories for the storage nodes. No new operational feature or mechanism is introduced beyond a change of physical platform.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This duplicates the ensemble\u2019s photonic quantum\u2010switch primitive. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"rydberg atom array\" and \"entangled quantum state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Each converts its memory excitation into one single photon (abstract modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter one static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the two unclicked output modes collapse into a Bell pair |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of memories. By post-selecting on different click-pairs, one \u201cactivates\u201d any of the six possible links in the square:\n\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D  (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangle B\u2013D  (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013C  (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013B  (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangle B\u2013C  (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangle A\u2013D  (diagonal AD)\n\nThis single device realizes all six entanglement-swapping channels in one static interferometer, enabling studies of entanglement percolation, network-coding primitives, and dynamic connectivity in a minimal four-node cell.\n\nexample config (for heralding {0,1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D):\n{\n  description:      '4-node percolation switch',\n  foldername:       'RydbergPercolation4',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],        // A,B,C,D emitters\n  num_anc:          0,\n  heralding_out:    [0,1],            // detectors Di,Dj that click\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],       // Bell basis on the remaining modes\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          20,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nOne runs six separate Pytheus optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair\u2014to recover a single 4\u00d74 network whose various two-click patterns select any desired Bell link. All four photons enter a single static 4\u00d74 linear-optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus). This implements one round of the BBPSSW entanglement-distillation protocol in a single passive module\u2014no dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, only static linear optics and heralding. By cascading or interconnecting multiple such modules, one can build multi-stage purification chains for long-distance quantum repeater networks.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3} \u2192 purified A\u2013B Bell pair):\n{\n  description:      'Entanglement purification for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydPurification2',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],       // modes from A:a1,a2 and B:b1,b2\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],           // detectors D2,D3 clicks herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],      // purified Bell basis on modes 0,1\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      30,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Introduces the first static, heralded entanglement-distillation primitive for Rydberg-atom quantum memories in a single module.  \n \u2022 Moves beyond point-to-point swapping: it cleans noisy links, a vital network primitive toward scalable repeaters.  \n \u2022 Fully generalizable to multi-stage purification chains and to higher dimensions by extending the network size and detection patterns.\n\nThis target leverages Pytheus\u2019s strength\u2014optimizing static linear-optical networks with single-photon sources and heralding detectors\u2014to discover minimal purification circuits, forging a new building block for quantum-network protocols.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the ensemble\u2019s one\u2010shot swap-and-concentrate repeater. Each memory\u2019s qubit is converted into one photon (abstract modes 0 and 1) that carries its Z\u2010basis information. We also introduce one ancillary single\u2010photon emitter (mode 2) to mediate the joint measurement. All three photons enter a single static 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The three output modes are monitored by number\u2010resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Depending on which detector clicks (exactly one click), the two Rydberg memories collapse into one of the two Z\u2297Z parity subspaces:\n\n \u2022 If Di clicks with i\u2208{0,1}, the memories are projected onto the even\u2010parity Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 (heralded by detector patterns {0} or {1}).  \n \u2022 If D2 clicks, the memories are projected onto the odd\u2010parity Bell state |01\u27e9+|10\u27e9 (heralded by {2}).\n\nThis realizes a non\u2010destructive, heralded remote Z\u2297Z parity check between two atomic qubits in one static module\u2014an essential building block for distributed error syndrome extraction and measurement\u2010based network protocols.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding Di\u2192even or odd parity):\n{\n  description:      'Heralded parity measurement for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydParityMeas',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],         // modes from A, B, and ancilla\n  heralding_out:    [i],             // i=0 or 1 \u2192 even parity; i=2 \u2192 odd parity\n  target_quantum:   (i<2 ? ['00','11'] : ['01','10']),\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      20,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 A joint nonlocal parity measurement is a key network transform\u2014beyond swapping or teleportation\u2014that underpins entanglement purification, error syndrome extraction, and measurement\u2010based repeater protocols.  \n \u2022 We deploy only static linear optics, three single\u2010photon emitters, and heralding detectors\u2014perfectly within Pytheus\u2019s remit.  \n \u2022 The concept generalizes immediately to N\u2010qubit stabilizer checks (e.g. 4\u2010mode network for X\u2297X\u2297Z\u2297Z) by adding ancilla emitters and detectors.  \n \u2022 This primitive opens new avenues for distributed quantum error correction and measurement\u2010based quantum networking with Rydberg\u2010memory nodes.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core parity\u2010measurement primitive duplicates the previously suggested nonlocal parity gate. Each memory is converted on demand into a single photon in modes 0 and 1. We also prepare one photonic Bell pair (ancilla) in modes 2 & 3 (abstractly |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9). All four photons enter a single static 4\u00d74 linear-optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Conditioned on a specific two-click heralding pattern (e.g. clicks on D2 & D3), the two photonic inputs from A and B emerge (in the remaining unclicked outputs) having undergone a CZ gate:\n\n  CZ : |x,y\u27e9 \u2192 (\u20131)^{x\u00b7y} |x,y\u27e9 \n\nThus the unknown memory qubits are teleported back to A and B with the CZ applied between them. No dynamic control is needed\u2014just static optics and heralding.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3}):\n{\n  description:      'Heralded tele-CZ gate for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydTeleCZ',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],           // modes: A_photon, B_photon, ancilla pair\n  amplitudes:       [[2,3]],             // one Bell-pair source on modes 2&3\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],               // clicks on detectors D2 & D3 herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00->00','01->01','10->10','11->-11'], // ideal CZ mapping\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          15,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Implements a nonlocal two-qubit CZ gate between remote Rydberg memories in one static linear\u2010optical device.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to multi-gate, graph-state fusion modules by adding ancilla Bell pairs and extending the interferometer.  \n \u2022 A centerpiece for distributed quantum computing and repeater protocols that require remote entangling gates, not just swapping.  \n \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope: abstract photonic modes, static interferometer, single-photon sources, heralding detectors\u2014no feedback or cavities needed.  \n\nThis target invites Pytheus to discover the minimal interferometer and detection scheme that, via post-selection, teleports a CZ between two atomic memories\u2014opening a new primitive for quantum networks and distributed processing.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This overlaps with standard teleportation-based entangling gates (e.g. the PT-symmetric tele-CNOT) and KLM-style non-deterministic CZ teleportation. To be PRL-worthy, you need a genuinely new network primitive\u2014e.g. multi-party gate teleportation, indefinite causal-order gating, higher-dimensional teleported operations, or an adaptive multi-stage gate sequence\u2014rather than a direct CZ variant of an existing teleportation protocol.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!
