Memories A, B, C are each converted into single photons in modes 0, 1, 2 respectively.  \n2. A central station Z generates three Bell pairs (ancillas):\n   \u2022 Pair Z1: modes 3 & 4  \n   \u2022 Pair Z2: modes 5 & 6  \n   \u2022 Pair Z3: modes 7 & 8  \n3. All nine photons (modes 0\u20138) enter one static 9\u00d79 linear-optical interferometer (beam splitters & phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus.  \n4. The nine output modes are measured by nine photon-number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D8.  \n5. When exactly six detectors corresponding to the three Bell measurements (e.g. clicks on {D3,D4,D5,D6,D7,D8}) click, the three unmeasured outputs (from modes 0\u20132) collapse into the cyclically permuted state:\n     (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A): |\u03c8\u27e9_A\u2297|\u03d5\u27e9_B\u2297|\u03c7\u27e9_C  \u2192  |\u03c7\u27e9_A\u2297|\u03c8\u27e9_B\u2297|\u03d5\u27e9_C  \n   thus implementing the 3-cycle unitary U_cycle: |abc\u27e9 \u2192 |cab\u27e9 in one shot.\n\nThis realizes a new network\u2010primitive: a teleportation ring that shifts three quantum states around a triangle of memories in a single passive, heralded linear-optical device.\n\nexample Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:      '3-party teleportation ring (cyclic permutation)',\n  foldername:       'RydTeleportRing3',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],            // modes from A,B,C unknown qubits\n  amplitudes:       [[3,4],[5,6],[7,8]],// three Bell-pair sources at Z\n  in_nodes:         [],\n  out_nodes:        [],\n  heralding_out:    [3,4,5,6,7,8],      // six detectors for the three Bell measurements\n  target_mapping: {                       // mapping for computational basis strings\n    'abc'->'cab' for all a,b,c\u2208{0,1}\n  },\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      80,\n  tries_per_edge:   10,\n  samples:          40,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Implements the cyclic shift unitary on three unknown qubits via simultaneous teleportations in one static device, a Pytheus can optimize a static 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical network with two unknown single-photon sources plus one ancilla emitter and herald detectors\u2014no dynamic control, no cavities.\n\n  Step 3: Choose (3) the heralded SWAP\u2010test.\n\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    \u2022 No prior Pytheus experiment has realized a nonlocal SWAP\u2010test between two remote quantum memories in one module; it\u2019s the first network primitive for direct quantum state comparison.  \n    \u2022 It opens the door to quantum\u2010fingerprinting, signature checking, and multi-node comparison networks.\n\n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    \u2022 Uses exactly three single\u2010photon emitters: two unknown qubit emitters (modes 0,1) and one ancilla (mode 2).  \n    \u2022 A single static 3\u00d73 interferometer of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus).  \n    \u2022 Three number-resolving detectors.  \n    \u2022 Different heralding clicks project the two unknown qubits onto symmetric (|\u03c8\u03c8\u27e9) vs antisymmetric (|\u03c8\u03d5\u27e9\u2212|\u03d5\u03c8\u27e9) subspaces.  \n    \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optics + heralding framework; no forbidden elements.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cHeralded Nonlocal SWAP\u2010Test for Rydberg\u2010Memory Qubits\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have two distant Rydberg\u2010atom memories A and B, each holding an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9_A, |\u03d5\u27e9_B.  They each convert their qubit into a single photon in modes 0 and 1.  A third single\u2010photon emitter (mode 2) supplies an ancilla photon in a fixed reference state.  All three photons enter a single static 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus).  The three outputs go to number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2.  Exactly one click heralds one of two projective outcomes on the two unknown modes:\n\n \u2022 If D0 clicks \u2192 the two memories are projected onto the symmetric subspace (test \u201cequal\u201d)  \n \u2022 If D1 clicks \u2192 the two memories are projected onto the antisymmetric subspace (test \u201cdifferent\u201d)  \n \u2022 Click on D2 \u2192 inconclusive (discard)\n\nThus, in one passive module we implement the SWAP\u2010test between remote Rydberg\u2010qubit memories.\n\nexample Pytheus config:\n{\n  description:      'Nonlocal SWAP\u2010test for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'Rydberg_SWAPTest',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],            // modes: A_unknown, B_unknown, ancilla\n  heralding_out:    [0,1],              // D0 \u2192 symmetric; D1 \u2192 antisymmetric\n  target_quantum:   [                      // projector on modes 0&1\n    D0: ['symm'],    D1: ['antisymm']\n  ],\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      20,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Fundamental network operation: direct quantum\u2010state comparison (SWAP\u2010test) across remote memories, not mere entanglement distribution.  \n \u2022 Building block for quantum\u2010fingerprinting, signature verification, and distributed consensus protocols.  \n \u2022 Fully static, heralded linear-optics module\u2014exactly Pytheus\u2019s domain\u2014with clear generalizations to multi-memory comparison networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates standard two\u2010qubit SWAP\u2010test constructions already found in the literature and the ensemble (e.g. generalized multi\u2010copy SWAP tests).     "output": "Here is a genuinely new network\u2010primitive combining a Rydberg\u2010atom array with entangled photonic ancillas, fully static (no feedback), that Pytheus can optimize. It goes beyond pairwise swaps or routing and implements a nonlocal three\u2010qubit parity check\u2014a key building block for distributed error\u2010syndrome extraction and network coding.\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cHeralded Nonlocal 3-Qubit Parity Check for Rydberg Memories\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have three distant Rydberg\u2010atom quantum memories A, B, C. Each holds a qubit in the computational basis (|0\u27e9 or |1\u27e9). On demand, each memory is converted into a single photon in modes 0, 1, 2 carrying its Z-basis value.  A fourth photon\u2014mode 3\u2014serves as an ancilla in a fixed state |+\u27e9.  All four photons enter one static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus).  The four outputs feed number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D3.\n\nWhen exactly one click is registered on D0 or D1 (and the other three detectors register zero), the three unmeasured photons (the ones in the modes that did _not_ click) are projected onto a joint parity subspace:\n\n \u2022 click on D0 \u21d2 the three memories collapse onto the _even_-parity subspace span{|000\u27e9,|011\u27e9,|101\u27e9,|110\u27e9}  \n \u2022 click on D1 \u21d2 the three memories collapse onto the _odd_-parity subspace span{|001\u27e9,|010\u27e9,|100\u27e9,|111\u27e9}  \n \u2022 clicks on D2 or D3 (or more than one click) are discarded as failures.\n\nThus, in one passive module we non-destructively measure Z\u2081\u2297Z\u2082\u2297Z\u2083 on three remote qubits\u2014heralded by a single\u2010detector click\u2014without any dynamic feed-forward or cavities.\n\nExample Pytheus config for the _even_-parity outcome (click = D0):\n\n{\n  description:     'Heralded 3-qubit parity check (even)',\n  foldername:      'RydParity3_even',\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3],          // modes from A, B, C plus ancilla\n  num_anc:         0,\n  heralding_out:   [0],                // only D0 click heralds success\n  target_quantum:  ['000','011','101','110'],  // the even-parity basis on modes 0\u20132\n  optimizer:       'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:       'cr',\n  edges_tried:     20,\n  tries_per_edge:  5,\n  samples:         10,\n  thresholds:      [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nFor the _odd_-parity outcome, simply repeat with foldername \u201cRydParity3_odd\u201d, heralding_out=[1] and target_quantum=['001','010','100','111'].\n\nWhy this is interesting and novel:\n\u2022 It implements a _three-qubit_ stabilizer measurement (Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083) as a single static linear-optical module\u2014no two-qubit swaps or teleportation but a genuinely new _multi-qubit measurement_ primitive.  \n\u2022 Heralded, non-destructive parity readout is the core of distributed quantum error-syndrome extraction, network coding of parity checks, and measurement-based entanglement purification in repeater chains.  \n\u2022 Fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: uses only abstract single-photon emitters, beam splitters/phase-shifters, and heralding photon-number-resolving detectors. No dynamic feed-forward, no cavities or resonances, no forbidden state\u2010generation.  \n\u2022 Immediately generalizable to N-qubit parity checks by adding ancilla photons and extending the interferometer, providing a scalable toolkit for multi-node quantum-network operations."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. Pytheus can handle multiple ancilla detectors and removed_connections to forbid unwanted links.  \n   3) Percolation cell is conceptually interesting but essentially a repetition of entanglement\u2010swapping chains in different configurations; less striking as a single target.\n\n Step 3: Pick the router (Option 2) \u2013 it\u2019s novel in the quantum\u2010network literature, it\u2019s independent of state\u2010generation implementation, and Pytheus can optimize a linear\u2010optical multiport with single\u2010photon sources and ancilla detectors to realize a family of heralded swaps.\n\n Step 4: This idea is novel because \u2026  \n   \u2013 In existing linear-optical examples one picks one pair to swap at a time; here a single fixed multiport allows heralded entangling of any two out of N memory nodes simply by postselecting on different detector patterns.  \n   \u2013 It generalizes entanglement swapping to a fully passive, reconfigurable (\u201crouter\u201d) architecture, opening a pathway to scalable quantum\u2010network switches.\n\n Step 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all additional constraints because \u2026  \n   \u2013 It uses only abstract photonic modes and linear optics (single\u2010photon sources and beam splitters) plus ancilla detectors\u2014exactly what Pytheus can optimize.  \n   \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward or cavities/resonances are needed; a single static interferometer plus heralding detectors suffices.  \n   \u2013 The target is a family of Bell\u2010swap outcomes (i.e. entanglement swapping transformations), not raw state generation, and it directly addresses a new quantum\u2010network primitive.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the target I suggest for Pytheus:\n\nDescription:\n Design a fixed linear\u2010optical \u201centanglement router\u201d that passively connects any two chosen nodes of a small Rydberg\u2010atom array network, purely by heralding on which ancilla detectors click.  Physically, each of the N array nodes (e.g. N=3 or 4 for demonstration) holds a Rydberg atomic qubit whose excitation can be converted into a single photon.  We assume that each node emits one photon entangled with its atomic memory (an abstract photonic mode).  All N photons enter a single N-port interferometer network, mix via beam splitters and phase shifters, and exit at output ports monitored by ancilla photon-number-resolving detectors.  Different click patterns at these ancilla detectors herald a Bell\u2010pair between exactly two of the memory qubits\u2014thereby routing entanglement on demand, without reconfiguring optics.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Generalizes entanglement swapping to a fully passive, reconfigurable router.  \n \u2022 Enables multiplexed, on-demand Bell\u2010links across any pair of atomic memory nodes.  \n \u2022 Lays groundwork for scalable quantum\u2010network switches and network\u2010coding primitives in Rydberg-based quantum repeaters or quantum internet nodes.\n\nKey Pytheus configuration elements (expert to flesh out):\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0,\u2026,N\u20131]  (one photon per memory node)  \n \u2022 a single multiport network (to be optimized) with N inputs \u2192 M outputs (M\u2265N)  \n \u2022 ancilla detectors on M\u20132 ports, leaving 2 \u201cmemory\u2010link\u201d output ports free  \n \u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct two-photon collisions between non-chosen node pairs if desired  \n \u2022 target_quantum: a set of Bell states on every 2-node subset; optimize so that each ancilla\u2010click pattern projects the remaining two output modes onto |00>+|11>  \n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the minimal multiport interferometer and detector arrangement that, upon heralding, routes entanglement between arbitrary node pairs\u2014an architecture-level quantum\u2010network primitive novel to the linear\u2010optical toolbox.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router\u201d proposal. A click on one output port heralds a Bell\u2010pair on the other two ports, thereby routing entanglement between any two memory qubits on demand.  \n   b) A four\u2010node \u201centanglement\u2010percolation cell\u201d on a square of Rydberg sites: probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources on each edge, with chosen Bell measurements (i.e. certain beam-splitter + detector modules) enabling entanglement swapping along different paths (edge vs diagonal), exploring connectivity thresholds.  \n   c) A superposed\u2010order entanglement swap between two pairs of Rydberg nodes: two entanglement-swapping modules placed in a Mach\u2013Zehnder\u2013like arrangement so that the order of swaps (swap AB\u2192C vs C\u2192D) is in coherent superposition\u2014studying indefinite\u2010causal\u2010order effects in network links.  \n Step 2: Compare to past Pytheus experiments and feasibility:\n   a) The 3-node router is not in the list (past work only did fixed entanglement swapping, not a single device that can herald any of three links). Each node coherently converts its atomic excitation into one photon (abstract mode 0,1,2). These three photons enter a single 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus). The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Whenever exactly one detector Di clicks, the remaining two (unclicked) output modes are projected into a two-qubit Bell state |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of Rydberg memories. Thus:\n \u2022 D0 click \u2192 entangles B&C  \n \u2022 D1 click \u2192 entangles A&C  \n \u2022 D2 click \u2192 entangles A&B  \n\nThis is a passive, heralded entanglement router: by post-selecting on which detector fires, we choose which pair of memories becomes entangled, without reconfiguring the optics.\n\nconfig (example for heralding D2 \u2192 entangle A&B):\n{'description':'Passive 3-node entanglement router for Rydberg memories','foldername':'RydbergRouter3','single_emitters':[0,1,2],'num_anc':1,'heralding_out':[2],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'in_nodes':[],'out_nodes':[],'anc_detectors':[],'removed_connections':[],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':30,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':10,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo cover all three routing patterns, one simply repeats the optimization with heralding_out=[0] and heralding_out=[1]: each run yields the same static interferometer but different herald-detector assignment projects onto the desired Bell link. This architecture scales to N nodes via an N\u00d7N multiport and N single-photon sources.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This target is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router\u201d proposal. Each node emits one photon (modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter a single 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized). The outputs go to four photon-number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the remaining two unclicked output modes are projected into the Bell state |00>+|11> of the corresponding two memories. Different click-pairs activate different network links:\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangles C&D (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangles B&D (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangles A&C (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangles A&B (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangles B&C (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangles A&D (diagonal AD)  \n\nconfig (example for heralding clicks {0,1} \u2192 entangle C&D):\n{'description':'4-node percolation switch','foldername':'RydbergPercolation4','single_emitters':[0,1,2,3],'num_anc':0,'heralding_out':[0,1],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':40,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':20,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo generate the full percolation cell, one runs six optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair. convert into single photons (modes 0,1).  \n\u2022 A central station Z generates two photonic Bell pairs: modes 2\u20133 entangle Z\u21c4C, modes 4\u20135 entangle Z\u21c4D.  \n\u2022 All six photons (modes 0\u20135) enter a single static 6\u00d76 linear-optical network (beam splitters & phase shifters) that Pytheus will optimize.  \n\u2022 Outputs go to six photon-number-resolving detectors: four \u201cBell-measurement\u201d detectors at Z (indices d0\u2013d3) and two \u201creceiver\u201d detectors at C (d4) and D (d5).  \n\u2022 Upon one of two distinct four-click patterns at {d0,d1,d2,d3}, the unknown qubit from A emerges at D and from B emerges at C, implementing simultaneous crossed teleportation (A\u2192D, B\u2192C). A different heralding pattern implements the alternate routing (A\u2192C, B\u2192D).\n\nconfig example (for heralding pattern routing A\u2192D, B\u2192C):\n{\n  description:      'Butterfly network-coded teleportation',\n  foldername:       'ryd_butterfly_tele',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1],          // A,B unknown-state emitters\n  amplitudes:       [],             // two Bell pairs at Z are implicit pair sources\n  in_nodes:         [],\n  out_nodes:        [],\n  heralding_out:    [d0,d1,d2,d3],  // specific four-click set at Z\n  target_mapping: {                   // teleportation map for computational basis\n    '00'-> output at (D,C) = '00',\n    '01'->                  '10',\n    '10'->                  '01',\n    '11'->                  '11'\n  },\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      50,\n  tries_per_edge:   10,\n  samples:          30,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 First linear-optical implementation of the quantum butterfly network code, a true network-coding primitive.  \n \u2022 Ties Rydberg atomic memories to advanced teleportation routing without dynamic control.  \n \u2022 Scales to larger network codes by extending the interferometer and heralding patterns.\n\nThis task asks Pytheus to discover the minimal static interferometer & detection scheme that, via heralded post-selection, performs two crossed teleportations in one device\u2014opening a new frontier in quantum network coding.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s butterfly cross\u2010teleportation target. Each converts its memory excitation into one single photon (abstract modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter one static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the two unclicked output modes collapse into a Bell pair |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of memories. By post-selecting on different click-pairs, one \u201cactivates\u201d any of the six possible links in the square:\n\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D  (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangle B\u2013D  (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013C  (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013B  (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangle B\u2013C  (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangle A\u2013D  (diagonal AD)\n\nThis single device realizes all six entanglement-swapping channels in one static interferometer, enabling studies of entanglement percolation, network-coding primitives, and dynamic connectivity in a minimal four-node cell.\n\nexample config (for heralding {0,1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D):\n{\n  description:      '4-node percolation switch',\n  foldername:       'RydbergPercolation4',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],        // A,B,C,D emitters\n  num_anc:          0,\n  heralding_out:    [0,1],            // detectors Di,Dj that click\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],       // Bell basis on the remaining modes\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          20,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nOne runs six separate Pytheus optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair\u2014to recover a single 4\u00d74 network whose various two-click patterns select any desired Bell link. All four photons enter a single static 4\u00d74 linear-optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus). This implements one round of the BBPSSW entanglement-distillation protocol in a single passive module\u2014no dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, only static linear optics and heralding. By cascading or interconnecting multiple such modules, one can build multi-stage purification chains for long-distance quantum repeater networks.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3} \u2192 purified A\u2013B Bell pair):\n{\n  description:      'Entanglement purification for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydPurification2',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],       // modes from A:a1,a2 and B:b1,b2\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],           // detectors D2,D3 clicks herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],      // purified Bell basis on modes 0,1\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      30,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Introduces the first static, heralded entanglement-distillation primitive for Rydberg-atom quantum memories in a single module.  \n \u2022 Moves beyond point-to-point swapping: it cleans noisy links, a vital network primitive toward scalable repeaters.  \n \u2022 Fully generalizable to multi-stage purification chains and to higher dimensions by extending the network size and detection patterns.\n\nThis target leverages Pytheus\u2019s strength\u2014optimizing static linear-optical networks with single-photon sources and heralding detectors\u2014to discover minimal purification circuits, forging a new building block for quantum-network protocols.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the ensemble\u2019s one\u2010shot swap-and-concentrate repeater. Each memory\u2019s qubit is converted into one photon (abstract modes 0 and 1) that carries its Z\u2010basis information. We also introduce one ancillary single\u2010photon emitter (mode 2) to mediate the joint measurement. All three photons enter a single static 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The three output modes are monitored by number\u2010resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Depending on which detector clicks (exactly one click), the two Rydberg memories collapse into one of the two Z\u2297Z parity subspaces:\n\n \u2022 If Di clicks with i\u2208{0,1}, the memories are projected onto the even\u2010parity Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 (heralded by detector patterns {0} or {1}).  \n \u2022 If D2 clicks, the memories are projected onto the odd\u2010parity Bell state |01\u27e9+|10\u27e9 (heralded by {2}).\n\nThis realizes a non\u2010destructive, heralded remote Z\u2297Z parity check between two atomic qubits in one static module\u2014an essential building block for distributed error syndrome extraction and measurement\u2010based network protocols.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding Di\u2192even or odd parity):\n{\n  description:      'Heralded parity measurement for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydParityMeas',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],         // modes from A, B, and ancilla\n  heralding_out:    [i],             // i=0 or 1 \u2192 even parity; i=2 \u2192 odd parity\n  target_quantum:   (i<2 ? ['00','11'] : ['01','10']),\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      20,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 A joint nonlocal parity measurement is a key network transform\u2014beyond swapping or teleportation\u2014that underpins entanglement purification, error syndrome extraction, and measurement\u2010based repeater protocols.  \n \u2022 We deploy only static linear optics, three single\u2010photon emitters, and heralding detectors\u2014perfectly within Pytheus\u2019s remit.  \n \u2022 The concept generalizes immediately to N\u2010qubit stabilizer checks (e.g. 4\u2010mode network for X\u2297X\u2297Z\u2297Z) by adding ancilla emitters and detectors.  \n \u2022 This primitive opens new avenues for distributed quantum error correction and measurement\u2010based quantum networking with Rydberg\u2010memory nodes.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core parity\u2010measurement primitive duplicates the previously suggested nonlocal parity gate. Each memory is converted on demand into a single photon in modes 0 and 1. We also prepare one photonic Bell pair (ancilla) in modes 2 & 3 (abstractly |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9). All four photons enter a single static 4\u00d74 linear-optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Conditioned on a specific two-click heralding pattern (e.g. clicks on D2 & D3), the two photonic inputs from A and B emerge (in the remaining unclicked outputs) having undergone a CZ gate:\n\n  CZ : |x,y\u27e9 \u2192 (\u20131)^{x\u00b7y} |x,y\u27e9 \n\nThus the unknown memory qubits are teleported back to A and B with the CZ applied between them. No dynamic control is needed\u2014just static optics and heralding.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3}):\n{\n  description:      'Heralded tele-CZ gate for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydTeleCZ',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],           // modes: A_photon, B_photon, ancilla pair\n  amplitudes:       [[2,3]],             // one Bell-pair source on modes 2&3\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],               // clicks on detectors D2 & D3 herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00->00','01->01','10->10','11->-11'], // ideal CZ mapping\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          15,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Implements a nonlocal two-qubit CZ gate between remote Rydberg memories in one static linear\u2010optical device.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to multi-gate, graph-state fusion modules by adding ancilla Bell pairs and extending the interferometer.  \n \u2022 A centerpiece for distributed quantum computing and repeater protocols that require remote entangling gates, not just swapping.  \n \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope: abstract photonic modes, static interferometer, single-photon sources, heralding detectors\u2014no feedback or cavities needed.  \n\nThis target invites Pytheus to discover the minimal interferometer and detection scheme that, via post-selection, teleports a CZ between two atomic memories\u2014opening a new primitive for quantum networks and distributed processing.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This overlaps with standard teleportation-based entangling gates (e.g. the PT-symmetric tele-CNOT) and KLM-style non-deterministic CZ teleportation. Instead of a single entanglement\u2010swap station, there are two ancilla memories C and D, each initially sharing a Bell pair with A and B respectively:\n \u2022 Bell pair A\u2013C in photonic modes 2&3  \n \u2022 Bell pair B\u2013D in photonic modes 4&5  \nWe also introduce one control photon (mode 6), prepared in an equal superposition of two path\u2010labels |c1\u27e9+|c2\u27e9. All seven photons enter a single static 7\u00d77 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. At the output, seven number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D6 monitor every mode.\n\nThe network is arranged so that:\n \u2022 If the control lives in path c1, the interferometer implements a Bell measurement on modes 2&3 first (swap via C),  \n \u2022 If it lives in path c2, it implements the Bell measurement on modes 4&5 first (swap via D).  \nBecause the control photon remains unmeasured and both paths are coherently recombined, the order of the two swap\u2010modules is placed in superposition. Conditioned on a single \u201cheralding\u2010click\u201d in a designated ancilla detector subset (e.g. D2), the two unmeasured output modes corresponding to A and B collapse into an entangled state. Crucially, A\u2013B becomes entangled by a pathway that is in an indefinite causal order\u2014an equal superposition of \u201cswap via C then D\u201d and \u201cswap via D then C.\u201d\n\nThis realizes a new network primitive: superposed\u2010order entanglement swapping (a photonic quantum SWITCH applied to Bell\u2010measurements), directly coupling Rydberg\u2010memory nodes in a way no prior static device has done.\n\nexample config skeleton:\n{\n  description:      'Q\u2010SWITCH entanglement swap between A,B via C,D',\n  foldername:       'RydQSwitchSwap',\n  single_emitters: Initially two Bell pairs are shared:\n \u2022 Pair 1: A\u2013B \u2192 photons in modes 0 & 1  \n \u2022 Pair 2: C\u2013D \u2192 photons in modes 2 & 3  \nA fifth photon (mode 4) serves as a control qubit, prepared in the state (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 by a single\u2010photon emitter.  \nAll five photons enter one static 5\u00d75 linear\u2010optical interferometer (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The five outputs go to detectors D0\u2013D4 (number\u2010resolving).  \n\nLogical operation:\n \u2022 If the control qubit is measured in state |0\u27e9, the interferometer\u2019s projection entangles memories A\u2013D by performing a Bell measurement on modes {1,2}, swapping entanglement from C\u2013D to A\u2013D.  \n \u2022 If the control is |1\u27e9, it instead swaps the A\u2013B link across memories B\u2013C.  \n \u2022 Because the control photon is injected as |+\u27e9, the device realizes a coherent superposition of \u201cswap via BC\u201d and \u201cswap via AD.\u201d  \n\nBy post\u2010selecting on a specific joint click pattern\u2014two clicks on the \u201cswap\u201d detectors (e.g. D1 & D2) plus one click on the control\u2010measurement detector (D4)\u2014the two unmeasured output modes correspond to the entangled memory pair programmed by the control. If the control was in |+\u27e9, the two memories end up entangled in a superposition of two different linkings\u2014a new programmable/superposed network transformation.\n\nexample Pytheus config:\n{\n  description:       'Quantum\u2010controlled entanglement swap',\n  foldername:        'RydQControlSwap',\n  single_emitters:   [0,1,2,3,4],        // modes: A,B,C,D, control\n  amplitudes:        [[0,1],[2,3]],      // Bell\u2010pair sources for A\u2013B and C\u2013D\n  heralding_out:     [1,2,4],            // detectors D1,D2 for swap, D4 for control\u2010measurement\n  target_mapping: {                      // mapping of A,B,C,D control inputs to remaining outputs\n    // condition on control outcome c=0 \u2192 swap A\u2013D; c=1 \u2192 swap B\u2013C\n    'c0': ['AD_Bell'], \n    'c1': ['BC_Bell']\n  },\n  optimizer:         'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:         'cr',\n  edges_tried:       50,\n  tries_per_edge:    10,\n  samples:           30,\n  thresholds:        [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving:  true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 First programmable, quantum\u2010controlled entanglement\u2010swapping device: a single static interferometer whose action\u2014\u201cwhich memories get entangled\u201d\u2014is selected by a control qubit, even in superposition.  \n \u2022 Goes beyond fixed swap/routing: it embeds a quantum \u201cif\u2010then\u201d in the network link, allowing superposed network configurations.  \n \u2022 Directly ties Rydberg\u2010atom memories to advanced network coding and quantum\u2010switch ideas, yet uses only static linear optics and heralding; permuted state:\n     (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A): |\u03c8\u27e9_A\u2297|\u03d5\u27e9_B\u2297|\u03c7\u27e9_C  \u2192  |\u03c7\u27e9_A\u2297|\u03c8\u27e9_B\u2297|\u03d5\u27e9_C  \n   thus They each convert their qubit into a single photon in modes 0 and 1.  A third single\u2010photon emitter (mode 2) supplies an ancilla photon in a fixed reference state.  All three photons enter a single static 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus).  The three outputs go to number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2.  Exactly one click heralds one of two projective outcomes on the two unknown modes:\n\n \u2022 If D0 clicks \u2192 the two memories are projected onto the symmetric subspace (test \u201cequal\u201d)  \n \u2022 If D1 clicks \u2192 the two memories are projected onto the antisymmetric subspace (test \u201cdifferent\u201d)  \n \u2022 Click on D2 \u2192 inconclusive (discard)\n\nThus, in one passive module we implement the SWAP\u2010test between remote Rydberg\u2010qubit memories.\n\nexample Pytheus config:\n{\n  description:      'Nonlocal SWAP\u2010test for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'Rydberg_SWAPTest',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],            // modes: A_unknown, B_unknown, ancilla\n  heralding_out:    [0,1],              // D0 \u2192 symmetric; D1 \u2192 antisymmetric\n  target_quantum:   [                      // projector on modes 0&1\n    D0: ['symm'],    D1: ['antisymm']\n  ],\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      20,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Fundamental network operation: direct quantum\u2010state comparison (SWAP\u2010test) across remote memories, not mere entanglement distribution.  \n \u2022 Building block for quantum\u2010fingerprinting, signature verification, and distributed consensus protocols.  \n \u2022 Fully static, heralded linear-optics module\u2014exactly Pytheus\u2019s domain\u2014with clear generalizations to multi-memory comparison networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates standard two\u2010qubit SWAP\u2010test constructions already found in the literature and the ensemble (e.g. generalized multi\u2010copy SWAP tests). It uses exactly what Pytheus can do (single-photon emitters for unknown qubits, Bell-pair sources, static linear optics, number-resolving detectors, no dynamic feedback).\n\n  Step 3: Chosen Idea: the N\u2192M Multiplexed Teleportation Switch.\n\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    \u2022 No prior linear-optical design has realized a single static device that, upon heralding distinct click patterns, teleports one of N unknown qubits to one of M chosen receivers on demand.  \n    \u2022 This \u201cquantum switchboard\u201d is a new primitive for quantum networks\u2014an on-demand teleportation multiplexer.\n\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2022 Inputs: N single_emitter modes (unknown qubits from Rydberg array) + M photonic Bell-pair sources connecting the central station to each receiver node.  \n    \u2022 A single (N+2M)\u00d7(N+2M) static interferometer\u2014beam splitters & phase shifters.  \n    \u2022 (N+2M) number-resolving detectors.  \n    \u2022 Heralding_out patterns indexed by (sender i, receiver j) map unknown mode i to output port j.  \n    \u2022 Uses only abstract photonic modes, static linear optics, and heralding detectors\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s remit.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cMultiplexed Teleportation Switchboard for Rydberg Memories\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have N Rydberg-atom memory nodes A\u2081,\u2026,A_N holding unknown qubits |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9,\u2026,|\u03c8_N\u27e9 and M receiver nodes R\u2081,\u2026,R_M.  Our goal is: in one static device, teleport any one chosen unknown state |\u03c8_i\u27e9 from A_i to any chosen receiver R_j on demand\u2014by simply postselecting on the heralding detector pattern (i,j), without reconfiguring optics.\n\nSetup:\n 1. Each sender A_i emits its unknown qubit as a single photon (modes 0\u2026N-1).  \n 2. The central station Z prepares M photonic Bell-pairs: for each receiver R_j, modes (N+2j\u22122, N+2j\u22121) form an abstract |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 pair.  \n 3. All N + 2M photons enter one fixed (N+2M)\u00d7(N+2M) linear-optical interferometer (beam splitters & phases)\u2014to be optimized by Pytheus.  \n 4. The (N+2M) output modes are monitored by number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D_{N+2M\u22121}.  \n 5. For each pair (i,j), there is a unique heralding_out pattern\u2014a specified set of M+1 detector clicks\u2014that projects the remaining unclicked output mode at R_j onto the state |\u03c8_i\u27e9.  All other outputs and detectors herald the transfer.\n\nBy running Pytheus with heralding_out arrays corresponding to each (i,j), one recovers a single static interferometer whose multiple click-patterns implement teleportation from any sender to any receiver on demand.\n\nexample config for N=3 senders, M=2 receivers (total modes=7):\n{\n  description:      '3\u21922 teleportation switchboard',\n  foldername:       'Ryd_Tele_Switch3to2',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],           // unknown qubit modes from A\u2081,A\u2082,A\u2083\n  amplitudes:       [[3,4],[5,6]],     // two Bell pairs connecting Z\u21c4R\u2081 and Z\u21c4R\u2082\n  in_nodes:         [],\n  out_nodes:        [],\n  heralding_out:    [],                // to be filled with detector sets for each (i,j)\n  target_mapping: {                     // for each (i,j) pattern, map mode i\u2192receiver j\n    '(i,j)': '\u03c8_i appears at output port for R_j'\n  },\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      50,\n  tries_per_edge:   10,\n  samples:          20,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Introduces the first on-demand teleportation multiplexer (\u201cswitchboard\u201d) for quantum memories\u2014an essential primitive for flexible quantum-internet routing.  \n \u2022 Directly ties Rydberg atomic memories to a static linear-optical network that handles unknown states, showing how to multiplex teleportation paths in one device.  \n \u2022 Generalizes immediately to any N\u2192M configuration\u2014stamp out a family of experiments and performance studies.  \n \u2022 Fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: only abstract modes, linear optics, single-photon emitters, Bell-pair sources, number-resolving detectors\u2014no dynamic feedback or forbidden elements.\n\nThis target challenges Pytheus to find the minimal interferometer and heralding scheme that multiplexes teleportation among any chosen pair of nodes in an atomic array\u2014a new frontier in photonic quantum-network design."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nHeralded Linear\u2010Optical 1\u21922 QuTrIt Telecloning via Resonance-Dip Multiport Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose and analyze a fully linear-optical implementation of the first 1\u21922 qutrit telecloner, in which three probabilistic qutrit-entangled photon-pair sources feed a balanced three-mode multiport Bell measurement module synchronized by identical delay-loop \u201cresonators.\u201d Success of the telecloning is unambiguously heralded by a generalized Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel resonance dip in triple-coincidence ancilla detections, conditionally projecting the two receivers into the optimal symmetric clones of the unknown input qutrit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a target PyTheus-compatible linear-optical network in which two classical users, Alice and Bob, each send Z-basis single photons to a fully quantum node, Charlie, who entangles them with his ancilla Bell pair and performs post-selected entanglement-swapping to nonlocally compute their parity x\u2295y as a shared key bit. The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the target I suggest for Pytheus:\n\nDescription:\n Design a fixed linear\u2010optical \u201centanglement router\u201d that passively connects any two chosen nodes of a small Rydberg\u2010atom array network, purely by heralding on which ancilla detectors click.  Physically, each of the N array nodes (e.g. N=3 or 4 for demonstration) holds a Rydberg atomic qubit whose excitation can be converted into a single photon.  We assume that each node emits one photon entangled with its atomic memory (an abstract photonic mode).  All N photons enter a single N-port interferometer network, mix via beam splitters and phase shifters, and exit at output ports monitored by ancilla photon-number-resolving detectors.  Different click patterns at these ancilla detectors herald a Bell\u2010pair between exactly two of the memory qubits\u2014thereby routing entanglement on demand, without reconfiguring optics.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Generalizes entanglement swapping to a fully passive, reconfigurable router.  \n \u2022 Enables multiplexed, on-demand Bell\u2010links across any pair of atomic memory nodes.  \n \u2022 Lays groundwork for scalable quantum\u2010network switches and network\u2010coding primitives in Rydberg-based quantum repeaters or quantum internet nodes.\n\nKey Pytheus configuration elements (expert to flesh out):\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0,\u2026,N\u20131]  (one photon per memory node)  \n \u2022 a single multiport network (to be optimized) with N inputs \u2192 M outputs (M\u2265N)  \n \u2022 ancilla detectors on M\u20132 ports, leaving 2 \u201cmemory\u2010link\u201d output ports free  \n \u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct two-photon collisions between non-chosen node pairs if desired  \n \u2022 target_quantum: a set of Bell states on every 2-node subset; optimize so that each ancilla\u2010click pattern projects the remaining two output modes onto |00>+|11>  \n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the minimal multiport interferometer and detector arrangement that, upon heralding, routes entanglement between arbitrary node pairs\u2014an architecture-level quantum\u2010network primitive novel to the linear\u2010optical toolbox.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed static multiport interferometer that passively heralds entanglement between any two of N quantum\u2010memory nodes is essentially the same \u201cmultiplexed entanglement router\u201d primitive already in the ensemble (\u201cA Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\u201d). Both rely on N emitters feeding a fixed interferometer and ancilla\u2010click heralds to select which two nodes share a Bell pair, differing only in physical platform (Rydberg vs. plasmonic waveguides). Because the core routing mechanism and target transformation are identical, this idea lacks sufficient novelty over existing suggestions.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router\u201d proposal. To be novel, you would need a fundamentally new routing mechanism (e.g. non-heralded, multi-stage network coding, coherent superposition of multiple routes, or indefinite causal order) rather than just changing the emitter technology.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cRydberg Entanglement Router (3-node)\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have a small Rydberg\u2010atom array of three memory nodes A, B, C. Each node coherently converts its atomic excitation into one photon (abstract mode 0,1,2). These three photons enter a single 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus). The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Whenever exactly one detector Di clicks, the remaining two (unclicked) output modes are projected into a two-qubit Bell state |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of Rydberg memories. Thus:\n \u2022 D0 click \u2192 entangles B&C  \n \u2022 D1 click \u2192 entangles A&C  \n \u2022 D2 click \u2192 entangles A&B  \n\nThis is a passive, heralded entanglement router: by post-selecting on which detector fires, we choose which pair of memories becomes entangled, without reconfiguring the optics.\n\nconfig (example for heralding D2 \u2192 entangle A&B):\n{'description':'Passive 3-node entanglement router for Rydberg memories','foldername':'RydbergRouter3','single_emitters':[0,1,2],'num_anc':1,'heralding_out':[2],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'in_nodes':[],'out_nodes':[],'anc_detectors':[],'removed_connections':[],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':30,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':10,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo cover all three routing patterns, one simply repeats the optimization with heralding_out=[0] and heralding_out=[1]: each run yields the same static interferometer but different herald-detector assignment projects onto the desired Bell link. This architecture scales to N nodes via an N\u00d7N multiport and N single-photon sources.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed 3-node \u201cRydberg Entanglement Router\u201d implements exactly the same passive, heralded routing primitive as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides,\u201d merely swapping in Rydberg emitters. Because the core transformation (N emitters \u2192 static N\u00d7N interferometer \u2192 heralded two-node Bell pair) and network-switch functionality are identical, this offers no new conceptual twist beyond what\u2019s already in the literature.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This target is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router\u201d proposal. To achieve genuine novelty, you\u2019d need a fundamentally different routing mechanism\u2014e.g. coherent superposition of multiple routing paths, indefinite causal-order switching, or an adaptive, multi-stage network-coding primitive\u2014rather than a one-for-one swap of emitter technology.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201c4-Node Quantum Percolation Switch for Rydberg Arrays\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have four Rydberg\u2010atom memory nodes A, B, C, D. Each node emits one photon (modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter a single 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized). The outputs go to four photon-number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the remaining two unclicked output modes are projected into the Bell state |00>+|11> of the corresponding two memories. Different click-pairs activate different network links:\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangles C&D (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangles B&D (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangles A&C (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangles A&B (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangles B&C (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangles A&D (diagonal AD)  \n\nconfig (example for heralding clicks {0,1} \u2192 entangle C&D):\n{'description':'4-node percolation switch','foldername':'RydbergPercolation4','single_emitters':[0,1,2,3],'num_anc':0,'heralding_out':[0,1],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':40,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':20,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo generate the full percolation cell, one runs six optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair. The result is one static 4\u00d74 network whose various two-click patterns switch on any desired Bell\u2010link among the four Rydberg memories. This device is the building block for testing entanglement percolation, network coding, and dynamic rerouting in quantum repeater networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The 4\u2010node \u201cpercolation switch\u201d is essentially the same passive, heralded entanglement\u2010routing primitive already proposed in the ensemble (\u201cQuantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\u201d and related entanglement\u2010percolation schemes). Merely extending from N=3 to N=4 and using two\u2010click patterns to select one of six edges does not introduce a fundamentally new routing mechanism or network capability. Action: reject  \nAction Input: This proposal duplicates the core idea of a fixed interferometer with heralded detector clicks selecting which two memories share a Bell pair. To be truly novel, you need a qualitatively different element\u2014e.g. coherent superposition of multiple linkings, indefinite causal\u2010order routing, or an adaptive multi\u2010stage network coding primitive\u2014rather than a straightforward N\u21924 scaling of the same router concept.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the new target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cButterfly A different heralding pattern implements the alternate routing (A\u2192C, B\u2192D).\n\nconfig example (for heralding pattern routing A\u2192D, B\u2192C):\n{\n  description:      'Butterfly map for computational basis\n    '00'-> output at (D,C) = '00',\n    '01'->                  '10',\n    '10'->                  '01',\n    '11'->                  '11'\n  },\n  optimizer: Each converts its memory excitation into one single photon (abstract modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter one static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the two unclicked output modes collapse into a Bell pair |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of memories. By post-selecting on different click-pairs, one \u201cactivates\u201d any of the six possible links in the square:\n\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D  (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangle B\u2013D  (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013C  (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013B  (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangle B\u2013C  (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangle A\u2013D  (diagonal AD)\n\nThis single device realizes all six entanglement-swapping channels in one static interferometer, enabling studies of entanglement percolation, network-coding primitives, and dynamic connectivity in a minimal four-node cell.\n\nexample config (for heralding {0,1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D):\n{\n  description:      '4-node percolation switch',\n  foldername:       'RydbergPercolation4',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],        // A,B,C,D emitters\n  num_anc:          0,\n  heralding_out:    [0,1],            // detectors Di,Dj that click\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],       // Bell basis on the remaining modes\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          20,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nOne runs six separate Pytheus optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair\u2014to recover a single 4\u00d74 network whose various two-click patterns select any desired Bell link. This constitutes a novel, expandable building block for quantum repeater networks and percolation studies, fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optics framework.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The 4-node \u201cpercolation switch\u201d is effectively the same static interferometer plus heralded\u2010click routing primitive for selecting which two memories share a Bell pair that already appears in the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router\u201d and related percolation proposals. Each node converts its two local memories into photons: A produces modes 0,1 (imperfect pair a\u2081\u2013b\u2081), and B produces modes 2,3 (imperfect pair a\u2082\u2013b\u2082). All four photons enter a single static 4\u00d74 linear-optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus). The four outputs go to four number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Upon obtaining clicks on detectors {D2,D3} (the \u201cancilla\u201d measurement), the unmeasured output modes (D0,D1) collapse into a purified high-fidelity Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between the two Rydberg memories at A and B. This implements one round of the BBPSSW entanglement-distillation protocol in a single passive module\u2014no dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, only static linear optics and heralding. By cascading or interconnecting multiple such modules, one can build multi-stage purification chains for long-distance quantum repeater networks.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3} \u2192 purified A\u2013B Bell pair):\n{\n  description:      'Entanglement purification for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydPurification2',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],       // modes from A:a1,a2 and B:b1,b2\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],           // detectors D2,D3 clicks herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],      // purified Bell basis on modes 0,1\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      30,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Introduces the first static, heralded entanglement-distillation primitive for Rydberg-atom quantum memories in a single module.  \n \u2022 Moves beyond point-to-point swapping: it cleans noisy links, a vital network primitive toward scalable repeaters.  \n \u2022 Fully generalizable to multi-stage purification chains and to higher dimensions by extending the network size and detection patterns.\n\nThis target leverages Pytheus\u2019s strength\u2014optimizing static linear-optical networks with single-photon sources and heralding detectors\u2014to discover minimal purification circuits, forging a new building block for quantum-network protocols.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed \u201cEntanglement Purification Module\u201d is essentially the same one\u2010shot, static linear\u2010optical distillation Each memory\u2019s qubit is converted into one photon (abstract modes 0 and 1) that carries its Z\u2010basis information. We also introduce one ancillary single\u2010photon emitter (mode 2) to mediate the joint measurement. All three photons enter a single static 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The three output modes are monitored by number\u2010resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Depending on which detector clicks (exactly one click), the two Rydberg memories collapse into one of the two Z\u2297Z parity subspaces:\n\n \u2022 If Di clicks with i\u2208{0,1}, the memories are projected onto the even\u2010parity Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 (heralded by detector patterns {0} or {1}).  \n \u2022 If D2 clicks, the memories are projected onto the odd\u2010parity Bell state |01\u27e9+|10\u27e9 (heralded by {2}).\n\nThis realizes a non\u2010destructive, heralded remote Z\u2297Z parity check between two atomic qubits in one static module\u2014an essential building block for distributed error syndrome extraction and measurement\u2010based network protocols.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding Di\u2192even or odd parity):\n{\n  description:      'Heralded parity measurement for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydParityMeas',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],         // modes from A, B, and ancilla\n  heralding_out:    [i],             // i=0 or 1 \u2192 even parity; i=2 \u2192 odd parity\n  target_quantum:   (i<2 ? ['00','11'] : ['01','10']),\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      20,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 A joint nonlocal parity measurement is a key network transform\u2014beyond swapping or teleportation\u2014that underpins entanglement purification, error syndrome extraction, and measurement\u2010based repeater protocols.  \n \u2022 We deploy only static linear optics, three single\u2010photon emitters, and heralding detectors\u2014perfectly within Pytheus\u2019s remit.  \n \u2022 The concept generalizes immediately to N\u2010qubit stabilizer checks (e.g. 4\u2010mode network for X\u2297X\u2297Z\u2297Z) by adding ancilla emitters and detectors.  \n \u2022 This primitive opens new avenues for distributed quantum error correction and measurement\u2010based quantum networking with Rydberg\u2010memory nodes.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This scheme is essentially a two\u2010qubit Z\u2297Z parity projector implemented by a fixed 3\u00d73 interferometer and a single ancilla photon, which collapses two atomic memories into the even\u2010 or odd\u2010parity Bell subspace based on one-click heralding. However, the ensemble has already proposed a nonlocal parity gate (\u201cExperimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\u201d) that uses static linear optics and post-selected ancilla measurements to compute x\u2295y and project onto even/odd parity. Swapping in Rydberg memories and trading a Bell-pair ancilla for one single photon does not introduce a fundamentally new network transform or mechanism.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The core parity\u2010measurement primitive duplicates the previously suggested nonlocal parity gate. Each memory is converted on demand into a single photon in modes 0 and 1. We also prepare one photonic Bell pair (ancilla) in modes 2 & 3 (abstractly |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9). All four photons enter a single static 4\u00d74 linear-optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Conditioned on a specific two-click heralding pattern (e.g. clicks on D2 & D3), the two photonic inputs from A and B emerge (in the remaining unclicked outputs) having undergone a CZ gate:\n\n  CZ : |x,y\u27e9 \u2192 (\u20131)^{x\u00b7y} |x,y\u27e9 \n\nThus the unknown memory qubits are teleported back to A and B with the CZ applied between them. No dynamic control is needed\u2014just static optics and heralding.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3}):\n{\n  description:      'Heralded tele-CZ gate for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydTeleCZ',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],           // modes: A_photon, B_photon, ancilla pair\n  amplitudes:       [[2,3]],             // one Bell-pair source on modes 2&3\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],               // clicks on detectors D2 & D3 herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00->00','01->01','10->10','11->-11'], // ideal CZ mapping\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          15,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Implements a nonlocal two-qubit CZ gate between remote Rydberg memories in one static linear\u2010optical device.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to multi-gate, graph-state fusion modules by adding ancilla Bell pairs and extending the interferometer.  \n \u2022 A centerpiece for distributed quantum computing and repeater protocols that require remote entangling gates, not just swapping. Pytheus to discover the minimal interferometer and detection scheme that, via post-selection, teleports a CZ between two atomic memories\u2014opening a new primitive for quantum networks and distributed processing.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The
