Pytheus to discover the minimal interferometer and detection scheme that, via post-selection, teleports a CZ between two atomic memories\u2014opening a new primitive for quantum networks and distributed processing.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The Instead of a single entanglement\u2010swap station, there are two ancilla memories C and D, each initially sharing a Bell pair with A and B respectively:\n \u2022 Bell pair A\u2013C in photonic modes 2&3  \n \u2022 Bell pair B\u2013D in photonic modes 4&5  \nWe also introduce one control photon (mode 6), prepared in an equal superposition of two path\u2010labels |c1\u27e9+|c2\u27e9. All seven photons enter a single static 7\u00d77 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. At the output, seven number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D6 monitor every mode.\n\nThe network is arranged so that:\n \u2022 If the control lives in path c1, the interferometer implements a Bell measurement on modes 2&3 first (swap via C),  \n \u2022 If it lives in path c2, it implements the Bell measurement on modes 4&5 first (swap via D).  \nBecause the control photon remains unmeasured and both paths are coherently recombined, the order of the two swap\u2010modules is placed in superposition. Conditioned on a single \u201cheralding\u2010click\u201d in a designated ancilla detector subset (e.g. D2), the two unmeasured output modes corresponding to A and B collapse into an entangled state. Crucially, A\u2013B becomes entangled by a pathway that is in an indefinite causal order\u2014an equal superposition of \u201cswap via C then D\u201d and \u201cswap via D then C.\u201d\n\nThis realizes a new network primitive: superposed\u2010order entanglement swapping (a photonic quantum SWITCH applied to Bell\u2010measurements), directly coupling Rydberg\u2010memory nodes in a way no prior static device has done.\n\nexample config skeleton:\n{\n  description:      'Q\u2010SWITCH entanglement swap between A,B via C,D',\n  foldername:       'RydQSwitchSwap',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,6],             // modes A, B, control\n  amplitudes:       [[2,3],[4,5]],       // two Bell\u2010pair sources: A\u2013C, B\u2013D\n  heralding_out:    [2],                  // e.g. click on detector D2 heralds success\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],          // AB in Bell basis on unmeasured modes\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      50,\n  tries_per_edge:   10,\n  samples:          30,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 First static\u2010optical realization of a quantum SWITCH on entanglement\u2010swapping modules\u2014placing the order of two Bell measurements in superposition.  \n \u2022 Goes beyond \u201centanglement router\u201d or \u201cpercolation switch\u201d: it introduces indefinite causal structure into a basic quantum\u2010network link operation.  \n \u2022 Directly uses Rydberg\u2010memory nodes as the endpoints and purely photonic ancillas and static optics\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to N\u2010swap superpositions, larger networks, and studies of causal order in entanglement distribution.\n\nThis invites Pytheus to discover the minimal 7\u00d77 interferometer and detection scheme that, via post\u2010selection, implements a superposed\u2010order entanglement swap between two remote atomic memories\u2014a brand\u2010new quantum\u2010network primitive.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you Initially two Bell pairs are shared:\n \u2022 Pair 1: A\u2013B \u2192 photons in modes 0 & 1  \n \u2022 Pair 2: C\u2013D \u2192 photons in modes 2 & 3  \nA fifth photon (mode 4) serves as a control qubit, prepared in the state (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 by a single\u2010photon emitter.  \nAll five photons enter one static 5\u00d75 linear\u2010optical interferometer (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The five outputs go to detectors D0\u2013D4 (number\u2010resolving).  \n\nLogical operation:\n \u2022 If the control qubit is measured in state |0\u27e9, the interferometer\u2019s projection entangles memories A\u2013D by performing a Bell measurement on modes {1,2}, swapping entanglement from C\u2013D to A\u2013D.  \n \u2022 If the control is |1\u27e9, it instead swaps the A\u2013B link across memories B\u2013C.  \n \u2022 Because the control photon is injected as |+\u27e9, the device realizes a coherent superposition of \u201cswap via BC\u201d and \u201cswap via AD.\u201d  \n\nBy post\u2010selecting on a specific joint click pattern\u2014two clicks on the \u201cswap\u201d detectors (e.g. D1 & D2) plus one click on the control\u2010measurement detector (D4)\u2014the two unmeasured output modes correspond to the entangled memory pair programmed by the control. If the control was in |+\u27e9, the two memories end up entangled in a superposition of two different linkings\u2014a new programmable/superposed network transformation.\n\nexample Pytheus config:\n{\n  description:       'Quantum\u2010controlled entanglement swap',\n  foldername:        'RydQControlSwap',\n  single_emitters:   [0,1,2,3,4],        // modes: A,B,C,D, control\n  amplitudes:        [[0,1],[2,3]],      // Bell\u2010pair sources for A\u2013B and C\u2013D\n  heralding_out:     [1,2,4],            // detectors D1,D2 for swap, D4 for control\u2010measurement\n  target_mapping: {                      // mapping of A,B,C,D control inputs to remaining outputs\n    // condition on control outcome c=0 \u2192 swap A\u2013D; c=1 \u2192 swap B\u2013C\n    'c0': ['AD_Bell'], \n    'c1': ['BC_Bell']\n  },\n  optimizer:         'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:         'cr',\n  edges_tried:       50,\n  tries_per_edge:    10,\n  samples:           30,\n  thresholds:        [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving:  true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 First programmable, quantum\u2010controlled entanglement\u2010swapping device: a single static interferometer whose action\u2014\u201cwhich memories get entangled\u201d\u2014is selected by a control qubit, even in superposition.  \n \u2022 Goes beyond fixed swap/routing: it embeds a quantum \u201cif\u2010then\u201d in the network link, allowing superposed network configurations.  \n \u2022 Directly ties Rydberg\u2010atom memories to advanced network coding and quantum\u2010switch ideas, yet uses only static linear optics and heralding; fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \n \u2022 Generalizable to N memories and multi\u2010control photons for richer programmable network fabrics.\n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the minimal 5\u00d75 interferometer and detector arrangement that, via post\u2010selection, implements a quantum\u2010controlled entanglement\u2010swapping gate between atomic memories\u2014a new quantum\u2010network primitive.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While embedding a control qubit to choose which pair of memories to entangle sounds appealing, this \u201cquantum-controlled entanglement swap\u201d is essentially the same static, heralded routing/swap\u2010switch primitive already in our ensemble (e.g. the \u201cEntanglement-Switch Quantum Switch\u201d and \u201cDual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch\u201d). Memories A, B, C are each converted into single photons in modes 0, 1, 2 respectively.  \n2. A central station Z generates three Bell pairs (ancillas):\n   \u2022 Pair Z1: modes 3 & 4  \n   \u2022 Pair Z2: modes 5 & 6  \n   \u2022 Pair Z3: modes 7 & 8  \n3. All nine photons (modes 0\u20138) enter one static 9\u00d79 linear-optical interferometer (beam splitters & phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus.  \n4. The nine output modes are measured by nine photon-number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D8.  \n5. When exactly six detectors corresponding to the three Bell measurements (e.g. clicks on {D3,D4,D5,D6,D7,D8}) click, the three unmeasured outputs (from modes 0\u20132) collapse into the cyclically permuted state:\n     (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A): |\u03c8\u27e9_A\u2297|\u03d5\u27e9_B\u2297|\u03c7\u27e9_C  \u2192  |\u03c7\u27e9_A\u2297|\u03c8\u27e9_B\u2297|\u03d5\u27e9_C  \n   thus implementing the 3-cycle unitary U_cycle: |abc\u27e9 \u2192 |cab\u27e9 in one shot.\n\nThis realizes a new network\u2010primitive: a teleportation ring that shifts three quantum states around a triangle of memories in a single passive, heralded linear-optical device.\n\nexample Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:      '3-party teleportation ring (cyclic permutation)',\n  foldername:       'RydTeleportRing3',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],            // modes from A,B,C unknown qubits\n  amplitudes:       [[3,4],[5,6],[7,8]],// three Bell-pair sources at Z\n  in_nodes:         [],\n  out_nodes:        [],\n  heralding_out:    [3,4,5,6,7,8],      // six detectors for the three Bell measurements\n  target_mapping: {                       // mapping for computational basis strings\n    'abc'->'cab' for all a,b,c\u2208{0,1}\n  },\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      80,\n  tries_per_edge:   10,\n  samples:          40,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Implements the cyclic shift unitary on three unknown qubits via simultaneous teleportations in one static device, a network transformation beyond pairwise swapping.  \n \u2022 Opens the door to programmable cyclic routing and higher\u2010order permutation codes for N-node quantum networks.  \n \u2022 Fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, heralded, static\u2010network paradigm\u2014no feedback, no cavities, no state-generation tails.  \n \u2022 Directly ties Rydberg atomic memories into a novel multi-party teleportation architecture, independent of its eventual physical realization.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The \u201cTeleportation Ring\u201d cyclic 3-party permutation is exactly the three-qubit cyclic SWAP (ring-exchange) They each convert their qubit into a single photon in modes 0 and 1.  A third single\u2010photon emitter (mode 2) supplies an ancilla photon in a fixed reference state.  All three photons enter a single static 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus).  The three outputs go to number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2.  Exactly one click heralds one of two projective outcomes on the two unknown modes:\n\n \u2022 If D0 clicks \u2192 the two memories are projected onto the symmetric subspace (test \u201cequal\u201d)  \n \u2022 If D1 clicks \u2192 the two memories are projected onto the antisymmetric subspace (test \u201cdifferent\u201d)  \n \u2022 Click on D2 \u2192 inconclusive (discard)\n\nThus, in one passive module we implement the SWAP\u2010test between remote Rydberg\u2010qubit memories.\n\nexample Pytheus config:\n{\n  description:      'Nonlocal SWAP\u2010test for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'Rydberg_SWAPTest',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],            // modes: A_unknown, B_unknown, ancilla\n  heralding_out:    [0,1],              // D0 \u2192 symmetric; D1 \u2192 antisymmetric\n  target_quantum:   [                      // projector on modes 0&1\n    D0: ['symm'],    D1: ['antisymm']\n  ],\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      20,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Fundamental network operation: direct quantum\u2010state comparison (SWAP\u2010test) across remote memories, not mere entanglement distribution.  \n \u2022 Building block for quantum\u2010fingerprinting, signature verification, and distributed consensus protocols.  \n \u2022 Fully static, heralded linear-optics module\u2014exactly Pytheus\u2019s domain\u2014with clear generalizations to multi-memory comparison networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While implementing a remote SWAP\u2010test between two Rydberg\u2010memory qubits via a static 3\u00d73 interferometer and single\u2010photon ancilla is a straightforward extension of existing SWAP\u2010test ideas (e.g. multi\u2010copy SWAP testers and Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel\u2013based two\u2010qubit tests in the ensemble), it does not introduce any fundamentally new network primitive\u2014merely swaps out the physical memory platform. The basic nonlocal SWAP\u2010test is well\u2010known and already appears in multiple ensemble proposals.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This duplicates standard two\u2010qubit SWAP\u2010test constructions already found in the literature and the ensemble (e.g. generalized multi\u2010copy SWAP tests). To be novel, you need a qualitatively new comparison primitive (e.g. multi\u2010party SWAP metrics, indefinite\u2010order SWAP tests, or programmable multi\u2010register comparisons) rather than a direct platform swap of an existing SWAP\u2010test module.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cMultiplexed Teleportation Switchboard for Rydberg Memories\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have N Rydberg-atom memory nodes A\u2081,\u2026,A_N holding unknown qubits |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9,\u2026,|\u03c8_N\u27e9 and M receiver nodes R\u2081,\u2026,R_M.  Our goal is: in one static device, teleport any one chosen unknown state |\u03c8_i\u27e9 from A_i to any chosen receiver R_j on demand\u2014by simply postselecting on the heralding detector pattern (i,j), without reconfiguring optics.\n\nSetup:\n 1. Each sender A_i emits its unknown qubit as a single photon (modes 0\u2026N-1).  \n 2. The central station Z prepares M photonic Bell-pairs: for each receiver R_j, modes (N+2j\u22122, N+2j\u22121) form an abstract |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 pair.  \n 3. All N + 2M photons enter one fixed (N+2M)\u00d7(N+2M) linear-optical interferometer (beam splitters & phases)\u2014to be optimized by Pytheus.  \n 4. The (N+2M) output modes are monitored by number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D_{N+2M\u22121}.  \n 5. For each pair (i,j), there is a unique heralding_out pattern\u2014a specified set of M+1 detector clicks\u2014that projects the remaining unclicked output mode at R_j onto the state |\u03c8_i\u27e9.  All other outputs and detectors herald the transfer.\n\nBy running Pytheus with heralding_out arrays corresponding to each (i,j), one recovers a single static interferometer whose multiple click-patterns implement teleportation from any sender to any receiver on demand.\n\nexample config for N=3 senders, M=2 receivers (total modes=7):\n{\n  description:      '3\u21922 teleportation switchboard',\n  foldername:       'Ryd_Tele_Switch3to2',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],           // unknown qubit modes from A\u2081,A\u2082,A\u2083\n  amplitudes:       [[3,4],[5,6]],     // two Bell pairs connecting Z\u21c4R\u2081 and Z\u21c4R\u2082\n  in_nodes:         [],\n  out_nodes:        [],\n  heralding_out:    [],                // to be filled with detector sets for each (i,j)\n  target_mapping: {                     // for each (i,j) pattern, map mode i\u2192receiver j\n    '(i,j)': '\u03c8_i appears at output port for R_j'\n  },\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      50,\n  tries_per_edge:   10,\n  samples:          20,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Introduces the first on-demand teleportation multiplexer (\u201cswitchboard\u201d) for quantum memories\u2014an essential primitive for flexible quantum-internet routing.  \n \u2022 Directly ties Rydberg atomic memories to a static linear-optical network that handles unknown states, showing how to multiplex teleportation paths in one device.  \n \u2022 Generalizes immediately to any N\u2192M configuration\u2014stamp out a family of experiments and performance studies.  \n \u2022 Fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: only abstract modes, linear optics, single-photon emitters, Bell-pair sources, number-resolving detectors\u2014no dynamic feedback or forbidden elements.\n\nThis target challenges Pytheus to find the minimal interferometer and heralding scheme that multiplexes teleportation among any chosen pair of nodes in an atomic array\u2014a new frontier in photonic quantum-network design.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While multiplexed teleportation is a useful primitive, this \u201cswitchboard\u201d is essentially the same routing/teleportation\u2010multiplexing concept already proposed in the ensemble (e.g. the dual\u2010destination teleportation switch and entanglement routers), merely extended to arbitrary N\u2192M. There\u2019s no new mechanism\u2014just scaling the mode count\u2014so it falls short of a novel network primitive for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is a straightforward N\u2192M generalization of the dual\u2010destination teleportation switch and entanglement\u2010router ideas. To be novel, propose a genuinely new routing mechanism (e.g. coherent superposition of multiple teleportation paths, indefinite causal\u2010order multiplexing, or adaptive multi\u2010stage network coding) rather than scaling up the existing passive heralded-teleportation design.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cHeralded 1\u21922 Universal Tele-Cloner for Rydberg Memories\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have three Rydberg\u2010atom memory nodes A, B, C.  \n \u2022 A holds an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9_A, which it converts into a single photon in mode 0.  \n \u2022 B and C are \u201cblank\u201d memories; each supplies one ancilla photon prepared in the known state |0\u27e9 (modes 1 and 2).  \nAll three photons enter one static 3\u00d73 linear-optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters), which Pytheus will optimize. The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Whenever exactly one heralding click occurs on detector D2, the two unclicked output modes (mapped back to memories B and C) collapse into the two optimal approximate clones of |\u03c8\u27e9_A with fidelity 5/6 (the universal cloning bound). A click on D0 or D1 indicates failure (discard).\n\nThis device implements the universal 1\u21922 cloning channel by passive linear optics and post-selection:\n\n   |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080\u2297|00\u27e9\u2081\u2082  \u2192 (herald D2) \u2192  2/3|\u03c8\u03c8\u27e9 + (1/6)(|\u03c8 \u03c8_\u22a5\u27e9+|\u03c8_\u22a5 \u03c8\u27e9)\n\non modes mapped to B and C, the two clones.  \n\nexample Pytheus config stub:\n{\n  description:      'Heralded 1\u21922 universal tele-cloner for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydUQCM_1to2',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],            // mode 0: unknown qubit; modes 1,2: ancilla blanks\n  heralding_out:    [2],                // click on D2 heralds successful cloning\n  target_quantum:   [                     // target mapping on modes 0,1 \u2192 clones in modes B,C\n    '000'-> ['200','020','002']  // shorthand: map input basis to the 3-photon output superposition for optimal clones\n    // Pytheus will expand this into the exact 5/6 & 1/6 amplitude pattern \n  ],\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      20,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Universal tele-cloning is a key multiparty channel\u2014producing two approximate copies of an unknown qubit\u2014that goes beyond swapping or routing.  \n \u2022 It is the first passive linear-optical \u201ctele-cloner\u201d linking Rydberg memories: one unknown input, two blank ancillas, and heralding detectors realize the optimal 1\u21922 cloning map.  \n \u2022 Generalizes immediately to N\u2192M tele-cloners by adding ancilla photons and scaling the interferometer\u2014yielding a whole new class of quantum-network primitives.  \n \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: uses only abstract photonic modes, single-photon sources, static beam splitters & phases, and number-resolving detectors\u2014no dynamic feedback, cavities, or hyper-entanglement. \n\nThis target challenges Pytheus to find the minimal 3\u00d73 interferometer and detection scheme that enacts the universal cloning channel by post-selection\u2014a novel building block for quantum-network coding, distributed sensing, and multi-party quantum information protocols.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposed 1\u21922 universal tele-cloner is functionally identical to linear-optical telecloning modules already in the ensemble (e.g. the \u201cHeralded Linear-Optical 1\u21922 Telecloning via Lossy Quantum Memories\u201d) and standard universal-cloner constructions. Simply swapping in Rydberg memories and using a 3\u00d73 static interferometer does not introduce a new network primitive or mechanism beyond what\u2019s already been explored.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This duplicates the ensemble\u2019s qubit telecloning targets. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"rydberg atom array\" and \"entangled quantum state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. We assume that each node emits one photon entangled with its atomic memory (an abstract photonic mode).  All N photons enter a single N-port interferometer network, mix via beam splitters and phase shifters, and exit at output ports monitored by ancilla photon-number-resolving detectors. Each node coherently converts its atomic excitation into one photon (abstract mode 0,1,2). These three photons enter a single 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus). The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Whenever exactly one detector Di clicks, the remaining two (unclicked) output modes are projected into a two-qubit Bell state |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of Rydberg memories. Each converts its memory excitation into one single photon (abstract modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter one static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the two unclicked output modes collapse into a Bell pair |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of memories. By post-selecting on different click-pairs, one \u201cactivates\u201d any of the six possible links in the square:\n\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D  (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangle B\u2013D  (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013C  (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013B  (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangle B\u2013C  (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangle A\u2013D  (diagonal AD)\n\nThis single device realizes all six entanglement-swapping channels in one static interferometer, enabling studies of entanglement percolation, network-coding primitives, and dynamic connectivity in a minimal four-node cell.\n\nexample config (for heralding {0,1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D):\n{\n  description:      '4-node percolation switch',\n  foldername:       'RydbergPercolation4',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],        // A,B,C,D emitters\n  num_anc:          0,\n  heralding_out:    [0,1],            // detectors Di,Dj that click\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],       // Bell basis on the remaining modes\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          20,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nOne runs six separate Pytheus optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair\u2014to recover a single 4\u00d74 network whose various two-click patterns select any desired Bell link. Depending on which detector clicks (exactly one click), the two Rydberg memories collapse into one of the two Z\u2297Z parity subspaces:\n\n \u2022 If Di clicks with i\u2208{0,1}, the memories are projected onto the even\u2010parity Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 (heralded by detector patterns {0} or {1}).  \n \u2022 If D2 clicks, the memories are projected onto the odd\u2010parity Bell state |01\u27e9+|10\u27e9 (heralded by {2}).\n\nThis realizes a non\u2010destructive, heralded remote Z\u2297Z parity check between two atomic qubits in one static module\u2014an essential building block for distributed error syndrome extraction and measurement\u2010based network protocols.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding Di\u2192even or odd parity):\n{\n  description:      'Heralded parity measurement for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydParityMeas',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],         // modes from A, B, and ancilla\n  heralding_out:    [i],             // i=0 or 1 \u2192 even parity; i=2 \u2192 odd parity\n  target_quantum:   (i<2 ? ['00','11'] : ['01','10']),\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      20,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 A joint nonlocal parity measurement is a key network transform\u2014beyond swapping or teleportation\u2014that underpins entanglement purification, error syndrome extraction, and measurement\u2010based repeater protocols.  \n \u2022 We deploy only static linear optics, three single\u2010photon emitters, and heralding detectors\u2014perfectly within Pytheus\u2019s remit.  \n \u2022 The concept generalizes immediately to N\u2010qubit stabilizer checks (e.g. 4\u2010mode network for X\u2297X\u2297Z\u2297Z) by adding ancilla emitters and detectors.  \n \u2022 This primitive opens new avenues for distributed quantum error correction and measurement\u2010based quantum networking with Rydberg\u2010memory nodes.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core parity\u2010measurement primitive duplicates the previously suggested nonlocal parity gate. Each memory is converted on demand into a single photon in modes 0 and 1. We also prepare one photonic Bell pair (ancilla) in modes 2 & 3 (abstractly |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9). Conditioned on a specific two-click heralding pattern (e.g. clicks on D2 & D3), the two photonic inputs from A and B emerge (in the remaining unclicked outputs) having undergone a CZ gate:\n\n  CZ : |x,y\u27e9 \u2192 (\u20131)^{x\u00b7y} |x,y\u27e9 \n\nThus the unknown memory qubits are teleported back to A and B with the CZ applied between them. No dynamic control is needed\u2014just static optics and heralding.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3}):\n{\n  description:      'Heralded tele-CZ gate for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydTeleCZ',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],           // modes: A_photon, B_photon, ancilla pair\n  amplitudes:       [[2,3]],             // one Bell-pair source on modes 2&3\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],               // clicks on detectors D2 & D3 herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00->00','01->01','10->10','11->-11'], // ideal CZ mapping\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          15,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Implements a nonlocal two-qubit CZ gate between remote Rydberg memories in one static linear\u2010optical device.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to multi-gate, graph-state fusion modules by adding ancilla Bell pairs and extending the interferometer.  \n \u2022 A centerpiece for distributed quantum computing and repeater protocols that require remote entangling gates, not just swapping.  \n \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope: abstract photonic modes, static interferometer, single-photon sources, heralding detectors\u2014no feedback or cavities needed.  \n\nThis target invites Pytheus to discover the minimal interferometer and detection scheme that, via post-selection, teleports a CZ between two atomic memories\u2014opening a new primitive for quantum networks and distributed processing.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This overlaps with standard teleportation-based entangling gates (e.g. the PT-symmetric tele-CNOT) and KLM-style non-deterministic CZ teleportation. Instead of a single entanglement\u2010swap station, there are two ancilla memories C and D, each initially sharing a Bell pair with A and B respectively:\n \u2022 Bell pair A\u2013C in photonic modes 2&3  \n \u2022 Bell pair B\u2013D in photonic modes 4&5  \nWe also introduce one control photon (mode 6), prepared in an equal superposition of two path\u2010labels |c1\u27e9+|c2\u27e9. All seven photons enter a single static 7\u00d77 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. At the output, seven number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D6 monitor every mode.\n\nThe network is arranged so that:\n \u2022 If the control lives in path c1, the interferometer implements a Bell measurement on modes 2&3 first (swap via C),  \n \u2022 If it lives in path c2, it implements the Bell measurement on modes 4&5 first (swap via D).  \nBecause the control photon remains unmeasured and both paths are coherently recombined, the order of the two swap\u2010modules is placed in superposition. Conditioned on a single \u201cheralding\u2010click\u201d in a designated ancilla detector subset (e.g. D2), the two unmeasured output modes corresponding to A and B collapse into an entangled state. Crucially, A\u2013B becomes entangled by a pathway that is in an indefinite causal order\u2014an equal superposition of \u201cswap via C then D\u201d and \u201cswap via D then C.\u201d\n\nThis realizes a new network primitive: superposed\u2010order entanglement swapping (a photonic quantum SWITCH applied to Bell\u2010measurements), directly coupling Rydberg\u2010memory nodes in a way no prior static device has done.\n\nexample config skeleton:\n{\n  description:      'Q\u2010SWITCH entanglement swap between A,B via C,D',\n  foldername:       'RydQSwitchSwap',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,6],             // modes A, B, control\n  amplitudes:       [[2,3],[4,5]],       // two Bell\u2010pair sources: A\u2013C, B\u2013D\n  heralding_out:    [2],                  // e.g. click on detector D2 heralds success\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],          // AB in Bell basis on unmeasured modes\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      50,\n  tries_per_edge:   10,\n  samples:          30,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 First static\u2010optical realization of a quantum SWITCH on entanglement\u2010swapping modules\u2014placing the order of two Bell measurements in superposition.  \n \u2022 Goes beyond \u201centanglement router\u201d or \u201cpercolation switch\u201d: it introduces indefinite causal structure into a basic quantum\u2010network link operation.  \n \u2022 Directly uses Rydberg\u2010memory nodes as the endpoints and purely photonic ancillas and static optics\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to N\u2010swap superpositions, larger networks, and studies of causal order in entanglement distribution.\n\nThis invites Pytheus to discover the minimal 7\u00d77 interferometer and detection scheme that, via post\u2010selection, implements a superposed\u2010order entanglement swap between If the control was in |+\u27e9, the two memories end up entangled in a superposition of two different linkings\u2014a new programmable/superposed network transformation.\n\nexample Pytheus config:\n{\n  description:       'Quantum\u2010controlled entanglement swap',\n  foldername:        'RydQControlSwap',\n  single_emitters:   [0,1,2,3,4],        // modes: A,B,C,D, control\n  amplitudes:        [[0,1],[2,3]],      // Bell\u2010pair sources for A\u2013B and C\u2013D\n  heralding_out:     [1,2,4],            // detectors D1,D2 for swap, D4 for control\u2010measurement\n  target_mapping: {                      // mapping of A,B,C,D control inputs to remaining outputs\n    // condition on control outcome c=0 \u2192 swap A\u2013D; c=1 \u2192 swap B\u2013C\n    'c0': ['AD_Bell'], \n    'c1': ['BC_Bell']\n  },\n  optimizer:         'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:         'cr',\n  edges_tried:       50,\n  tries_per_edge:    10,\n  samples:           30,\n  thresholds:        [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving:  true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 First programmable, quantum\u2010controlled entanglement\u2010swapping device: a single static interferometer whose action\u2014\u201cwhich memories get entangled\u201d\u2014is selected by a control qubit, even in superposition.  \n \u2022 Goes beyond fixed swap/routing: it embeds a quantum \u201cif\u2010then\u201d in the network link, allowing superposed network configurations.  \n \u2022 Directly ties Rydberg\u2010atom memories to advanced network coding and quantum\u2010switch ideas, yet uses only static linear optics and heralding; permuted state:\n     (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A): |\u03c8\u27e9_A\u2297|\u03d5\u27e9_B\u2297|\u03c7\u27e9_C  \u2192  |\u03c7\u27e9_A\u2297|\u03c8\u27e9_B\u2297|\u03d5\u27e9_C  \n   thus implementing the 3-cycle unitary U_cycle: |abc\u27e9 \u2192 |cab\u27e9 in one shot.\n\nThis realizes a new network\u2010primitive: a teleportation ring that shifts three quantum states around a triangle of memories in a single passive, heralded linear-optical device.\n\nexample Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:      '3-party teleportation ring (cyclic permutation)',\n  foldername:   [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Implements the cyclic shift unitary on three unknown qubits via simultaneous teleportations in one static device, a They each convert their qubit into a single photon in modes 0 and 1.  A third single\u2010photon emitter (mode 2) supplies an ancilla photon in a fixed reference state.  All three photons enter a single static 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus).  The three outputs go to number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2.  Exactly one click heralds one of two projective outcomes on the two unknown modes:\n\n \u2022 If D0 clicks \u2192 the two memories are projected onto the symmetric subspace (test \u201cequal\u201d)  \n \u2022 If D1 clicks \u2192 the two memories are projected onto the antisymmetric subspace (test \u201cdifferent\u201d)  \n \u2022 Click on D2 \u2192 inconclusive (discard)\n\nThus, in one passive module we implement the SWAP\u2010test between remote Rydberg\u2010qubit memories.\n\nexample Pytheus config:\n{\n  description:      'Nonlocal SWAP\u2010test for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'Rydberg_SWAPTest',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],            // modes: A_unknown, B_unknown, ancilla\n  heralding_out:    [0,1],              // D0 \u2192 symmetric; D1 \u2192 antisymmetric\n  target_quantum:   [                      // projector on modes 0&1\n    D0: ['symm'],    D1: ['antisymm']\n  ],\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      20,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Fundamental network operation: direct quantum\u2010state comparison (SWAP\u2010test) across remote memories, not mere entanglement distribution.  \n \u2022 Building block for quantum\u2010fingerprinting, signature verification, and distributed consensus protocols.  \n \u2022 Fully static, heralded linear-optics module\u2014exactly Pytheus\u2019s domain\u2014with clear generalizations to multi-memory comparison networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates standard two\u2010qubit SWAP\u2010test constructions already found in the literature and the ensemble (e.g. generalized multi\u2010copy SWAP tests). Our goal is: in one static device, teleport any one chosen unknown state |\u03c8_i\u27e9 from A_i to any chosen receiver R_j on demand\u2014by simply postselecting on the heralding detector pattern (i,j), without reconfiguring optics.\n\nSetup:\n 1. Each sender A_i emits its unknown qubit as a single photon (modes 0\u2026N-1).  \n 2. The central station Z prepares M photonic Bell-pairs: for each receiver R_j, modes (N+2j\u22122, N+2j\u22121) form an abstract |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 pair.  \n 3. All N + 2M photons enter one fixed (N+2M)\u00d7(N+2M) linear-optical interferometer (beam splitters & phases)\u2014to be optimized by Pytheus.  \n 4. The (N+2M) output modes are monitored by number-resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D_{N+2M\u22121}.  \n 5. For each pair (i,j), there is a unique heralding_out pattern\u2014a specified set of M+1 detector clicks\u2014that projects the remaining unclicked output mode at R_j onto the state |\u03c8_i\u27e9.  All other outputs and detectors herald the transfer.\n\nBy running Pytheus with heralding_out arrays corresponding to each (i,j), one recovers a single static interferometer whose multiple click-patterns implement teleportation from any sender to any receiver on demand.\n\nexample config for N=3 senders, M=2 receivers (total modes=7):\n{\n  description:      '3\u21922 teleportation switchboard',\n  foldername:       'Ryd_Tele_Switch3to2',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],           // unknown qubit modes from A\u2081,A\u2082,A\u2083\n  amplitudes:       [[3,4],[5,6]],     // two Bell pairs connecting Z\u21c4R\u2081 and Z\u21c4R\u2082\n  in_nodes:         [],\n  out_nodes:        [],\n  heralding_out:    [],                // to be filled with detector sets for each (i,j)\n  target_mapping: {                     // for each (i,j) pattern, map mode i\u2192receiver j\n    '(i,j)': '\u03c8_i appears at output port for R_j'\n  },\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      50,\n  tries_per_edge:   10,\n  samples:          20,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Introduces the first on-demand teleportation multiplexer (\u201cswitchboard\u201d) for quantum memories\u2014an essential primitive for flexible quantum-internet routing.  \n \u2022 Directly ties Rydberg atomic memories to a static linear-optical network that handles unknown states, showing how to multiplex teleportation paths in one device.  \n \u2022 Generalizes immediately to any N\u2192M configuration\u2014stamp out a family of experiments and performance studies.  \n \u2022 Fully compatible with Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: only abstract modes, linear optics, single-photon emitters, Bell-pair sources, number-resolving detectors\u2014no dynamic feedback or forbidden elements.\n\nThis target challenges Pytheus to find the minimal interferometer and heralding scheme that multiplexes teleportation among any chosen pair of nodes in an atomic array\u2014a new frontier in photonic quantum-network design.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is a straightforward N\u2192M generalization LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nI need a truly new quantum-network transformation\u2014neither plain state prep nor a small twist on swapping/router ideas\u2014that ties a Rydberg\u2010atom array to entangled photonic ancillas and lives wholly within Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optics + heralding framework. A universal 1\u21922 quantum cloner is exactly such a primitive: it takes one unknown qubit at Rydberg node A and, using only static beam splitters, blank ancillas, and post-selection, produces two optimal clones at nodes B and C. This \u201ctele-cloning\u201d device is a new multiparty network channel, not mere state generation, and generalizes immediately to N\u2192M tele-cloners. \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target for Pytheus:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cHeralded 1\u21922 Universal Tele-Cloner for Rydberg Memories\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have three Rydberg\u2010atom memory nodes A, B, C.  \n \u2022 A holds an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9_A, which it converts into a single photon in mode 0.  \n \u2022 B and C are \u201cblank\u201d memories; each supplies one ancilla photon prepared in the known state |0\u27e9 (modes 1 and 2).  \nAll three photons enter one static 3\u00d73 linear-optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters), which Pytheus will optimize. The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Whenever exactly one heralding click occurs on detector D2, the two unclicked output modes (mapped back to memories B and C) collapse into the two optimal approximate clones of |\u03c8\u27e9_A with fidelity 5/6 (the universal cloning bound). A click on D0 or D1 indicates failure (discard).\n\nThis device implements the universal 1\u21922 cloning channel by passive linear optics and post-selection:\n\n   |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080\u2297|00\u27e9\u2081\u2082  \u2192 (herald D2) \u2192  2/3|\u03c8\u03c8\u27e9 + (1/6)(|\u03c8 \u03c8_\u22a5\u27e9+|\u03c8_\u22a5 \u03c8\u27e9)\n\non modes mapped to B and C, the two clones.  \n\nexample Pytheus config stub:\n{\n  description:      'Heralded 1\u21922 universal tele-cloner for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydUQCM_1to2',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],            // mode 0: unknown qubit; modes 1,2: ancilla blanks\n  heralding_out:    [2],                // click on D2 heralds successful cloning\n  target_quantum:   [                     // target mapping on modes 0,1 \u2192 clones in modes B,C\n    '000'-> ['200','020','002']  // shorthand: map input basis to the 3-photon output superposition for optimal clones\n    // Pytheus will expand this into the exact 5/6 & 1/6 amplitude pattern \n  ],\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      20,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Universal tele-cloning is a key multiparty channel\u2014producing two approximate copies of an unknown qubit\u2014that goes beyond swapping or routing.  \n \u2022 It is the first passive linear-optical \u201ctele-cloner\u201d linking Rydberg memories: one unknown input, two blank ancillas, and heralding detectors realize the optimal 1\u21922 cloning map.  \n \u2022 Generalizes immediately to N\u2192M tele-cloners by adding ancilla photons and scaling the interferometer\u2014yielding a whole new class of quantum-network primitives.  \n \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s remit: uses only abstract photonic modes, single-photon sources, static beam splitters & phases, and number-resolving detectors\u2014no dynamic feedback, cavities, or hyper-entanglement. \n\nThis target challenges Pytheus to find the minimal 3\u00d73 interferometer and detection scheme that enacts the universal cloning channel by post-selection\u2014a novel building block for quantum-network coding, distributed sensing, and multi-party quantum information protocols.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the ensemble\u2019s qubit telecloning targets.     "output": "Here is a genuinely new quantum-network primitive\u2014no raw state generation\u2014that marries a Rydberg-atom array with entangled photonic ancillas and lives entirely inside Pytheus\u2019s static linear-optics + heralding framework:\n\nEXPERIMENT \u201cHeralded 3-Qubit GHZ-Basis Analyzer for Rydberg Memories\u201d\n\nexplanation:\nWe have three Rydberg-atom memory qubits A, B, C held at distant sites.  Each memory qubit is converted on demand into one single photon in abstract modes 0, 1, 2.  To perform a joint GHZ-basis measurement on these three qubits, we supply two photonic Bell-pair ancillas at a central station Z (modes 3&4 and 5&6, each in |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9).  All seven photons enter one static 7\u00d77 linear-optical network (beam-splitters & phase-shifters), which Pytheus will optimize.  The seven outputs are monitored by number-resolving detectors D0\u2026D6.  \n\nBy post-selecting on one of four distinct three-click patterns in a designated ancilla detector subset, the three unclicked detectors (i.e. the three output modes originally carrying A, B, C) are projected onto one of the four canonical GHZ basis states:\n  1) |000\u27e9+|111\u27e9  \n  2) |000\u27e9\u2013|111\u27e9  \n  3) |001\u27e9+|110\u27e9  \n  4) |001\u27e9\u2013|110\u27e9  \n\nThus the device implements a full four-outcome GHZ-basis measurement of three remote memories in one static heralded module\u2014no dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, only linear optics and photon counting.\n\nexample Pytheus config:\n{\n  description:      '3-qubit GHZ-basis analyzer for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydGHZAnalyzer3',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],              // modes from memories A, B, C\n  amplitudes:       [[3,4],[5,6]],        // two Bell-pair ancilla sources at Z\n  heralding_out:    [                       // sets of detector indices for each GHZ outcome\n    [d0,d1,d2],  // herald for |000\u27e9+|111\u27e9  \n    [d0,d1,d3],  // herald for |000\u27e9\u2013|111\u27e9  \n    [d0,d2,d3],  // herald for |001\u27e9+|110\u27e9  \n    [d1,d2,d3]   // herald for |001\u27e9\u2013|110\u27e9  \n  ],\n  target_quantum: {\n    '[clicks d0,d1,d2]' : ['000','111'],\n    '[d0,d1,d3]'       : ['000','-111'],\n    '[d0,d2,d3]'       : ['001','110'],\n    '[d1,d2,d3]'       : ['001','-110']\n  },\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      60,\n  tries_per_edge:   8,\n  samples:          20,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and novel:\n\u2022 It provides the first *static* linear-optical module that carries out a *full* GHZ-basis projection on three remote quantum memories\u2014an essential building block for multi-party entanglement swapping, network coding, cluster-state fusion, and distributed measurement-based protocols.  \n\u2022 It fuses a Rydberg-atom array (as long-lived memories) with entangled photonic resources in a single heralded interferometer, sidestepping all dynamic feed-forward or resonant elements.  \n\u2022 As soon as Pytheus finds the 7\u00d77 network and click patterns, one can generalize to 4-, 5- or N-qubit GHZ measurements simply by adding more ancilla Bell-pairs and extending the interferometer\u2014yielding a whole family of nonlocal measurement primitives for quantum networks.  \n\u2022 This target focuses squarely on an *interesting transformation* (GHZ basis measurement) rather than on producing a GHZ state, perfectly aligned with Pytheus\u2019s strengths and the given constraints."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. Physically, each of the N array nodes (e.g. N=3 or 4 for demonstration) holds a Rydberg atomic qubit whose excitation can be converted into a single photon.  We assume that each node emits one photon entangled with its atomic memory (an abstract photonic mode).  All N photons enter a single N-port interferometer network, mix via beam splitters and phase shifters, and exit at output ports monitored by ancilla photon-number-resolving detectors.  Different click patterns at these ancilla detectors herald a Bell\u2010pair between exactly two of the memory qubits\u2014thereby routing entanglement on demand, without reconfiguring optics.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Generalizes entanglement swapping to a fully passive, reconfigurable router.  \n \u2022 Enables multiplexed, on-demand Bell\u2010links across any pair of atomic memory nodes.  \n \u2022 Lays groundwork for scalable quantum\u2010network switches and network\u2010coding primitives in Rydberg-based quantum repeaters or quantum internet nodes.\n\nKey Pytheus configuration elements (expert to flesh out):\n \u2022 single_emitters = [0,\u2026,N\u20131]  (one photon per memory node)  \n \u2022 a single multiport network (to be optimized) with N inputs \u2192 M outputs (M\u2265N)  \n \u2022 ancilla detectors on M\u20132 ports, leaving 2 \u201cmemory\u2010link\u201d output ports free  \n \u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct two-photon collisions between non-chosen node pairs if desired  \n \u2022 target_quantum: a set of Bell states on every 2-node subset; optimize so that each ancilla\u2010click pattern projects the remaining two output modes onto |00>+|11>  \n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the minimal multiport interferometer and detector arrangement that, upon heralding, routes entanglement between arbitrary node pairs\u2014an architecture-level quantum\u2010network primitive novel to the linear\u2010optical toolbox.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router\u201d proposal. Each node coherently converts its atomic excitation into one photon (abstract mode 0,1,2). These three photons enter a single 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus). The three outputs go to photon-number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Whenever exactly one detector Di clicks, the remaining two (unclicked) output modes are projected into a two-qubit Bell state |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of Rydberg memories. Thus:\n \u2022 D0 click \u2192 entangles B&C  \n \u2022 D1 click \u2192 entangles A&C  \n \u2022 D2 click \u2192 entangles A&B  \n\nThis is a passive, heralded entanglement router: by post-selecting on which detector fires, we choose which pair of memories becomes entangled, without reconfiguring the optics.\n\nconfig (example for heralding D2 \u2192 entangle A&B):\n{'description':'Passive 3-node entanglement router for Rydberg memories','foldername':'RydbergRouter3','single_emitters':[0,1,2],'num_anc':1,'heralding_out':[2],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'in_nodes':[],'out_nodes':[],'anc_detectors':[],'removed_connections':[],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':30,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':10,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo cover all three routing patterns, one simply repeats the optimization with heralding_out=[0] and heralding_out=[1]: each run yields the same static interferometer but different herald-detector assignment projects onto the desired Bell link. This architecture scales to N nodes via an N\u00d7N multiport and N single-photon sources.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This target is too similar to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Entanglement Router\u201d proposal. Each node emits one photon (modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter a single 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer (to be optimized). The outputs go to four photon-number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the remaining two unclicked output modes are projected into the Bell state |00>+|11> of the corresponding two memories. Different click-pairs activate different network links:\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangles C&D (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangles B&D (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangles A&C (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangles A&B (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangles B&C (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangles A&D (diagonal AD)  \n\nconfig (example for heralding clicks {0,1} \u2192 entangle C&D):\n{'description':'4-node percolation switch','foldername':'RydbergPercolation4','single_emitters':[0,1,2,3],'num_anc':0,'heralding_out':[0,1],'target_quantum':['00','11'],'optimizer':'L-BFGS-B','loss_func':'cr','bulk_thr':0.0,'edges_tried':40,'tries_per_edge':5,'samples':20,'thresholds':[0.3,0.1],'number_resolving':True}\n\nTo generate the full percolation cell, one runs six optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair. convert into single photons (modes 0,1).  \n\u2022 A central station Z generates two photonic Bell pairs: modes 2\u20133 entangle Z\u21c4C, modes 4\u20135 entangle Z\u21c4D.  \n\u2022 All six photons (modes 0\u20135) enter a single static 6\u00d76 linear-optical network (beam splitters & phase shifters) that Pytheus will optimize.  \n\u2022 Outputs go to six photon-number-resolving detectors: four \u201cBell-measurement\u201d detectors at Z (indices d0\u2013d3) and two \u201creceiver\u201d detectors at C (d4) and D (d5).  \n\u2022 Upon one of two distinct four-click patterns at {d0,d1,d2,d3}, the unknown qubit from A emerges at D and from B emerges at C, implementing simultaneous crossed teleportation (A\u2192D, B\u2192C). A different heralding pattern implements the alternate routing (A\u2192C, B\u2192D).\n\nconfig example (for heralding pattern routing A\u2192D, B\u2192C):\n{\n  description:      'Butterfly network-coded teleportation',\n  foldername:       'ryd_butterfly_tele',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1],          // A,B unknown-state emitters\n  amplitudes:       [],             // two Bell pairs at Z are implicit pair sources\n  in_nodes:         [],\n  out_nodes:        [],\n  heralding_out:    [d0,d1,d2,d3],  // specific four-click set at Z\n  target_mapping: {                   // teleportation map for computational basis\n    '00'-> output at (D,C) = '00',\n    '01'->                  '10',\n    '10'->                  '01',\n    '11'->                  '11'\n  },\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      50,\n  tries_per_edge:   10,\n  samples:          30,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 First linear-optical implementation of the quantum butterfly network code, a true network-coding primitive.  \n \u2022 Ties Rydberg atomic memories to advanced teleportation routing without dynamic control.  \n \u2022 Scales to larger network codes by extending the interferometer and heralding patterns.\n\nThis task asks Pytheus to discover the minimal static interferometer & detection scheme that, via heralded post-selection, performs two crossed teleportations in one device\u2014opening a new frontier in quantum network coding.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s butterfly cross\u2010teleportation target. Each converts its memory excitation into one single photon (abstract modes 0\u20133). All four photons enter one static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Whenever exactly two detectors Di and Dj click, the two unclicked output modes collapse into a Bell pair |00>+|11> between the corresponding pair of memories. By post-selecting on different click-pairs, one \u201cactivates\u201d any of the six possible links in the square:\n\n \u2022 clicks {D0,D1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D  (edge CD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D2} \u2192 entangle B\u2013D  (edge BD)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013C  (edge AC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D2,D3} \u2192 entangle A\u2013B  (edge AB)  \n \u2022 clicks {D0,D3} \u2192 entangle B\u2013C  (diagonal BC)  \n \u2022 clicks {D1,D2} \u2192 entangle A\u2013D  (diagonal AD)\n\nThis single device realizes all six entanglement-swapping channels in one static interferometer, enabling studies of entanglement percolation, network-coding primitives, and dynamic connectivity in a minimal four-node cell.\n\nexample config (for heralding {0,1} \u2192 entangle C\u2013D):\n{\n  description:      '4-node percolation switch',\n  foldername:       'RydbergPercolation4',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],        // A,B,C,D emitters\n  num_anc:          0,\n  heralding_out:    [0,1],            // detectors Di,Dj that click\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],       // Bell basis on the remaining modes\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          20,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nOne runs six separate Pytheus optimizations\u2014each with a different heralding_out pair\u2014to recover a single 4\u00d74 network whose various two-click patterns select any desired Bell link. All four photons enter a single static 4\u00d74 linear-optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus). This implements one round of the BBPSSW entanglement-distillation protocol in a single passive module\u2014no dynamic feed-forward, no cavities, only static linear optics and heralding. By cascading or interconnecting multiple such modules, one can build multi-stage purification chains for long-distance quantum repeater networks.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3} \u2192 purified A\u2013B Bell pair):\n{\n  description:      'Entanglement purification for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydPurification2',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],       // modes from A:a1,a2 and B:b1,b2\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],           // detectors D2,D3 clicks herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00','11'],      // purified Bell basis on modes 0,1\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      30,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Introduces the first static, heralded entanglement-distillation primitive for Rydberg-atom quantum memories in a single module.  \n \u2022 Moves beyond point-to-point swapping: it cleans noisy links, a vital network primitive toward scalable repeaters.  \n \u2022 Fully generalizable to multi-stage purification chains and to higher dimensions by extending the network size and detection patterns.\n\nThis target leverages Pytheus\u2019s strength\u2014optimizing static linear-optical networks with single-photon sources and heralding detectors\u2014to discover minimal purification circuits, forging a new building block for quantum-network protocols.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the ensemble\u2019s one\u2010shot swap-and-concentrate repeater. Each memory\u2019s qubit is converted into one photon (abstract modes 0 and 1) that carries its Z\u2010basis information. We also introduce one ancillary single\u2010photon emitter (mode 2) to mediate the joint measurement. All three photons enter a single static 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The three output modes are monitored by number\u2010resolving detectors D0, D1, D2. Depending on which detector clicks (exactly one click), the two Rydberg memories collapse into one of the two Z\u2297Z parity subspaces:\n\n \u2022 If Di clicks with i\u2208{0,1}, the memories are projected onto the even\u2010parity Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 (heralded by detector patterns {0} or {1}).  \n \u2022 If D2 clicks, the memories are projected onto the odd\u2010parity Bell state |01\u27e9+|10\u27e9 (heralded by {2}).\n\nThis realizes a non\u2010destructive, heralded remote Z\u2297Z parity check between two atomic qubits in one static module\u2014an essential building block for distributed error syndrome extraction and measurement\u2010based network protocols.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding Di\u2192even or odd parity):\n{\n  description:      'Heralded parity measurement for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydParityMeas',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],         // modes from A, B, and ancilla\n  heralding_out:    [i],             // i=0 or 1 \u2192 even parity; i=2 \u2192 odd parity\n  target_quantum:   (i<2 ? ['00','11'] : ['01','10']),\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      20,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 A joint nonlocal parity measurement is a key network transform\u2014beyond swapping or teleportation\u2014that underpins entanglement purification, error syndrome extraction, and measurement\u2010based repeater protocols.  \n \u2022 We deploy only static linear optics, three single\u2010photon emitters, and heralding detectors\u2014perfectly within Pytheus\u2019s remit.  \n \u2022 The concept generalizes immediately to N\u2010qubit stabilizer checks (e.g. 4\u2010mode network for X\u2297X\u2297Z\u2297Z) by adding ancilla emitters and detectors.  \n \u2022 This primitive opens new avenues for distributed quantum error correction and measurement\u2010based quantum networking with Rydberg\u2010memory nodes.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core parity\u2010measurement primitive duplicates the previously suggested nonlocal parity gate. Each memory is converted on demand into a single photon in modes 0 and 1. We also prepare one photonic Bell pair (ancilla) in modes 2 & 3 (abstractly |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9). All four photons enter a single static 4\u00d74 linear-optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The four outputs go to four number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D3. Conditioned on a specific two-click heralding pattern (e.g. clicks on D2 & D3), the two photonic inputs from A and B emerge (in the remaining unclicked outputs) having undergone a CZ gate:\n\n  CZ : |x,y\u27e9 \u2192 (\u20131)^{x\u00b7y} |x,y\u27e9 \n\nThus the unknown memory qubits are teleported back to A and B with the CZ applied between them. No dynamic control is needed\u2014just static optics and heralding.\n\nexample Pytheus config (for heralding {2,3}):\n{\n  description:      'Heralded tele-CZ gate for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'RydTeleCZ',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2,3],           // modes: A_photon, B_photon, ancilla pair\n  amplitudes:       [[2,3]],             // one Bell-pair source on modes 2&3\n  heralding_out:    [2,3],               // clicks on detectors D2 & D3 herald success\n  target_quantum:   ['00->00','01->01','10->10','11->-11'], // ideal CZ mapping\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      40,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          15,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and novel:\n \u2022 Implements a nonlocal two-qubit CZ gate between remote Rydberg memories in one static linear\u2010optical device.  \n \u2022 Generalizes to multi-gate, graph-state fusion modules by adding ancilla Bell pairs and extending the interferometer.  \n \u2022 A centerpiece for distributed quantum computing and repeater protocols that require remote entangling gates, not just swapping.  \n \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope: abstract photonic modes, static interferometer, single-photon sources, heralding detectors\u2014no feedback or cavities needed.  \n\nThis target invites Pytheus to discover the minimal interferometer and detection scheme that, via post-selection, teleports a CZ between two atomic memories\u2014opening a new primitive for quantum networks and distributed processing.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This overlaps with standard teleportation-based entangling gates (e.g. the PT-symmetric tele-CNOT) and KLM-style non-deterministic CZ teleportation. Instead of a single entanglement\u2010swap station, there are two ancilla memories C and D, each initially sharing a Bell pair with A and B respectively:\n \u2022 Bell pair A\u2013C in photonic modes 2&3  \n \u2022 Bell pair B\u2013D in photonic modes 4&5  \nWe also introduce one control photon (mode 6), prepared in an equal superposition of two path\u2010labels |c1\u27e9+|c2\u27e9. All seven photons enter a single static 7\u00d77 linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. At the output, seven number\u2010resolving detectors D0\u2013D6 monitor every mode.\n\nThe network is arranged so that:\n \u2022 If the control lives in path c1, the interferometer implements a Bell measurement on modes 2&3 first (swap via C),  \n \u2022 If it lives in path c2, it implements the Bell measurement on modes 4&5 first (swap via D).  \nBecause the control photon remains unmeasured and both paths are coherently recombined, the order of the two swap\u2010modules is placed in superposition. Conditioned on a single \u201cheralding\u2010click\u201d in a designated ancilla detector subset (e.g. D2), the two unmeasured output modes corresponding to A and B collapse into an entangled state. Crucially, A\u2013B becomes entangled by a pathway that is in an indefinite causal order\u2014an equal superposition of \u201cswap via C then D\u201d and \u201cswap via D then C.\u201d\n\nThis realizes a new network primitive: superposed\u2010order entanglement swapping (a photonic quantum SWITCH applied to Bell\u2010measurements), directly coupling Rydberg\u2010memory nodes in a way no prior static device has done.\n\nexample config skeleton:\n{\n  description:      'Q\u2010SWITCH entanglement swap between A,B via C,D',\n  foldername:       'RydQSwitchSwap',\n  single_emitters: Initially two Bell pairs are shared:\n \u2022 Pair 1: A\u2013B \u2192 photons in modes 0 & 1  \n \u2022 Pair 2: C\u2013D \u2192 photons in modes 2 & 3  \nA fifth photon (mode 4) serves as a control qubit, prepared in the state (|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2 by a single\u2010photon emitter.  \nAll five photons enter one static 5\u00d75 linear\u2010optical interferometer (beam splitters + phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus. The five outputs go to detectors D0\u2013D4 (number\u2010resolving).  \n\nLogical operation:\n \u2022 If the control qubit is measured in state |0\u27e9, the interferometer\u2019s projection entangles memories A\u2013D by performing a Bell measurement on modes {1,2}, swapping entanglement from C\u2013D to A\u2013D.  \n \u2022 If the control is |1\u27e9, it instead swaps the A\u2013B link across memories B\u2013C.  \n \u2022 Because the control photon is injected as |+\u27e9, the device realizes a coherent superposition of \u201cswap via BC\u201d and \u201cswap via AD.\u201d  \n\nBy post\u2010selecting on a specific joint click pattern\u2014two clicks on the \u201cswap\u201d detectors (e.g. D1 & D2) plus one click on the control\u2010measurement detector (D4)\u2014the two unmeasured output modes correspond to the entangled memory pair programmed by the control. If the control was in |+\u27e9, the two memories end up entangled in a superposition of two different linkings\u2014a new programmable/superposed network transformation.\n\nexample Pytheus config:\n{\n  description:       'Quantum\u2010controlled entanglement swap',\n  foldername:        'RydQControlSwap',\n  single_emitters:   [0,1,2,3,4],        // modes: A,B,C,D, control\n  amplitudes:        [[0,1],[2,3]],      // Bell\u2010pair sources for A\u2013B and C\u2013D\n  heralding_out:     [1,2,4],            // detectors D1,D2 for swap, D4 for control\u2010measurement\n  target_mapping: {                      // mapping of A,B,C,D control inputs to remaining outputs\n    // condition on control outcome c=0 \u2192 swap A\u2013D; c=1 \u2192 swap B\u2013C\n    'c0': ['AD_Bell'], \n    'c1': ['BC_Bell']\n  },\n  optimizer:         'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:         'cr',\n  edges_tried:       50,\n  tries_per_edge:    10,\n  samples:           30,\n  thresholds:        [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving:  true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 First programmable, quantum\u2010controlled entanglement\u2010swapping device: a single static interferometer whose action\u2014\u201cwhich memories get entangled\u201d\u2014is selected by a control qubit, even in superposition.  \n \u2022 Goes beyond fixed swap/routing: it embeds a quantum \u201cif\u2010then\u201d in the network link, allowing superposed network configurations.  \n \u2022 Directly ties Rydberg\u2010atom memories to advanced network coding and quantum\u2010switch ideas, yet uses only static linear optics and heralding; fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.  \n \u2022 Generalizable to N memories and multi\u2010control photons for richer programmable network fabrics.\n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the minimal 5\u00d75 interferometer and detector arrangement that, via post\u2010selection, implements a quantum\u2010controlled entanglement\u2010swapping gate between atomic memories\u2014a new quantum\u2010network primitive.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the ensemble\u2019s photonic quantum-switch primitives. Memories A, B, C are each converted into single photons in modes 0, 1, 2 respectively.  \n2. A central station Z generates three Bell pairs (ancillas):\n   \u2022 Pair Z1: modes 3 & 4  \n   \u2022 Pair Z2: modes 5 & 6  \n   \u2022 Pair Z3: modes 7 & 8  \n3. All nine photons (modes 0\u20138) enter one static 9\u00d79 linear-optical interferometer (beam splitters & phase shifters) to be optimized by Pytheus.  \n4. The nine output modes are measured by nine photon-number-resolving detectors D0\u2013D8.  \n5. When exactly six detectors corresponding to the three Bell measurements (e.g. clicks on {D3,D4,D5,D6,D7,D8}) click, the three unmeasured outputs (from modes 0\u20132) collapse into the cyclically permuted state:\n     (A\u2192B, B\u2192C, C\u2192A): |\u03c8\u27e9_A\u2297|\u03d5\u27e9_B\u2297|\u03c7\u27e9_C  \u2192  |\u03c7\u27e9_A\u2297|\u03c8\u27e9_B\u2297|\u03d5\u27e9_C  \n   thus implementing the 3-cycle unitary U_cycle: |abc\u27e9 \u2192 |cab\u27e9 in one shot.\n\nThis realizes a new network\u2010primitive: a teleportation ring that shifts three quantum states around a triangle of memories in a single passive, heralded linear-optical device.\n\nexample Pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:      '3-party teleportation ring (cyclic permutation)',\n  foldername:  out_nodes:        [],\n  heralding_out:    [3,4,5,6,7,8],      // six detectors for the three Bell measurements\n  target_mapping: {                       // mapping for computational basis strings\n    'abc'->'cab' for all a,b,c\u2208{0,1}\n  },\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      80,\n  tries_per_edge:   10,\n  samples:          40,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Implements the cyclic shift unitary on three unknown qubits via simultaneous teleportations in one static device, a They each convert their qubit into a single photon in modes 0 and 1.  A third single\u2010photon emitter (mode 2) supplies an ancilla photon in a fixed reference state.  All three photons enter a single static 3\u00d73 linear\u2010optical network of beam splitters and phase shifters (to be optimized by Pytheus).  The three outputs go to number-resolving detectors D0, D1, D2.  Exactly one click heralds one of two projective outcomes on the two unknown modes:\n\n \u2022 If D0 clicks \u2192 the two memories are projected onto the symmetric subspace (test \u201cequal\u201d)  \n \u2022 If D1 clicks \u2192 the two memories are projected onto the antisymmetric subspace (test \u201cdifferent\u201d)  \n \u2022 Click on D2 \u2192 inconclusive (discard)\n\nThus, in one passive module we implement the SWAP\u2010test between remote Rydberg\u2010qubit memories.\n\nexample Pytheus config:\n{\n  description:      'Nonlocal SWAP\u2010test for Rydberg memories',\n  foldername:       'Rydberg_SWAPTest',\n  single_emitters:  [0,1,2],            // modes: A_unknown, B_unknown, ancilla\n  heralding_out:    [0,1],              // D0 \u2192 symmetric; D1 \u2192 antisymmetric\n  target_quantum:   [                      // projector on modes 0&1\n    D0: ['symm'],    D1: ['antisymm']\n  ],\n  optimizer:        'L-BFGS-B',\n  loss_func:        'cr',\n  edges_tried:      20,\n  tries_per_edge:   5,\n  samples:          10,\n  thresholds:       [0.3,0.1],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Fundamental network operation: direct quantum\u2010state comparison (SWAP\u2010test) across remote memories, not mere entanglement distribution.  \n \u2022 Building block for quantum\u2010fingerprinting, signature verification, and distributed consensus protocols.  \n \u2022 Fully static, heralded linear-optics module\u2014exactly Pytheus\u2019s domain\u2014with clear generalizations to multi-memory comparison networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates standard two\u2010qubit SWAP\u2010test constructions already found in the literature and the ensemble (e.g. generalized multi\u2010copy SWAP tests).
